279{padding-top:7.5pt;padding-bottom:0pt;line-height:1.5;text-align:left}.c138{padding-top:14pt;padding-bottom:20pt;line-height:1.15;text-align:left}.c99{padding-top:20pt;padding-bottom:11pt;line-height:1.1500000000000001;text-align:left}.c70{font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-family:"Arial"}.c109{padding-top:0pt;padding-bottom:8pt;line-height:1.15;text-align:left}.c292{padding-top:0pt;padding-bottom:12pt;line-height:1.5999999999999999;text-align:left}.c168{padding-top:0pt;padding-bottom:9pt;line-height:1.7;text-align:left}.c205{padding-top:14pt;padding-bottom:6pt;line-height:1.1500000000000001;text-align:left}.c201{padding-top:0pt;padding-bottom:3pt;line-height:1.0;text-align:left}.c289{padding-top:0pt;padding-bottom:0pt;line-height:1.1500000000000001;text-align:center}.c177{padding-top:8pt;padding-bottom:23pt;line-height:1.5999999999999999;text-align:left}.c136{padding-top:20pt;padding-bottom:19pt;line-height:1.1500000000000001;text-align:left}.c194{padding-top:20pt;padding-bottom:12pt;line-height:1.1500000000000001;text-align:left}.c191{padding-top:0pt;padding-bottom:0pt;line-height:1.5625;text-align:left}.c147{padding-top:20pt;padding-bottom:8pt;line-height:1.7;text-align:left}.c125{padding-top:12pt;padding-bottom:12pt;line-height:1.7;text-align:left}.c263{padding-top:0pt;padding-bottom:12pt;line-height:1.0;text-align:left}.c96{padding-top:20pt;padding-bottom:6pt;line-height:1.15;text-align:left}.c190{padding-top:20pt;padding-bottom:9pt;line-height:1.1500000000000001;text-align:left}.c175{padding-top:20pt;padding-bottom:28pt;line-height:1.1500000000000001;text-align:left}.c126{padding-top:0pt;padding-bottom:19pt;line-height:1.1500000000000001;text-align:left}.c256{padding-top:0pt;padding-bottom:0pt;line-height:1.3875;text-align:left}.c170{padding-top:0pt;padding-bottom:3pt;line-height:1.15;text-align:left}.c60{padding-top:14pt;padding-bottom:14pt;line-height:1.0;text-align:left}.c222{padding-top:0pt;padding-bottom:8pt;line-height:1 .c209{margin-right:23pt}.c61{page-break-after:avoid}.c120{font-weight:400}.c145{background-color:#434343}.c189{color:#4d5156}.c217{color:#00ff00}.c208{color:#474747}.c106{color:#0000aa}.c124{background-color:#0000ee}.c40{color:#0000ee}.c150{margin-right:30pt}.c52{color:#2c2d30}.c55{margin-right:13pt}.c218{background-color:#f5f5f5}.c94{color:#3fa9f5}.c272{color:#1c1e1c}.c7{height:16pt}.c288{font-family:"Nunito"}.c219{font-family:"Merriweather"}.c117{margin-right:8pt}.c81{margin-left:72pt}.c24{margin-left:36pt}.c265{color:#cc0000}.c274{font-family:"Montserrat"}.title{padding-top:0pt;color:#0000ee;font-size:26pt;padding-bottom:3pt;font-family:"Arial";line-height:1.1500000000000001;page-break-after:avoid;orphans:2;widows:2;text-align:left}.subtitle{padding-top:0pt;color:#666666;font-size:15pt;padding-bottom:16pt;font-family:"Arial";line-height:1.1500000000000001;page-break-after:avoid;orphans:2;widows:2;text-align:left}li{color:#0000ee;font-size:16pt;font-family:"Arial"}p{margin:0;color:#0000ee;font-size:16pt;font-family:"Arial"}h1{padding-top:20pt;color:#7f6000;font-weight:700;font-size:16pt;padding-bottom:6pt;font-family:"Arial";line-height:1.1500000000000001;page-break-after:avoid;orphans:2;widows:2;text-align:left}h2{background-color:#ffffff;padding-top:0pt;color:#333333;font-size:16pt;padding-bottom:0pt;font-family:"Arial";line-height:1.1500000000000001;page-break-after:avoid;orphans:2;widows:2;text-align:left}h3{padding-top:16pt;color:#434343;font-size:14pt;padding-bottom:4pt;font-family:"Arial";line-height:1.1500000000000001;page-break-after:avoid;orphans:2;widows:2;text-align:left}h4{padding-top:14pt;color:#666666;font-size:12pt;padding-bottom:4pt;font-family:"Arial";line-height:1.1500000000000001;page-break-after:avoid;orphans:2;widows:2;text-align:left}h5{padding-top:12pt;color:#666666;font-size:11pt;padding-bottom:4pt;font-family:"Arial";line-height:1.1500000000000001;page-break-after:avoid;orphans:2;widows:2;text-align:left}h6{padding-top:12pt;color:#666666;font-size:11pt;padding-bottom:4pt;font-family:"Arial";line-height:1.1500000000000001;page-break-after:avoid;font-style:italic;orphans:2;widows:2;text-align:left}</style></head><body class="c36 c242 doc-content"><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; </span><span class="c21">&nbsp; HIGH</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17">Apathy,</span><span>&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">empty inside, learned helplessness, hopelessness,, broken , emotionally empty , gutted, neglecting self or numb, quarshed, in victim hood, worthless, withdrawn </span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.8phznkstn0z4"><span class="c12">Could you suffer from &lsquo;Apathy&rsquo;?</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c70 c39 c17">Do any of the following apply to you&hellip;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c73 c17 c25 c40"></span></p><ul class="c41 lst-kix_4vjml2fxs4aa-0 start"><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Have you generally given up on life?</span></li><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Have you lost your motivation or passion? </span></li><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Do you doubt your worth? </span></li><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Does your life lack meaning or purpose?</span></li><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Do you believe you will never meet life&#39;s challenges? </span></li><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Do you feel helpless? </span></li><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Do you feel numb?</span></li></ul><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">If any of the above apply to you might be described as having &lsquo;apathy&rsquo;. &nbsp;Understand that we may all feel this way from time to time - but if we stay in this state of apathy, it leads to a lower quality of life. It can even shorten our life.</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">The subsequent physical effect of apathy is &lsquo;atrophy&rsquo;. It&#39;s a physical &lsquo;wasting away&#39;. So, with apathy we are at risk of &lsquo;wasting our life&rsquo; or even physically &lsquo;wasting&rsquo; or atrophy and subsequent disease.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c33 c10 c17">Apathy, unhappy, withdrawn, empty, learned helplessness, negative mindset</span></p><h1 class="c104 c61" id="h.5o2fx7setwvk"><span class="c12">Are you in a state of &lsquo;Apathy&rsquo;?</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">Consider this description of &lsquo;apathy&rsquo; by Vera Peiffer, a psychotherapist &amp; self-help author.</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36"><span class="c17 c32">&ldquo;Apathy is unhappy listlessness, where nothing appeals anymore, where life has lost its taste, shape and colour and where nothing has meaning for you.&rdquo; </span><span class="c17 c32 c43">&nbsp;</span><span class="c17 c32">Vera Peiffer</span><span class="c17 c32 c43">, More Positive Thinking; how to create a better future for yourself</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Is this state of apathy how you want to experience life? </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c39 c17">Consider this approach:</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;Carefully ponder w</span><span class="c17 c40">hat it is that you want </span><span>from life</span><span class="c8">? What do you really want for yourself? Your motivation to reach that goal can help generate enthusiasm. But first you need to consider &amp; visualize what you really want.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c39 c17">Your Challenge: </span><span class="c17 c40">Visualize what you want and then build</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;the enthusiasm to help you break free from a state of apathy.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c33 c10 c17">Apathy, victimhood, trauma victim, victim traits, timid, learned helplessness, beaten, broken, quitting, qualms, negative mindset, terror victim, freeze, beset with issues </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17">&nbsp; </span></p><h1 class="c1 c61" id="h.dd3go2j950oc"><span class="c12">Are you buying into the &ldquo;I can&rsquo;t&rdquo; story?</span></h1><p class="c34 c45 c36"><span class="c17 c40">Psychiatrist </span><span class="c17 c40">David R. Hawkins PhD in his book</span><span class="c39 c17">&nbsp;Letting Go,</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;says that apathy is the feeling that we CAN&rsquo;T do anything about our situation.</span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36"><span class="c8">Hawkins says that in reality we are very capable, so most &ldquo;I cant&rsquo;s&rdquo; are really &ldquo;I wont&rdquo; and behind that is usually a fear.</span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36"><span class="c39 c17">Your Challenge:</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;Consider what fear has led to you giving up and saying &ldquo;I can&rsquo;t&rdquo;? Once you understand that, it can be more easily overcome.</span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8 c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c19"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c19"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c19"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c19"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c19"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c19"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c19"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c74">Apathy, not enthusiastic, &nbsp;unhappy, unease, lacking effort, learned &nbsp;helplessness, negative mindset, languishing, empty inside , emotionally empty, lacking effort, blocked, quitting, ,victim, wavering withdrawn &nbsp; </span><span class="c73 c17 c25 c74">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c73 c17 c25 c74"></span></p><h1 class="c1 c61" id="h.4t8we3bosa3c"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Add more Enthusiasm to your life.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">Arnold Tornbee, a British professor of history-philosophy offers this approach to managing &lsquo;apathy&rsquo;:</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c33 c17 c32">&ldquo;Apathy can only be overcome by enthusiasm, and enthusiasm can only be aroused by two things: first, an ideal that takes the imagination by storm; second, a definite, intelligible plan for carrying that ideal into practice.&rdquo;<br></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c17 c43">Your Challenge:</span><span class="c20 c17">&nbsp;Try this approach to overcoming apathy:</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><ul class="c41 lst-kix_35ms8g0gwiw-0 start"><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c17 c40">Consider w</span><span class="c8">hat vision of the future inspires you?</span></li><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Think through the steps needed to make that vision a reality.</span></li><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">What is one small step forward you can take today?</span></li><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Take that first step </span></li></ul><p class="c1 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><h1 class="c34 c45 c36 c61" id="h.vya65ja17p6v"><span class="c12">Learn how to overcome feelings of &lsquo;Apathy&rsquo;.</span></h1><p class="c34 c45 c36"><span class="c8">&nbsp;Consider these simple life-style strategies for Apathy:</span></p><ul class="c41 lst-kix_shs5tpt5wsjk-0 start"><li class="c34 c45 c36 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Try some gentle exercise</span></li><li class="c34 c45 c36 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Spend time in nature</span></li><li class="c34 c45 c36 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Do things you used to enjoy &nbsp;</span></li><li class="c34 c45 c36 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Spend time with friends </span></li><li class="c34 c45 c36 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Get more sleep</span></li></ul><p class="c34 c45 c36"><span class="c17 c40">These kinds of activities can help jump start us. Also remember to break big tasks into small steps and reward yourself after each milestone.</span></p><p class="c97 c29 c134 c45 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c97 c29 c134 c45 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c97 c29 c134 c45 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c17 c27">Apathy, atrophy, broken, gloom, withdrawn, emotionally empty, emotional exhausted , helpless, learned helplessness , neglecting self / numb, quashed, wiped out/ worthless, negative mindset, burning out, compassion fatigue </span></p><h1 class="c97 c98 c45 c79 c36 c61" id="h.b2et5d2p4nd9"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Understand that </span><span>H</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">ealth affects emotions </span><span>and</span><span class="c12">&nbsp;behavior.</span></h1><p class="c34 c45 c36"><span class="c17 c40">W</span><span class="c8">hen we are sick, tired or otherwise unhealthy, we are more susceptible to negative emotions and self sabotaging strategies. </span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36"><span class="c8">So, start by monitoring and improving your physical health and lifestyle. This simple strategy can improve your wellbeing.</span></p><p class="c97 c134 c45 c79 c36 c7 c256"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c17 c27">Apathetic, resilience, blocked, beaten, quitting, beset with issues, quitting, grumbling, gloomy, weak, wavering &nbsp; </span></p><h1 class="c34 c45 c36 c61" id="h.agwuzmustkxm"><span class="c12">See your situation as an opportunity for &lsquo;strength building&rsquo;.</span></h1><p class="c34 c45 c36"><span class="c17 c40">Consider this perspective from Arnold Schwarzenegger:</span><span class="c40"><br></span><span class="c17 c32">&ldquo;</span><span class="c17 c32">Strength does not come from winning. Your struggles develop your strengths. When you go through hardships and decide not to surrender, that is strength.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c97 c29 c134 c45 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c129 c77 c25"></span></p><p class="c97 c29 c134 c45 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c129 c77 c25"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; </span><span class="c17 c25 c74">&nbsp;</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.fn56o9okddpp"><span class="c12">Consider what Happiness really means.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">When you&#39;re feeling down, c</span><span class="c17 c40">onsider this perspective on happiness &nbsp;from Rita Mae Brown in </span><span class="c39 c17">Hiss of Death</span><span class="c8">:</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c17 c32">&ldquo;Happiness is pretty simple: someone to love, something to do, something to look forward to.&rdquo;</span><span class="c36 c17 c32">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c97 c121 c134 c45 c79"><span class="c70 c39 c17">Your Challenge:</span></p><ul class="c41 lst-kix_ya8gg8ox563l-0 start"><li class="c97 c121 c134 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Consider what happiness really means to you. </span></li><li class="c97 c121 c134 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">How can you better meet those inner needs?</span></li></ul><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; of yourself?</span></h1><p class="c29 c45 c36"><span class="c8">Contemplate this perspective on &lsquo;Apathy&rsquo; from Psychiatrist David R Hawkins PhD:</span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36"><span class="c36 c17 c32">&ldquo;Apathy and depression are the prices we pay for having settled for and bought into our smallness. It&rsquo;s what we get for having played the victim and allowed ourselves to be programmed. It&rsquo;s the price we pay for having bought into negativity..&rdquo; </span><span class="c36 c17 c32">David R. Hawkins</span><span class="c36 c17 c32">, </span><span class="c36 c17 c32 c43"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.goodreads.com/work/quotes/21908238&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309605526&amp;usg=AOvVaw2o1t2LIuuhc8xe8d4vf6pR">Letting Go: The Pathway of Surrender</a></span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c33 c17 c74">Apathy, unhappy, unease, lacking effort, learned &nbsp;helplessness, negative mindset, noxious thought,empty in side , emotionally empty, lacking effort, blocked, quitting, tentative timid ,victim, weak, wavering withdrawn &nbsp; </span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c74"></span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36"><span class="c12 c36">Consider this Way out of your predicament. </span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36"><span class="c36 c17 c40">What if there was a universal approach to overcoming most issues? Consider t</span><span class="c8 c36">his approach from psychiatrist David R. Hawkins PhD:</span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36"><span class="c18 c17">&ldquo;The way out is to become more conscious. What does it mean, &lsquo;to become more conscious&rsquo;? To begin with, becoming more conscious means to start looking for the truth for ourselves, instead of blindly allowing ourselves to be programmed, whether from without or by an inner voice within the mind, which seeks to diminish and invalidate, focusing on all that is weak and helpless. </span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36"><span class="c36 c17 c40">So what do we do next to overcome this? Hawkins goes on to give us an explanation of what to do: </span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36"><span class="c36 c17 c32">&ldquo;To get out of it, we have to accept the responsibility that we have bought into the negativity and have been willing to believe it. The way out of this, then, is to start questioning everything.&rdquo; David R. Hawkins, </span><span class="c36 c17 c32 c43"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.goodreads.com/work/quotes/21908238&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309607893&amp;usg=AOvVaw0WPSLMYgkO4b5VpIfzl1hT">Letting Go: The Pathway of Surrender</a></span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c17 c74">Apathy, unhappy, unease, lacking effort, learned &nbsp;helplessness, negative mindset, noxious thought, empty inside, emotionally empty, lacking effort, blocked, quitting, tentative timid ,victim, weak, wavering withdrawn</span></p><h1 class="c34 c45 c61" id="h.9ixq07qjdsd2"><span class="c12">Take action &amp; accomplish a task, no matter how small.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c20 c17">When we are feeling &lsquo;apathetic&rsquo;, nothing seems worthwhile and the less we do, the less motivation and energy we have. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c17 c43">Try this approach: </span><span class="c20 c17">To find a sense of accomplishment, encourage yourself to do some small easily managed tasks. Then give yourself a pat on the back or a &lsquo;high five&rsquo; when the task has been completed. This task could be as simple as washing the dishes or putting away the laundry. Or perhaps even taking a shower and getting into your day clothes.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c20 c17">This sense of accomplishment will help you feel better. You will be more motivated to take a more proactive approach to life.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36"><span class="c58 c17 c43">Your Challenge:</span><span class="c20 c17">&nbsp;What simple task or tasks will you do today?</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c97 c29 c193"><span class="c10 c17">Apathy, withdrawn, emotional exhaustion, exhaustion disassociated, disconnected</span><span class="c17"><br></span><span class="c37 c17 c25">Are you perpetually switched &lsquo;Off&rsquo;?<br><br></span><span class="c58 c17">Psychotherapist Elisa Bragg explains that after a traumatic event we can occasionally become stuck in the &ldquo;On&rdquo; position, or we can become stuck in the &ldquo;Off&rdquo; position instead of returning to the normal range.<br><br>The &ldquo;Off&rdquo; position includes a feeling of flat affect, lethargy or deadness etc.<br><br>Could this be happening to you?</span><span class="c111 c17"><br></span><span class="c111 c17"><br></span><span class="c58 c17">Recommended Resource:</span><span class="c111 c17">&nbsp; Elisa Bragg</a></span></p><p class="c97 c29 c193"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c97 c29 c193 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c97 c29 c193 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c84"></span></p><p class="c97 c29 c193 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c84"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c50 title" id="h.5sh1iaxvtc6z"><span class="c33 c10 c47"></span></p><p class="c50 c29 title" id="h.gn2yzllga62a"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10 c17">Atrophy, languishing, brocken, beaten, disempowered, </span><span class="c8">&nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c53 c1 c61" id="h.3bw6po3lrdra"><span class="c12">Understand Atrophy.</span></h1><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">&lsquo;Atrophy&rsquo;, in its essence, is a silent thief. It gradually erodes the vitality of both body and soul. Physically, it manifests as muscle wastage, a result of inactivity or illness. Yet, the concept extends beyond the physical realm, infiltrating our psychological and spiritual dimensions.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Psychologically, atrophy may show up as a decline in mental sharpness or emotional numbness, stemming from a lack of stimulation or unresolved traumas. Spiritually, it appears as a loss of purpose or connection, often due to neglect of one&rsquo;s inner life and values.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Understand that combatting atrophy requires mindful engagement with our mental and spiritual selves. </span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Your Challenge:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Regularly extend your mind, nurture emotional well-being, and cultivate spiritual practices. By doing so, we can preserve our inner vibrancy and prevent the subtle decay that atrophy brings.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">So, stay connected, stay active, and keep nurturing your inner world.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c62 c7 c24"><span class="c14"></span></p><p class="c1 c62 c7 c24"><span class="c14"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10 c17">Atrophy, languishing, beaten, brocken, disempowered, &nbsp; </span></p><h1 class="c53 c1 c61" id="h.8bvebj4xq4wu"><span class="c12">Overcome Atrophy: Keep Moving Forward.</span></h1><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c17 c40">&lsquo;</span><span class="c8">Atrophy&rsquo; is more than just a technical or medical term; it represents the gradual decline of strength and skills when we become inactive. Whether it&rsquo;s physical or mental, atrophy sneaks in quietly and slowly erodes our capabilities. It&rsquo;s easy to let it take hold, especially when life feels overwhelming or motivation is low. But we do have the power to fight back and reclaim our vitality.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Consider this simple poem on overcoming atrophy :</span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c70 c39 c17">Atrophy is a thief, it takes your strength away,</span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c70 c39 c17">Rise up, stay active, don&rsquo;t let it have its sway.</span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c70 c39 c17">Challenge yourself daily, let your muscles thrive,</span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c70 c39 c17">Break free, keep growing, keep your dreams alive.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Consider this approach:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;To combat atrophy, make a commitment to yourself today. Incorporate small, consistent actions into your daily routine that promote movement and growth. </span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Your challenge: </span><span class="c8">Start taking action today. Whether it&#39;s a short walk, a new hobby, or mental exercises, every step you take helps to counteract the effects of atrophy. </span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">So start now, and keep moving forward.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c62 c7 c24"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10 c17">Atrophy, languishing, beaten, brocken, </span></p><h1 class="c53 c1 c61" id="h.d81g6wp7e6rm"><span class="c12">Consider this Metaphor for Atrophy: A Garden of the Mind. </span></h1><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Imagine your mind and spirit as a lush, vibrant garden. Each thought, emotion, and spiritual practice is a plant, blossoming with care and attention. This garden however requires regular watering, sunlight, and nurturing to flourish. If neglected, the once vibrant flowers wilt. Weeds of stagnation can also creep in, choking the life out of what once thrived.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Atrophy is like the garden&#39;s quiet decay. Without tending, the soil of our minds becomes barren, and the once strong roots of our spirit weaken. The absence of intellectual and emotional engagement allows weeds of complacency and disconnection to overrun our inner landscape.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Just as a gardener must diligently tend to their plants, we must care for our mental and spiritual well-being. </span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Your challenge</span><span class="c8">: Engage in activities that challenge your mind, connect with your emotions, and nourish your spirit. By doing so, you can prevent atrophy, ensuring your inner garden remains a place of growth, beauty, and resilience.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Remember, a thriving garden is a testament to consistent care and attention. Keep tending to yours, and let it bloom in all its splendor.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c62 c7 c24"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c62 c7 c24"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10 c17">Atrophy, languishing, brocken, beaten, &nbsp;</span><span class="c17">&nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c53 c1 c61" id="h.veiydpcf5a9c"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Consider this Case</span><span>&nbsp;of </span><span class="c12">Atrophy: Loss of Creative Spirit.</span></h1><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">A Case Study:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;John was once a vibrant artist, known for his imaginative paintings that brought joy to many. His creativity flowed effortlessly, a wellspring of inspiration. But over time, John found himself caught up in the demands of a corporate job, leaving little room for his artistic pursuits. Slowly, his brushes collected dust, and the canvases lay untouched.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">The Consequences: </span><span class="c8">As the years passed, John noticed a decline in his creative spark. The colors that once danced in his mind became dull, and the ideas that once bubbled with excitement faded away. He struggled to find joy in his art, feeling disconnected from the passion that once drove him. This was a classic case of creative atrophy, where neglect led to a gradual decline in his artistic abilities.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">The Turning Point &amp; Strategy:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Determined to reclaim his creative spirit, John began to set aside time each day to paint, even if only for a few minutes. He visited art galleries and reconnected with fellow artists, reigniting his passion. Slowly but surely, his creativity began to flourish once more. The vibrant colors and imaginative scenes returned, revitalizing his soul.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">In Overview:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;John&rsquo;s journey illustrates how neglect can lead to atrophy, not just in muscles or minds, but in the very essence of our passions and talents. It serves as a powerful reminder to nurture our inner selves, keeping our creative spirits alive and thriving.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c62 c7 c24"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10 c17">Atrophy, languishing, beaten, broken, disconnected, disempowered, </span><span class="c17">&nbsp; </span></p><h1 class="c53 c1 c61" id="h.5ta6pmdihszv"><span class="c12">Recognize the Negative Ripple Effect of Atrophy.</span></h1><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">When we fall into a state of &lsquo;atrophy&rsquo;, whether physically, mentally, or spiritually, it creates a ripple effect that impacts not just ourselves but those around us. </span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c17 c25 c40">Recognize the Physical ripple effect:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Physically, atrophy can lead to decreased mobility and energy, limiting our ability to engage in activities and connect with others. This physical decline can create a sense of isolation and dependency, burdening loved ones who may need to provide additional support and care.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c17 c25 c40">Recognize the Mental ripple effect:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Mentally and emotionally, atrophy can result in a loss of sharpness and vitality, leading to feelings of stagnation and disconnection. When our minds are not stimulated and our emotions are neglected, we may struggle with mood swings, depression, and a lack of enthusiasm for life. This can strain relationships, as our lack of engagement and diminished emotional capacity can create distance and misunderstanding between us and those we care about.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c17 c25 c40">Recognize the Spiritual ripple effect: </span><span class="c8">Spiritually, atrophy manifests as a loss of purpose and connection to something greater than ourselves. Without nurturing our spiritual lives, we can become disconnected from our values and sense of meaning, leading to a sense of emptiness and despair. This spiritual void can be felt by others, creating a barrier to deep, meaningful connections and diminishing our ability to contribute positively to the world.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">In overview, overcoming atrophy is not just a personal endeavor but also a gift to those around us. By nurturing our physical, mental, and spiritual health, we enhance our capacity to engage with and support others, creating a positive ripple effect that extends beyond ourselves.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Your challenge:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Make a conscious effort to invest in your well-being every day. Engage in activities that stimulate your mind, nourish your spirit, and keep your body active. Remember, your vitality will not only enrich your own life, but will also positively impact those around you.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c62 c7 c24"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c62 c7 c24"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c62 c7 c24"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10 c17">Atrophy, languishing, disconnected, disempowered, &nbsp;</span><span class="c17">&nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c53 c1 c61" id="h.8o2bfpo5nnhs"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Understand how Atrophy Affects </span><span>Us and Our Persona</span><span class="c12">.</span></h1><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">When we find ourselves in a state of &lsquo;atrophy&rsquo;, whether physically, mentally, or spiritually, it subtly alters how we present ourselves to the world and how others perceive us. In the grip of atrophy, we may appear withdrawn, lethargic, or disengaged, creating an invisible barrier that distances us from meaningful connections and interactions.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c17 c25 c40">Physical effects:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Atrophy can make us seem frail or lacking in vitality. Our posture may slump, movements might become sluggish, and an overall aura of exhaustion or lack of energy can be noticeable. This physical decline not only affects our ability to participate in activities but also can lead others to perceive us as weak or incapable, fostering a sense of pity or concern rather than admiration or respect.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c17 c25 c40">Mental &amp; emotional effects:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Atrophy can manifest as a lack of enthusiasm and responsiveness. We might come across as indifferent or emotionally unavailable, making it difficult for others to engage with us on a deeper level. This can create an impression of being disinterested or detached, potentially leading to strained relationships and a sense of isolation.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c17 c25 c40">Spiritual effects: </span><span class="c17 c40">A</span><span class="c8">trophy can make us seem disconnected from a sense of purpose or inner peace. We might appear lost or lacking in direction, which can be disheartening for those who look to us for inspiration or support. This spiritual disengagement can lead others to view us as merely going through the motions, lacking the depth and vitality that comes from a well-nourished inner life.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">In essence, being in a state of atrophy impacts not only our internal well-being but also the way we are seen and connected to by others. By recognizing the signs of atrophy and taking steps to address them, we can improve our presence in the world, fostering more positive and meaningful relationships.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Consider this approach: </span><span class="c8">Take time each day to nurture your physical, mental, and spiritual health. A balanced and vibrant inner life will not only enhance your own well-being but will also help you present a more engaged and inspiring presence to those around you.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><h1 class="c53 c1 c61 c7" id="h.vq5foi3ikbgh"><span class="c12"></span></h1><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10 c17">Atrophy, languishing, beaten, broken, disconnected, disempowered, &nbsp; </span><span class="c17">&nbsp; </span></p><h1 class="c53 c1 c61" id="h.wesv565srsmn"><span class="c12">Revitalize Your Mind Through Daily Challenges.</span></h1><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Mental &lsquo;atrophy&rsquo; can sneak up on us when we become complacent or stop challenging our minds. </span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Consider this approach: </span><span class="c8">To combat mental atrophy , integrate small, daily mental exercises into your routine. For example, puzzles, reading diverse genres, or learning a new skill can keep your cognitive abilities sharp and vibrant.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Engage in activities that stretch your thinking and expand your horizons. Just as physical exercise strengthens muscles, mental exercises keep your mind agile and resilient.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Your challenge: </span><span class="c8">Dedicate 15 minutes each day to a new mental challenge. This is a small step with big rewards for your mental vitality.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c62 c7 c24"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c33 c10 c17">Atrophy, languishing, beaten, broken, disconnected, disempowered, &nbsp; </span></p><h1 class="c53 c1 c61" id="h.1wd6yolh288u"><span class="c12">Nourish Your Spirit with a Daily Reflection.</span></h1><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Spiritual atrophy occurs when we neglect our inner life and lose connection with our values and purpose. </span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Consider this approach: </span><span class="c8">To overcome spiritual atrophy, start and cultivate a practice of daily reflection, journaling or meditation. Spend time each day connecting with your deeper self, reflecting on your values, and setting intentions.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Consider journaling your thoughts and feelings or engaging in mindfulness practices. These actions nourish your spirit, helping you stay connected and grounded.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Your challenge: </span><span class="c8">Start with 5 minutes of quiet reflection or journaling or meditation each morning. Reconnect with your inner self and set a positive tone for the day.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c62 c7 c24"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c17">Atrophy, languishing, not connection &nbsp;</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c53 c1 c61" id="h.9d6lkd1kuyir"><span class="c12">Combat Emotional Atrophy Through Connection.</span></h1><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Emotional &lsquo;atrophy&rsquo; can result from isolation or neglecting relationships. </span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Consider this approach:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;To counteract emotional atrophy, make an effort to connect with others regularly. Engage in meaningful conversations, share your feelings, and support others in their emotional journeys.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Remember, building and maintaining strong relationships helps keep your emotional life rich and fulfilling. Don&rsquo;t let emotional connections wither; nurture them with intention and care.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Your challenge:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Reach out to a friend or loved one today for a meaningful conversation, even if it&rsquo;s just a quick call or text message.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c62 c7 c24"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c17">Atrophy, not creative, </span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c53 c1 c61" id="h.3z9fh3mg7e60"><span class="c12">Reignite Your Creative Spark: Overcome Atrophy.</span></h1><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Creative &lsquo;atrophy&rsquo; sets in when we stop engaging in activities that spark our imagination and innovation. </span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Consider this approach: </span><span class="c8">To overcome creative atrophy, reignite your creative pursuits by dedicating time to explore your passions. Whether it&rsquo;s painting, writing, or playing an instrument, make creativity a regular part of your life.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c17 c40">Consider setting</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;aside time each week to dive into a creative project, free from distractions and obligations. This nurtures your creative spirit and keeps your imagination flourishing.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Your Challenge:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Schedule a weekly &ldquo;creative hour&rdquo; to immerse yourself in some artistic activity that brings you joy.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c62 c7 c24"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c17">Atrophy, not vitality, exercise, &nbsp;</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c53 c1 c61" id="h.ymmpnsd7a7u"><span class="c12">Restore Physical Vitality with Regular Movement.</span></h1><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Physical atrophy happens when our bodies don&rsquo;t get the movement and exercise they need. </span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Consider this approach:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;To prevent physical atrophy, incorporate regular physical activity that&#39;s appropriate for you into your routine. Whether it&rsquo;s a daily walk, yoga, or strength training, keeping your body active is key to maintaining physical health and vitality. Always choose an activity and level that&rsquo;s suitable for your health and fitness. Start very gently and work up. &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Remember, consistency is crucial; even small amounts of daily stretching or movement can make a significant difference in your physical well-being.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Your challenge:</span><span class="c17 c25 c40">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">Commit to some appropriate physical activity each day to keep your body strong and resilient.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17">Atrophy , not vitality, movement, exercise &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c53 c1 c61" id="h.usvfciaftdee"><span class="c12">Restore Physical Vitality with Regular Movement.</span></h1><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c33 c17 c32">&ldquo;Movement is a medicine for creating change in a person&rsquo;s physical, emotional, and mental states.&rdquo; &nbsp;Carol Welch</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Physical atrophy can occur when we lead a sedentary lifestyle, neglecting the need for regular movement and exercise. Our bodies are designed to move, and physical activity is essential for maintaining not only physical health but also emotional and mental well-being. </span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Regular exercise can help prevent the decline of muscle strength, flexibility, and endurance, keeping our bodies resilient and agile.</span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Engaging in daily movement, whether through walking, yoga, strength training, or even dancing, stimulates blood flow, improves mood, and enhances overall vitality. Understand that it&rsquo;s not just about staying fit; it&#39;s about nurturing a harmonious balance between body and mind. This contributes to a healthier, more fulfilling life.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Consider this approach: </span><span class="c8">To combat physical atrophy and promote overall well-being, commit to some physical activity that&#39;s appropriate for you each day. It can be as gentle as some stretches or going for a walk. Or consider a group stretch, exercise or Yoga class. Always take your health and fitness into account. </span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Your Challenge:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Make your commitment to overcome physical atrophy. Watch your body and spirit flourish with consistent self-care and movement. Choose activities that are safe, appropriate and enjoyable.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17">Movement, </span><span class="c17">Atrophy, lack of exercise, lack of vitality, &nbsp; </span></p><h1 class="c53 c1 c61" id="h.le1u9rs7p9yr"><span class="c12">Mindful Movement: Reclaim Your Physical Vitality.</span></h1><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Physical atrophy can quietly creep in when we neglect the need for regular movement. Our bodies are designed to stay active, and even small, mindful movements can make a significant difference. </span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Consider this approach:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Choose an appropriate level of physical activity or exercise for you. For example, incorporate stretching, a short daily walk or yoga stretches into your routine to keep your body agile and energized. These activities not only boost physical health but also enhance mental clarity and emotional well-being.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Starting your day with 10-15 minutes of mindful movement can set a positive tone and improve overall vitality. By making movement a regular part of your life, you combat the effects of atrophy and build a foundation for lasting health. Remember to always choose activities suitable for your health and fitness. Start gently and slowly build up. &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Your challenge:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;As appropriate, consider starting each day with a 10-minute stretch, walk or yoga session. This can help to maintain your physical vitality and you can start your day energized.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17">Atrophy, not curious, not love of learning, </span></p><h1 class="c53 c1 c61" id="h.dvrb0qeqz6sx"><span class="c12">Engage the Power of Curiosity: Keep Your Mind Active.</span></h1><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Mental &lsquo;atrophy&rsquo; often sneaks in when we stop challenging our minds. Maintaining a curious mindset is key to keeping our cognitive abilities sharp and vibrant. </span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Consider this approach:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Engage in activities that pique your interest, such as reading diverse genres, learning a new language, or picking up a new hobby. These actions stimulate the mind and prevent the decline of mental sharpness.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">By dedicating time each day to explore new knowledge, you foster mental resilience and enthusiasm. Your brain, much like a muscle, thrives on being exercised regularly.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Your Challenge: </span><span class="c8">Spend 15 minutes daily on a mental exercise, like solving puzzles or reading about a new topic. Keep your mind active and engaged.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17">Atrophy, not spiritual growth </span></p><h1 class="c53 c1 c61" id="h.gkvc7ba393x6"><span class="c12">Practice daily Reflection: Nurture your Inner World.</span></h1><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Spiritual &lsquo;atrophy&rsquo; can occur when we neglect our inner lives and lose touch with our values. Daily reflection or journaling is a powerful way to reconnect with your deeper self and foster spiritual growth. </span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Consider this approach: </span><span class="c8">Take a few minutes each day to meditate, reflect on your day, or write down your thoughts and feelings. This practice helps you stay grounded and aligned with your personal values.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Understand that by nurturing your inner world, you maintain a sense of purpose and direction. This combats the effects of spiritual neglect.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Your Challenge:</span><span class="c17 c25 c40">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">Start a self-reflection or gratitude journal. Write down three things you are thankful for each day. Remember this simple strategy can help foster a positive and reflective mindset.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17">Atrophy, lack of connection, social skills, wellbeing &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c53 c1 c61" id="h.z29lt8h6fxqj"><span class="c12">Maintain Social Connections for Emotional Health.</span></h1><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Emotional atrophy can set in when we isolate ourselves or neglect our relationships. Maintaining social connections is crucial for emotional well-being. </span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Consider this approach:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Make an effort to reach out to friends and family, engage in meaningful conversations, and participate in social activities. These connections enrich our lives and provide essential emotional support.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Regular interaction with others helps keep our emotional lives vibrant and prevents the disconnection that comes from isolation.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Your Challenge:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Make it a goal to call or message a friend or loved one, at least daily. This helps maintain and strengthen your emotional connections.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17">Atrophy, not creativity, not engaged &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c53 c1 c61" id="h.i62gia8y4d4d"><span class="c12">Unleash Your Inner Artist: Overcome Apathy &amp; Atrophy </span></h1><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Creative &lsquo;atrophy&rsquo; occurs when we stop engaging in activities that inspire our imagination. Reignite your creative spark by dedicating time to pursue artistic endeavors like painting, writing, or playing an instrument. </span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Regularly engaging in creative activities not only brings joy but also fosters a sense of fulfillment and purpose.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Consider this approach:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Set aside a specific time each week for creative pursuits. Allowing your imagination to flourish helps prevent the dullness of routine.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Your challenge:</span><span class="c17 c25 c40">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">Schedule a weekly &ldquo;creative hour&rdquo; where you can immerse yourself in a hobby or creative project that excites you.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17">Atrophy, languishing, lacking motivation, lacking purpose &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c53 c1 c61" id="h.1x7l487xdtux"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Set Small Goals: </span><span>Help B</span><span class="c12">uild Momentum.</span></h1><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c17 c40">&lsquo;</span><span class="c8">Atrophy&rsquo; in any aspect of life can occur when we lack direction and purpose. Setting small, achievable goals helps create momentum and prevents stagnation. </span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Consider this approach:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;A good way to start is to break down large goals into small manageable tasks and then celebrate each accomplishment. This approach fosters a sense of progress and motivation, encouraging continuous growth and development.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Remember even small steps can lead to significant changes over time. This makes goal-setting a powerful tool against atrophy.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Your challenge: </span><span class="c8">Start setting a small daily goal that aligns with your larger objectives. Then acknowledge your progress to help you stay motivated.</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17">Atrophy, not spiritual growth, not mindful, not self awareness </span></p><h1 class="c53 c1 c61" id="h.a8rqvy2sxzw3"><span class="c12">Center Your Being with Mindfulness.</span></h1><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Mental and spiritual &lsquo;atrophy&rsquo; can result from a lack of mindfulness and self-awareness. Incorporating mindfulness and meditation into your daily routine helps center your being and fosters inner peace. </span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Consider this approach:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Spend a few minutes each day in quiet reflection, focusing on your breath and the present moment. This practice reduces stress and enhances your connection with your inner self.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Remember that mindfulness and meditation are simple yet powerful tools for maintaining mental and spiritual vitality.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Your Challenge:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Begin with a 5-minute mindfulness practice or meditation exercise each day. Do this consistently. Gradually increase the time spent as you become more comfortable with the practice.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17">Atrophy, nature, lack of balance, not engaged &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c53 c1 c61" id="h.g2481b9m900s"><span class="c12">Reconnect with Nature: Revitalize Your Spirit.</span></h1><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Spiritual &lsquo;atrophy&rsquo; often stems from a disconnection with the natural world. Spending time in nature can rejuvenate your spirit and restore a sense of balance. </span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Consider this approach:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Plan regular outings to parks, forests, or even your own backyard to soak in the beauty of nature. These moments of connection with the natural environment can bring peace, clarity, and a renewed sense of purpose.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Your challenge:</span><span class="c17 c25 c40">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">Take a weekly walk in nature to reconnect with the natural world and revitalize your spirit.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Remember, nature has a unique way of grounding us and reminding us of our place in the world.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17">Atrophy, languishing, not love of learning, not enthusiastic, not thriving &nbsp; </span></p><h1 class="c53 c1 c61" id="h.tw0rdvg051pz"><span class="c12">Learn Something New: Keep Life Exciting.</span></h1><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Mental &lsquo;atrophy&rsquo; can set in when we stop challenging ourselves and exploring new interests. </span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Consider this approach:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Learning something new, whether it&rsquo;s a language, a musical instrument, or a new hobby, can keep life exciting and our minds sharp. </span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Embrace the joy of discovery and the satisfaction that comes with mastering a new skill. By continuously seeking out new learning experiences, you keep your mind agile and prevent stagnation.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Your Challenge: </span><span class="c8">Commit to learning a new skill or hobby each month, to keep your mind engaged and life exciting.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17">Atrophy, not wellbeing, not self care, neglecting self &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c53 c1 c61" id="h.5u9rympdzqj"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Prioritize </span><span>y</span><span class="c12">our Well-Being with Self Care.</span></h1><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Neglecting self-care can lead to physical, mental, and emotional atrophy. Regular self-care practices are essential for maintaining overall well-being. </span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Consider this approach: </span><span class="c8">Whether it&rsquo;s taking time for a relaxing bath, reading a good book, or practicing mindfulness, prioritize activities that nurture your body, mind, and spirit.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Remember, self-care is not just a luxury but a necessity for staying healthy and resilient.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Your Challenge:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Create a self-care routine that includes daily or weekly activities you enjoy. Use this to help you relax and rejuvenate.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c5"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17">Atrophy, not purpose, service to others, not connection &nbsp; </span></p><h1 class="c53 c1 c61" id="h.ewl3oga8wcjv"><span class="c12">Give Back to Others to Revitalize Your Soul.</span></h1><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Spiritual &lsquo;atrophy&rsquo; can result from a lack of purpose and connection. </span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Consider this approach:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Engaging in volunteer work can provide a sense of fulfillment and community connection, revitalizing your soul. Whether it&rsquo;s helping at a local shelter, participating in community projects, or supporting a cause you care about, volunteering enriches your life and strengthens your connection to others.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c39 c17">Your Challenge: </span><span class="c8">Find a local cause or organization to volunteer with regularly. Start researching. Give back and stay connected with your community.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1"><span class="c8">Remember, by giving back, you also combat spiritual atrophy and nurture a sense of purpose.</span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c53 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c115 c124">{M:DEFINE}</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10 c17">Aversion, learned avoidance, triggered, cowardly closed down, timid, traumatized, fear, lacking self worth,</span><span class="c10">&nbsp;anxiety ( mild) </span></p><h1 class="c104 c61" id="h.o9mz7lvv1cra"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Understand &lsquo;Aversion&rsquo; in your personal responses.</span></h1><p class="c29"><span class="c8">Do you avoid situations, people or actions which trigger fear or a sense of inadequacy? This could indicate an &lsquo;aversion&rsquo;. <br></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c8">For example, do you avoid driving on a road where you have previously had an accident? Or perhaps you avoid going back to a club or place where you had previously embarrassed yourself or been humiliated.</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c8">This behavior is what we term having an &lsquo;aversion&rsquo; or an &lsquo;averse&rsquo; situational response. It&#39;s like feeling &#39;allergic&rsquo; to some personal setting. We then tend to strongly avoid that situation because of an unpleasant past experience. <br></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c8">What&rsquo;s the result? This can lead to living a smaller and more constricted life. So, maybe it is time to address this. </span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c33 c17 c27">Aversion, learned avoidance, triggered, fearful, angst, rejecting reality, </span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.s2w3wk62josi"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Understand how &lsquo;Aversion&rsquo; can make our lives small.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Consider how your world shrinks as you avoid people, places, and other triggers. We call this behavior response having an &lsquo;Aversion&rsquo; to a particular situation.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c39 c17">Your Challenge: </span><span class="c17 c40">Imagine</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;how your life could be different if you decided to overcome your tendency of aversion and avoidance?</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c90 c40"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c74">&nbsp;Aversion, avoidance, denial, rejecting reality, learned avoidance, yielding, kowtowing, blocked, procrastination, wavering, Avoidance,</span><span class="c17 c25 c74">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c5"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Understand that Avoidance </span><span class="c37 c25">and</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">&nbsp;Aversion is not beneficial!</span></p><h1 class="c45 c61 c160" id="h.lbuuta7p5pe2"><span class="c17 c120 c40">Avoidance of </span><span class="c120 c40">issues</span><span class="c17 c120 c40">&nbsp;and especially having an &lsquo;aversion&rsquo; to certain things can </span><span class="c120 c40">take</span><span class="c17 c40 c120">&nbsp;us further away from what we really </span><span class="c120 c40">need to face</span><span class="c8">. </span></h1><h1 class="c160 c45 c61" id="h.50mpym3e5pjr"><span class="c17 c120 c40">By not </span><span class="c120 c40">facing</span><span class="c17 c120 c40">&nbsp;things that are in our best interest to </span><span class="c120 c40">confront</span><span class="c8">, we might temporarily feel better. However, we miss out on long-term benefits, especially in personal growth. </span></h1><h1 class="c160 c45 c61" id="h.haapch"><span class="c120 c40">For example,</span><span class="c39 c17 c120">&nbsp;</span><span class="c120 c40">a</span><span class="c8">voidance includes NOT speaking up when our boundaries are violated. Or NOT socializing when we are lonely.</span></h1><p class="c160 c45"><span class="c39 c17">Your Challenge</span><span class="c39 c17">:</span><span class="c17 c25 c40">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">Pause, reflect on what you can do and then take some small but positive direct action. Remember, even a small step in the right direction will help you feel better. </span></p><p class="c160 c45"><span class="c17 c40">Stretch yourself a little. Just take a small step and assess how you feel.</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c33 c17 c27">Aversion, triggered, tense, traumatized, volatile, hijacked </span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Try reframing the Meaning you give to a situation.</span><span class="c17 c27">&nbsp; </span></p><h1 class="c34 c45 c61" id="h.nc9t3ucf62bp"><span class="c17 c120 c40">Can you reframe the meaning you give to a situation you </span><span class="c120 c40">falsely</span><span class="c17 c120 c40">&nbsp;</span><span class="c120 c40">regarded</span><span class="c17 c120 c40">&nbsp;as </span><span class="c120 c40">threatening. Consider</span><span class="c17 c120 c40">&nbsp;one you&#39;ve been avoiding, or have an aversion to? </span><span class="c120 c40">If you can reassess the situation it </span><span class="c8">will interrupt your automatic trigger response.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">Start by considering the following explanation by Elizabeth Thornton. It can help us understand how an aversion can arise: </span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c18 c17">&lsquo;We perceive through our senses a person, a situation or an event, and in an instant, we project our mental models - our fears, background and experiences - onto that perception. This often results in cognitive errors, which means we judge and respond incorrectly.&rsquo; </span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c39 c36 c17">Your Challenge:</span><span class="c8 c36">&nbsp;Consider the above explanation by Thrornton. Then assess which situations cause you to automatically respond in a negative way? &nbsp;Quietly contemplate what past experiences and fears you might be projecting into the present? Could this be responsible for your avoidance or aversion?</span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c33 c17 c27">Averse, triggered, tense, traumatized, volatile, hijacked, </span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c27"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Practice interrupting established brain circuits. </span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c36 c17 c40">Elizabeth Thornton explains</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;how our brain&rsquo;s negative responses can be overcome: </span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c18 c17">&ldquo;The key to transforming mental models is to interrupt the automatic responses that are driven by the old model and respond differently based on the new model.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c36 c17 c40">&nbsp;Thornton goes on to explain how this process works:</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c36 c17 c32">&nbsp;&ldquo;Each time you are able to do this, you are actually loosening the old circuit and creating new neural connections in your brain, often referred to as self-directed neuroplasticity.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c8 c36">In this way you change your brain&#39;s neural connections. This can help overcome old automatic responses. &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c39 c36 c17">Your Challenge: </span><span class="c8 c36">Remind yourself to look at each new situation with fresh eyes.
