Coincider the benefit to your brain&#39;s wiring!</span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c198"><span class="c10 c17">Aversion, triggered, learned avoidance,sensitized, tense, traumatized, tormented</span><span class="c33 c10 c195">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c198"><span class="c12">Expand the &lsquo;window of tolerance&rsquo; to your triggers</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">S</span><span class="c8">taying away from things that you find triggering and therefore want to avoid may seem to work short term. But in the long term, this can severely limit your life.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c39 c17">Consider this approach:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;One useful strategy to overcome this triggering is called &lsquo;exposure therapy&rsquo;. This starts with small steps &amp; experimenting in safe ways. We slowly come closer to what we fear and avoid. Sometimes if the situation is particularly traumatic we might need additional support or expert guidance to help us do this. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">For Example,</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;if you had been bitten by a dog and since then have been fearful of them - find a gentle dog in a safe situation. Then practice getting closer to it - perhaps eventually even patting it.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">If you have had a car accident and then avoid going back to the scene of the accident, take small steps. Perhaps start by sitting in your car and visualize confidently driving past the scene.</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; HIGH</span></p><p class="c198"><span class="c10 c17">Aversion, triggered, learned avoidance, emotional excess, hijacked,breathe, exercise, journaling, nature, mindfulness </span></p><h1 class="c34" id="h.j4afo4ux26t2"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Practice </span><span>H</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">ealthy </span><span>C</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">oping </span><span>S</span><span class="c12">trategies.</span></h1><p class="c34"><span class="c8">It&#39;s important to have a &lsquo;toolbox&rsquo; of good coping strategies.These can help when you are upset or triggered. </span></p><p class="c34"><span class="c73 c17 c25 c40">Here are some &lsquo;tried &amp; true&rsquo; healthy coping strategies:</span></p><ol class="c41 lst-kix_5k8z7sxsi7pq-0 start" start="1"><li class="c34 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Deep breathing - for a calming effect</span></li><li class="c34 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Exercising - to release pent-up energy &amp; emotions</span></li><li class="c34 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Journaling - to recognise your thoughts &amp; emotions &nbsp;</span></li><li class="c34 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Nature walks - to relax &amp; better appreciate things </span></li><li class="c34 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c17 c40">Mindfulness - to practice watching your inner state &nbsp;</span></li></ol><p class="c97 c112"><span class="c58 c17">For more discussion</span><span class="c58 c17">&nbsp;on triggers consider reading this article: </span><span class="c71 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.verywellmind.com/what-does-it-mean-to-be-triggered-4175432&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309679482&amp;usg=AOvVaw1D2drOHsNizLTX-fPqHXxO">What Does It Mean to Be Triggered</a></span></p><p class="c97 c112 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c27"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c198"><span class="c10 c17">Aversion, triggered, learned avoidance, emotional excess, hijacked, reactive, not open, not resilient, emotionally dysregulated, nervy </span></p><h1 class="c97 c112 c61" id="h.h56fea5bastf"><span class="c12">Understand how to calm your nervous system. </span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c17">Elisa Bragg in her article linked below illustrates in simple visual form how a healthy nervous system fluctuates over time. There are times of sympathetic &lsquo;activation&rsquo; and times of parasympathetic &lsquo;settling&rsquo;. She explains that we can recognize and influence these states though our awareness of it and through the lines of thoughts we pursue.</span></p><p class="c97 c112"><span class="c58 c17 c218">Recommended reading: </span><span class="c155 c27 c218">&nbsp;</span><span class="c71 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://bespoketraumatherapy.com/somatic-experiencing&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309681083&amp;usg=AOvVaw0e2nrfSx7yiK3zzNZeX-II">Somatic Experiencing &mdash; Elisa Bragg</a></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c27"></span></p><p class="c97 c7 c228"><span class="c33 c155 c27 c218"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c97 c228 c7"><span class="c33 c155 c27 c218"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c198"><span class="c10 c17">Aversion, triggered, learned avoidance, emotional excess, hijacked, self righteous, annoyed, angry, exaggerated style </span></p><h1 class="c97 c112 c61" id="h.lcxjrspw7l6a"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Try these phrases to calm your nervous system.</span></h1><p class="c97 c112"><span class="c8">To help calm your autonomic nervous system, try repeating to these calming phrases suggested by Eliza Bragg: </span></p><ul class="c41 lst-kix_j3rps13ls235-0 start"><li class="c97 c112 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c33 c111 c17">&lsquo;I feel relaxed yet alert&rsquo;</span></li><li class="c97 c112 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c33 c111 c17">&lsquo;I am resilient and competent&rdquo; </span></li><li class="c97 c112 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c33 c111 c17">&lsquo;I have the tools and ability to calm myself&rsquo; </span></li><li class="c97 c112 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c111 c17">&lsquo;I know when and to whom to reach out to for help&rsquo;</span></li></ul><p class="c97 c112"><span class="c58 c17">Recommended reading:</span><span class="c155 c27">&nbsp; </span><span class="c71 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://bespoketraumatherapy.com/somatic-experiencing&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309682838&amp;usg=AOvVaw3QfrCJUG3BBqWtAaVHJbro">Somatic Experiencing &mdash; Elisa Bragg</a></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c90 c40"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c64">{M:LATE}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c97 c112"><span class="c8">Aversion, triggered , stressed, traumatized, fight, flee, freeze, fawn </span></p><h1 class="c97 c61 c112" id="h.u2hrzwhly8jw"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Do you recognise your stress pattern </span><span>and</span><span class="c12">&nbsp;that of others?</span></h1><p class="c97 c112"><span class="c8">Do you react to stress with flight, fight, freeze or a fawn response? </span></p><p class="c97 c112"><span class="c8">Are you challenged or triggered by the behavior of others who take a different route when stressed?</span></p><p class="c97 c112"><span class="c58 c17">Recommended reading:</span><span class="c17 c27">&nbsp;</span><span class="c71 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://complextraumahealing.wordpress.com/2019/02/08/the-4f-trauma-personality-types/&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309684433&amp;usg=AOvVaw3uNjlLOVQF09_t3GXP9zK9">The 4F Trauma Personality Types and Recovery</a></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c64">{M:LATE}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c97 c112"><span class="c33 c17 c27">Aversion, learned avoidance, resistant, rejecting reality, denial, avoidance, flee/flight </span></p><h1 class="c97 c112 c61" id="h.svk138jb9r2l"><span class="c17 c25 c37">Know that </span><span>not facing A</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">version </span><span>can cause</span><span class="c12">&nbsp;more problems. </span></h1><p class="c97 c112"><span class="c17 c40">Are you working to overcome your &lsquo;aversion&rsquo; or avoidant behavior?</span></p><p class="c97 c112"><span class="c58 c17">Hermann Hesse puts it his way:</span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&nbsp;&ldquo;Love your suffering. Do not resist it, do not flee from it. It is only your aversion to it that hurts, nothing else.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c84"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c17 c27">Appeasing, approval seeking, fawning, &nbsp;accommodating, kowtowing , yak-like, yoked </span></p><h1 class="c104 c61" id="h.wcrr6ybx9n6q"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Do you have the </span><span>A</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">ttributes of a </span><span>P</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">eople </span><span>P</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">leaser?</span></h1><p class="c29"><span class="c8">Does this persona sound like you?</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><ul class="c41 lst-kix_6mpf5zk2xbbc-0 start"><li class="c112 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">People consider you are &lsquo;very kind&rsquo; person</span></li><li class="c112 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">You tend to agree with whoever is in front of you</span></li><li class="c102 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">You apologize for things that aren&rsquo;t your fault</span></li><li class="c102 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">You find it hard to say &lsquo;no&rsquo;</span></li><li class="c102 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">You tend to shift your behavior to match the situation </span></li><li class="c102 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Your worth depends upon how others see you</span></li></ul><p class="c29 c24"><span class="c17 c40">Adapted from </span><span class="c71 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.webmd.com/mental-health/what-is-a-people-pleaser&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309687751&amp;usg=AOvVaw0KViwDRmcl0fZuV3F-ibFt">What Is a People Pleaser?</a></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c24"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c102"><span class="c8">The above characteristics are those of a &lsquo;people-pleaser&rsquo;. We also term this behavior &lsquo;appeasement&rsquo; or &rsquo;approval-seeking&rsquo;.</span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c72"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c72"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c72"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c17 c27">Agreeable, Appeasement, approval-seeking (people pleasing), fawning &nbsp;accommodating, kowtowing, yak, yoked, insecure</span></p><h1 class="c99 c61" id="h.c9lnifaffcgh"><span class="c91 c17 c25">Are you </span><span class="c91">&lsquo;</span><span class="c91 c17 c25">Agreeable</span><span class="c91">&rsquo;</span><span class="c17 c25 c91">&nbsp;or &lsquo;Too </span><span class="c91">A</span><span class="c73 c91 c17 c25">greeable&rsquo; for your own good?</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">Below is a brief overview of agreeable-ness by self help author Sherri Gordon. She explains where being &lsquo;agreeable&rsquo; fits into personality assessment:</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c102"><span class="c111 c36 c17">&ldquo;When it comes to personality traits, if you&#39;re someone that has scored high in agreeableness, you&#39;re likely popular and tend to make friends easily. You also may be seen as trustworthy, altruistic, honest, modest, empathetic, and cooperative. Agreeableness is one of the Big Five personality traits, which theorizes that there are five major dimensions to personality.&rdquo; &nbsp;Sherri Gordon &nbsp;</span><span class="c71 c36 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.verywellmind.com/how-agreeableness-affects-your-behavior-4843762%23:~:text%3DIf%2520someone%2520scores%2520high%2520in,are%2520easy%2520to%2520relate%2520to&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309690099&amp;usg=AOvVaw0t00DVRj9a6oeDucsu8Ao6">How Agreeableness Affects Your Behavior</a></span><span class="c33 c111 c36 c17">.</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">The issue is not with being &lsquo;agreeable&rsquo; which is a good thing. But it can be difficult keeping a happy balance. The problem arises when we are &lsquo;too agreeable&rsquo; or not agreeable enough. &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c102 c7"><span class="c33 c111 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c102 c7"><span class="c33 c111 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c17 c27">Appeasement, approval-seeking (people pleasing), fawning &nbsp;accommodating, kowtowing, yak, yoked, insecure</span></p><h1 class="c99 c61" id="h.5bbmz7hm490h"><span class="c91 c17 c25">Understand the </span><span class="c91">D</span><span class="c91 c17 c25">ownside of being &lsquo;</span><span class="c91">T</span><span class="c91 c17 c25">oo </span><span class="c91">A</span><span class="c91 c17 c25">greeable&rsquo;?</span></h1><p class="c102"><span class="c8 c36">Self-help author Sherri Gordon says that:</span></p><p class="c102"><span class="c111 c36 c17">&ldquo;Although agreeableness has many positive aspects, there are some downsides. For instance, agreeable people may struggle to assert their wants, needs, and preferences. They also struggle in situations that require tough decisions or tough love. And when it comes to their careers, they may be so intent on helping others get ahead that they forget to plan their own advancement.&rdquo; Sherri Gordon &nbsp;</span><span class="c71 c36 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.verywellmind.com/how-agreeableness-affects-your-behavior-4843762%23:~:text%3DIf%2520someone%2520scores%2520high%2520in,are%2520easy%2520to%2520relate%2520to&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309692441&amp;usg=AOvVaw2b_djQ_d5OFLvNR4EaGR8H">How Agreeableness Affects Your Behavior</a></span><span class="c33 c111 c36 c17">.</span></p><p class="c102 c7"><span class="c33 c111 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c39 c17">Your Challenge: </span><span class="c17 c40">Consider h</span><span class="c8">ow often do you put your needs second or even last? You might have even no idea what your own needs really are!</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">Can you see how this approach has impacted your life in a negative way?</span></p><p class="c102 c7"><span class="c33 c111 c17 c140"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c33 c17 c27">Approval seeking, Appeasing, , fawning &nbsp;accommodating, kowtowing , yak, yoked , yielding, emotional exhaustion, compassion-fatigue, enmeshed</span></p><h1 class="c104 c61" id="h.ihqdzkhdmev7"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Contemplate the </span><span>D</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">ownside of being a &lsquo;People Pleaser&rsquo; </span></h1><p class="c102"><span class="c8">Have you lost sight of the true and authentic you?</span></p><p class="c102"><span class="c8">Consider the following questions:</span></p><ul class="c41 lst-kix_jklgap87ggrk-0 start"><li class="c102 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Do you know what makes people around you happy - but not what makes you happy - let alone doing anything about it?</span></li><li class="c102 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Are you so busy taking care of the needs of others that there is no time left for your own relaxation and maintenance?</span></li><li class="c102 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Has a lack of downtime and being at the call of others caused you to feel constantly stressed and wound up?</span></li><li class="c102 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c17 c40">Have you developed a simmering resentment that can boil over into an &lsquo;Mt Vesuvius&rsquo; volcanic eruption? </span><span class="c176 c17 c120 c266">&nbsp; </span></li></ul><p class="c102"><span class="c39 c17">Ask yourself this:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Do you truly want to continue living this way?</span></p><p class="c102 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c102 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10 c17">Appeasing, Approval seeking, fawn, acquiescence, victim, domineering,persecutor, aggressive, harsh, controlling, co-opting, kowtowing, yielding, toxic, negating others, condemning, victim traits </span></p><h1 class="c45 c61 c92" id="h.3l56g3iu2xml"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Which </span><span>R</span><span class="c12">ole are you playing?</span></h1><p class="c16"><span class="c17 c40">Everyone has a &ldquo;perpetrator&quot; (too mean) part of them and a &ldquo;</span><span class="c17 c40">victim</span><span class="c39 c17">&rdquo;</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;(too nice) part. Hopefully there is also a &ldquo;grown-up&rdquo; or </span><span class="c17 c40">psychologically differentiated</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;part too. </span></p><p class="c16"><span class="c58 c17">In their book, </span><span class="c58 c17 c43">The Power and Grace between Nasty or Nice, </span><span class="c20 c17">John &amp; Linda Friel explain that:</span></p><p class="c16"><span class="c17 c32">&ldquo;Within a given individual, these parts come in different sizes.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c16"><span class="c39 c17">Your challenge:</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;Can you identify when</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;you are in a victim, perpetrator or grown-up mode?</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c16 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c83 c45"><span class="c33 c10 c17">Appeasement, approval seeking, acquiescence, avoidant, &nbsp;fawn, kowtowing, yes-man, yoked </span></p><h1 class="c16 c61" id="h.4anzqyu"><span class="c12">Where did you pick up the &lsquo;people-pleasing&rsquo; habit?</span></h1><p class="c16"><span class="c58 c17 c25">Consider the Origin for your &lsquo;People-Pleasing&rsquo;:</span></p><p class="c16"><span class="c20 c17">Were your parents stressed? </span></p><p class="c16"><span class="c20 c17">&gt; Did this lead them to some compensatory behavior such as alcoholism, workaholism, or other behavior? </span></p><p class="c16"><span class="c20 c17">&gt; Did your parents somehow become distracted from their parental role?</span></p><p class="c16"><span class="c20 c17">Perhaps as a result you took on the role of a good girl or boy to gain love and attention. Maybe you are still carrying on this &lsquo;appeasement&rsquo; behavior into your adult relationships.</span></p><p class="c16"><span class="c58 c17 c43">Your challenge</span><span class="c20 c17">: Consider the possible origin of your &lsquo;people-pleasing&rsquo; behavior. </span></p><p class="c16"><span class="c58 c17">Is it still in your best interest to continue this &lsquo;appeasement&rsquo; or &lsquo;approval seeking&rsquo; behavior? </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c33 c17 c153">Validation seeking, approval seeking, appeasement, &nbsp;fawning, Codependency, kowtowing, yes man, lack of self worth &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c31"><span class="c12">Do you seek external Validation for your self-worth?</span></p><p class="c31"><span class="c8">Consider an alternative approach to external validation. It&rsquo;s believing in yourself:</span></p><p class="c31"><span class="c36 c17 c32">&ldquo;Belief in yourself is more important than endless worries of what others think of you. Value yourself and others will value you. Validation is best that comes from within.&rdquo; &nbsp; </span><span class="c17 c32">Ng&#361;g&#297; wa Thiong&rsquo;o, </span><span class="c17 c32 c43"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.goodreads.com/work/quotes/6912943&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309698555&amp;usg=AOvVaw1N5dr8m9mdzu8vgOhrZr96">Dreams in a Time of War</a></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c83 c45"><span class="c33 c10 c17">Approval seeking, appeasement, acquiescence, fawn, kowtowing, yes-man</span></p><h1 class="c31 c61" id="h.14ykbeg"><span class="c37 c17 c25">How</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">&nbsp;does being a &lsquo;</span><span>P</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">eople-</span><span>P</span><span class="c12">leaser&rsquo; impact your life? </span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">Consider writing down or j</span><span class="c8">ournaling &nbsp;both the positive and negative impacts of being a &lsquo;people pleaser&rsquo;. Technically we call this behavior &lsquo;approval seeking&rsquo; or &lsquo;appeasement&rsquo;. &nbsp; </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c39 c17">Try this approach:</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;Look at the positive &amp; negative impact this </span><span class="c58 c17 c253">behavior has</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;in your life. This includes work, relationships and recreation.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c39 c17">Your challenge: </span><span class="c17 c40">Ask yourself: </span></p><ul class="c41 lst-kix_39mjwylz18c5-0 start"><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">How has my past &lsquo;people-pleasing&rsquo; behavior impacted me?</span></li><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">How does my &lsquo;approval seeking&rsquo; behavior affect me now?</span></li><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">How will this affect me in the future if I don&rsquo;t change?</span></li></ul><p class="c1 c7 c24"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7 c24"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c72"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c72"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">M:EARLY}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c83 c45"><span class="c8">Appeasement, approval seeking, acquiescence, &nbsp;anxiety ( mild), insecure, neurotic, sensitive, angst, avoidant, fawn, kowtowing, yes-man, stress,</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.p3pgp31ycqnh"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Do you &lsquo;</span><span>P</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">eople-</span><span>P</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">lease&rsquo; to </span><span>A</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">void </span><span>C</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">onflict </span><span>&amp;</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">&nbsp;</span><span>A</span><span class="c12">nger?</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c36 c17 c40">Consider this rationale for &lsquo;appeasement&rsquo; behavior or &lsquo;people pleasing&rsquo;. It&rsquo;s from self-help author David Burns: </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c36 c17 c32">&ldquo;People who are prone to anxiety are nearly always people-pleasers who fear conflict and negative feelings like anger. When you feel upset, you sweep your problems under the rug because you don&#39;t want to upset anyone. You do this so quickly and automatically that you&#39;re not even aware you&#39;re doing it.&rsquo; </span><span class="c17 c32">David D. Burns, </span><span class="c17 c32 c43"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.goodreads.com/work/quotes/199282&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309702027&amp;usg=AOvVaw2zQz-hfLASWosQkYXBLg7d">When Panic Attacks: The New, Drug-Free Anxiety Therapy That Can Change Your Life</a></span><span class="c4">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c39 c17">Your challenge:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Consider whether this explanation could apply to you?</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{A:EARLY}</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Approval seeking, Appeasement, compassion fatigue, kowtowing, yes-man, acquiescence, fawn, &nbsp;yoked, &nbsp;emotional exhaustion, resentment, stress</span></p><h1 class="c1 c61" id="h.3oy7u29"><span class="c12">Are you being kind enough to yourself?</span></h1><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Consider whether you are generally more kind to others than to yourself. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">It&#39;s ok to be agreeable and cooperate with others, however it&#39;s easy to go too far - especially if you are driven by a &lsquo;need to please&rsquo;. We also call that &lsquo;approval-seeking&rsquo; or &lsquo;appeasement&rsquo; behavior. </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c39 c17">Your Challenge:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Have you noticed this tendency to overgiving? Has this led to lack of self care and perhaps exhaustion or resentment?</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17">A</span><span class="c17">ppeasement, approval seeking, acquiescence, fawn, kowtowing, yes-man, controlled easily , manipulated easily, yoked, angst, resentment, emotional exhaustion,resentment &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.owo0x7gqafms"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Are you at </span><span>R</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">isk of being </span><span>E</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">xploited by others?</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Is your need to be &lsquo;approved of&rsquo; leading to you being exploited?</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Is your time, energy or loyalty currently being exploited by others?</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Remember that appeasing others or approval seeking behavior (people-pleasing) or acquiescence (giving-in) is usually done to gain approval.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Having this tendency you are a prime target to be taken advantage of. This can occur unconsciously by others around you. You can be subtly taken advantage of! And in the case of narcissists and psychopaths this is a deliberate manipulation.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c68 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c68 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c68 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c83 c45"><span class="c8">Appeasement, avoidant, fawn, kowtowing, controlled, yes-man, acquiescence, learned avoidance, timid, passive </span></p><h1 class="c1 c61" id="h.gifuceo38zdt"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Are you limiting yourself by avoiding conflict?</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c39 c17">Your Challenge:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Consider how often you avoid conflict in daily life:</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">&gt; Do you &lsquo;acquiesce&rsquo; or &lsquo;give-in&rsquo; too easily to others? &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">&gt; Do you &lsquo;people-please&rsquo; or &lsquo;appease&rsquo; to be liked? </span></p><p class="c168 c45"><span class="c8">&gt; Do you take on too much because it&#39;s hard to say &lsquo;no&rsquo;?</span></p><p class="c45 c168"><span class="c17 c40">Consider this quote from </span><span class="c20 c17">Bernard Kelvin Clive:</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c36 c17 c32">&ldquo;If you are too afraid to offend anyone, then I&#39;m afraid you may not be able to do anything remarkable&rdquo; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c11"><span class="c8">Appeasement, acquiescence, kowtowing, &nbsp;yes man, yoked </span></p><h1 class="c190 c45 c61" id="h.yefxycryt59g"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Be </span><span>k</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">ind if you occasionally slip back to old ways. </span></h1><p class="c11"><span class="c8">Remember that changing patterns you have held for years can be challenging. Progress forward takes courage and determination. </span></p><p class="c11"><span class="c17 c40">It also requires self-compassion and understanding when there are inevitable slip-backs. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c11"><span class="c39 c17">Your Challenge:</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">Be kind to yourself if sometimes you don&#39;t act as well as you would have wished. That&#39;s called having self-compassion. Give yourself a break, but you can still remember the lesson!</span></p><p class="c11"><span class="c17 c40">This quote from </span><span class="c58 c36 c17">Christopher Germer</span><span class="c36 c17 c32">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">might help: </span></p><p class="c11"><span class="c36 c17 c32">&lsquo;Self-compassion is simply giving the same kindness to ourselves that we would give to others.&rsquo; </span></p><p class="c11 c7"><span class="c4"></span></p><p class="c11 c7"><span class="c4"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c59 c17">Appeasement, approval seeking, acquiescence, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing &nbsp; </span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c190 c45 c61" id="h.sjmdfso3rft2"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Keep on going</span><span>&hellip;</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">&nbsp;it&rsquo;s worth it ! </span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c20 c17">Remember that changing old patterns can be challenging. You will likely have setbacks on your journey. But don&rsquo;t give up - it&rsquo;s worth reclaiming your life. You are worth it! Take time to appreciate your wins no matter how small they may seem to others.</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c20 c17">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c17 c43">Consider this:</span><span class="c20 c17">&nbsp;Those who seem dismissive of your wins usually have their own issues to overcome. They could be focusing on your journey to avoid doing their own work !</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c17">Some people may consciously or subconsciously want you to stay as accommodating, as it benefited them. So they may indicate their displeasure of you changing. </span><span class="c17 c40">Consider all this when you encounter obstruction from others. </span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c17 c27">Approval seeking, </span><span class="c33 c59 c17">Appeasement, acquiescence, authentic, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing, insecure, indecisive, doubts &nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c114 c45 c61" id="h.4fsjm0b"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Understand how being &lsquo;</span><span>A</span><span class="c12">uthentic&rsquo; can help you:</span></h1><p class="c42"><span class="c39 c17">Remember this:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;It&#39;s almost impossible to please everyone - especially if you also include yourself. So instead, be your authentic self! Then you will attract people who like and appreciate the real you. </span></p><p class="c42"><span class="c70 c39 c17">Consider this quote: </span></p><p class="c11"><span class="c36 c17 c32">&ldquo;Don&#39;t go into the business of pleasing people. You can&#39;t please everybody. Simply do your best at what you do&rdquo; </span><span class="c17 c32">Bangambiki Habyarimana, </span><span class="c17 c32 c43"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.goodreads.com/work/quotes/46911351&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309716413&amp;usg=AOvVaw0tHEGsOvyr7YXkylyOaLA7">The Great Pearl of Wisdom</a></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c109 c45"><span class="c33 c59 c17">&nbsp;Appeasement, acquiescence, approval seeking, avoidant, not assertiveness, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing, insecure, neurotic &nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c114 c45 c61" id="h.2uxtw84"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Develop your </span><span>A</span><span class="c12">ssertiveness skills</span></h1><p class="c42"><span class="c36 c17 c40">Developing your assertiveness</span><span class="c36">&nbsp;skills</span><span class="c8 c36">&nbsp;can help many aspects of life. It&rsquo;s particularly beneficial in overcoming &lsquo;people-pleasing&rsquo;, approval seeking and avoidant behavior. It&#39;s also an important goal in managing anger or aggression. </span></p><p class="c42"><span class="c36 c17 c40">Consider this explanation of assertiveness from the W.A. Center for Clinical Intervention: </span></p><p class="c42"><span class="c36 c17 c32">&ldquo;Assertiveness means expressing your point of view in a way that is clear and direct, while still respecting others. Communicating in an assertive manner can help you to minimise conflict, to control anger, to have your needs better met, and to have more positive relationships with friends, family and others.&rdquo;</span><span class="c36 c17 c32 c43">&nbsp;</span><span class="c70 c39 c17">Western Australian Centre for Clinical Interventions </span></p><p class="c42 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c42"><span class="c8 c36">The following link will take you to their &lsquo;Assertiveness Workbook&rsquo; for more information and activities.</span></p><p class="c42"><span class="c71 c36 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.cci.health.wa.gov.au/Resources/Looking-After-Yourself/Assertiveness&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309719045&amp;usg=AOvVaw0izIjSZsKZ1Rs1_16AF0ZI">Improving Assertiveness Self-Help Resources - Information Sheets</a></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c109 c45"><span class="c17">&nbsp;</span><span class="c36 c17">Avoiding conflict, </span><span class="c33 c59 c17">&nbsp;approval seeking, appeasement, acquiescence, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing, controlled easily, not assertive, &nbsp;insecure, neurotic, victim traits &nbsp; &nbsp; </span></p><h1 class="c114 c45 c61" id="h.2m7ny76ekdwr"><span class="c12">Recognise attempts by others to &lsquo;put you down&rsquo;</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">I</span><span class="c8">f you have a tendency to avoid conflict and want to please others it is important to be wary of the efforts of those with narcissistic traits. They will try to undermine your sense of self confidence and efficacy. It&#39;s their strategy to keep you in your place and to avoid facing their own shortcomings and responsibility.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36"><span class="c39 c17">Your Challenge:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Recognise when others are attempting to dump undeserved shame, blame and criticism onto you. Don&rsquo;t allow them to put their &lsquo;monkey&rsquo; of feeling bad onto your back. Don&#39;t avoid dealing with your own saboteurs simply by labeling all others whom you find challenging as narcissists.</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c109 c45"><span class="c33 c59 c17">&nbsp;Approval seeking, validation seeking, appeasement, acquiescence, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing, insecure , neurotic, sensitive &nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c114 c45 c61" id="h.yxwpz9r31vef"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Are you </span><span>A</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">ddicted to </span><span>A</span><span class="c12">pproval? </span></h1><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c17 c40">If you have the need for constant approval there is a big downside or a &lsquo;big cost&rsquo; you will pay. David Burns a professor of psychiatry at Stanford explains it this way:<br></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c33 c17 c32">&ldquo;The price you pay for your addiction to praise will be an extreme vulnerability to the opinions of others. Like any addict, you will find you must continue to feed your habit with approval in order to avoid withdrawal pangs. The moment someone who is important to you expresses disapproval, you will crash painfully, just like the junkie who can no longer get his &ldquo;stuff.&rdquo; <br></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c17 c40">Recommended reference: </span><span class="c58 c17">&nbsp;David D. Burns, </span><span class="c51 c17 c43">Feeling Good: The New Mood Therapy</span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c8"><br></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c70 c59 c17 c43"></span></p><p class="c114 c45"><span class="c59 c17">&nbsp;</span><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c8">Approval seeking, validation seeking, acquiescent, assertive, apathy, neurotic, sensitive, insecure, controlled easily &nbsp; </span></p><h1 class="c26 c13" id="h.tmpaepc84pk"><span class="c12">Understand that life is more than being &lsquo;a doormat&rsquo;</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c36 c17 c40">We all have great inherent worth but often don&#39;t see this. Instead we often measure our worth by how much approval we get from others. This is sometimes termed being &lsquo;a doormat&rsquo; for others &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c58 c36 c17">Consider the words of Bryant McGill, author of </span><span class="c58 c36 c17 c43">Simple Reminders: Inspiration for Living Your Best Life:</span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c18 c17">&ldquo;Your life was meant for more than being a life-long doormat for deadbeats, losers, gossipers, naysayers, dream-crushers, energy vampires, users, abusers, ragers, and passive-aggressive backstabbers.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c42"><span class="c39 c17">Your Challenge</span><span class="c17 c40">: S</span><span class="c8">tart addressing this issue. Note the feeling you get when interacting with others - do they uplift and encourage you on your journey or do you feel discouraged and &lsquo;less than&rsquo;? Are you simply &lsquo;a doormat&rsquo; to them?</span></p><p class="c42 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c42 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c114 c45"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c42"><span class="c59 c17">Approval seeking, Validation seeking, Appeasement, acquiescence, fawn, approval seeking, yes-man, kowtowing, codependent, rescuing &nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c213 c45 c61" id="h.dyeprhz0o8ur"><span>Understand </span><span class="c37 c17 c25">People </span><span>P</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">leasing vs </span><span>A</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">uthentic </span><span>K</span><span class="c12">indness.</span></h1><p class="c42"><span class="c8">Do you understand the real differences between &lsquo;authentic kindness&rsquo; and &lsquo;people pleasing&rsquo;? </span></p><p class="c42 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c42"><span class="c8">A people pleaser may falsely think they are being kind when they engage in appeasing or acquiescent behavior.</span></p><p class="c42"><span class="c17 c40">The comparative list which illustrates the difference is available from The Holistic Psychologist article linked below: </span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c71 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://themindsjournal.com/authentic-kindness-vs-people-pleasing/&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309725400&amp;usg=AOvVaw1dPc-dkgdEdFyEk3kdJLSa">Authentic Kindness Vs. People Pleasing</a></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c42 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c42 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c114 c45"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c109 c45"><span class="c33 c59 c17">Appeasement, acquiescence, lacking assertiveness, insecure, neurotic, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing &nbsp; </span></p><h1 class="c213 c45 c61" id="h.z1s7ssom3rj5"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Consider why you lack sufficient assertiveness.</span></h1><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c39 c17">Consider this: </span><span class="c8">Were you discouraged from asserting your own views and needs as a child?</span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c8">The following explanation is by Beverly Engel a psychotherapist &amp; self-help author:</span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c18 c17">&ldquo;The messages you received from your family or your childhood experiences may have caused you to believe that assertiveness is unacceptable or even dangerous.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c39 c17">Your Challenge: </span><span class="c17 c40">Consider</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;this strategy suggested by Engel: </span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c18 c17">&ldquo;Practice saying the following: I have the right to be treated with respect by others. I have the right to express my feelings and opinions. I have the right to say no without feeling guilty. I have the right to ask for what I want. I have the right to make my own mistakes. I have the right to pursue happiness.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c58 c36 c17">Recommended Reading:</span><span class="c58 c36 c17 c43">&nbsp;</span><span class="c58 c36 c17">Beverly Engel </span><span class="c58 c36 c17 c43"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.goodreads.com/work/quotes/2885602&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309727571&amp;usg=AOvVaw3XJExCUNkNqNNmNwNcqFwm">The Nice Girl Syndrome: Stop Being Manipulated and Abused -- And Start Standing Up for Yourself</a></span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c33 c59 c17">&nbsp;Appeasement, acquiescence, approval seeking, not assertive, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing, powerlessness &nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c42 c61" id="h.7qnep5797jp4"><span class="c37 c17 c25">You can say &lsquo;no&rsquo; to unreasonable demands.</span></h1><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c8 c36">It is important to say &lsquo;no&rsquo; to requests that are not in your best interest long term? That might seem obvious but often we don&#39;t do it in practice. We might even think we are being mean.</span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c8 c36">How do we overcome all this? Psychotherapist Beverly Engel explains it this way: </span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c18 c17">&ldquo;If you live your life to please everyone else, you will continue to feel frustrated and powerless. This is because what others want may not be good for you. You are not being mean when you say NO to unreasonable demands or when you express your ideas, feelings, and opinions, even if they differ from those of others.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c58 c36 c17">Recommended reading: Beverly Engel </span><span class="c58 c36 c17 c43"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.goodreads.com/work/quotes/2885602&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309729638&amp;usg=AOvVaw1K_YV709-8U5OUyxQPfU7i">The Nice Girl Syndrome: Stop Being Manipulated and Abused -- And Start Standing Up for Yourself</a></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c18 c17">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c70 c39 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c59 c17">Appeasement, acquiescence, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing &nbsp;</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; </span></p><h1 class="c26 c13" id="h.kmdxw5se03o8"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Setting good </span><span>B</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">oundaries is important. &nbsp;</span></h1><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c8 c36">We know that having &lsquo;healthy boundaries&rsquo; is important. But what could be holding you back? </span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c8 c36">You might feel that you are putting yourself first. That can feel selfish so you don&#39;t do it. The answer is to treat yourself as an equal: &nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c8">For more advice: Watch this 60 second video</span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c71 c36 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.youtube.com/shorts/enctOnICYKw&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309730926&amp;usg=AOvVaw1rKQA_IATtyRlQHpjRmHWq">If You Find It Hard To Set Boundaries | Dr Julie - YouTube</a></span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c114 c45"><span class="c33 c59 c17">&nbsp;Appeasement, approval seeking, acquiescence, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing</span></p><p class="c114 c45"><span class="c12">Understand the Damage that &lsquo;People Pleasing&rsquo; does.</span></p><p class="c109 c45"><span class="c8">To overcome our &lsquo;people pleasing&rsquo; it helps to understand its &nbsp;deleterious effect on us. Do you know what these are? </span></p><p class="c109 c45"><span class="c8">&nbsp;We are giving up parts of our authentic self. &nbsp;The damage increases with time if we don&#39;t address this. </span></p><p class="c109 c45"><span class="c17 c40">This video from psychologist Dr. Julie helps summarizes this process:</span></p><h1 class="c26 c13" id="h.cu6jj03qy1dj"><span class="c71 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.youtube.com/shorts/s2iH2nRABww&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309732024&amp;usg=AOvVaw22l0-A1nYJNRVVWh3KgGqa">Stop Being A People Pleaser - Dr Julie #shorts - YouTube</a></span></h1><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c59 c17">&nbsp;Not assertive, Appeasement, acquiescence, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing &nbsp;</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26 c13" id="h.asxpc2ndp4fa"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Be willing to </span><span>P</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">ush </span><span>B</span><span class="c12">ack if you are being disrespected. </span></h1><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c8 c36">If your opinion is disrespected or your voice is not heard, then it&#39;s time to take a stand. That requires taking a risk. </span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c36 c17 c40">&nbsp;Self help author Beverly Engel explains it this way:</span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c18 c17">&ldquo;If someone is inconsiderate or rude to you, risk telling them how it made you feel or that you didn&rsquo;t appreciate being treated that way. If you tend to talk yourself out of anger by telling yourself that you don&rsquo;t want to make waves, try telling yourself instead that it is okay to make waves sometimes and risk letting people know how you really feel.</span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c58 c36 c17">Recommended reading: &rdquo;Beverly Engel, </span><span class="c58 c36 c17 c43"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.goodreads.com/work/quotes/2885602&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309734152&amp;usg=AOvVaw1vM2MNOEkQTad6e7x5LS6t">The Nice Girl Syndrome: Stop Being Manipulated and Abused -- And Start Standing Up for Yourself</a></span></p><p class="c45 c7 c114"><span class="c33 c59 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c114 c45 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c17"></span></p><p class="c114 c45 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c114 c45"><span class="c59 c17">Validation seeking , approval seeking, appeasement, acquiescence, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26 c13" id="h.wosr6fgpl3ye"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Regain your </span><span>P</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">ower by not needing the approval of others.</span></h1><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c36 c17 c40">Ponder this perspective from self-help author Caroline Myss:</span></p><p class="c31"><span class="c36 c17 c32">&nbsp;&ldquo;</span><span class="c36 c17 c32"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://quotefancy.com/quote/783435/Caroline-Myss-When-you-do-not-seek-or-need-approval-you-are-at-your-most-powerful&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309735112&amp;usg=AOvVaw1UWR6LV6D3ptcaJLBOxatT">When you do not seek or need approval, you are at your most powerful.</a></span><span class="c36 c17 c32">&rdquo; </span><span class="c36 c17 c32"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://quotefancy.com/caroline-myss-quotes&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309735216&amp;usg=AOvVaw0Ym2XxQqgmJbl3EhwvaMqd">Caroline Myss</a></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c114 c45 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c114 c45"><span class="c59 c17">&nbsp;Appeasement, acquiescence, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing &nbsp;</span><span class="c33 c59 c17">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c114 c45"><span class="c12">Tips for overcoming the &lsquo;Need to Please&rsquo; </span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c8">Below are 12 strategies to help overcome a tendency to &lsquo;people please&rsquo; adapted from therapist Sharon Martin (link below). </span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c73 c17 c25 c40">The strategies to overcome People Pleasing include:</span></p><ol class="c41 lst-kix_g8knw9wvly8f-0 start" start="1"><li class="c56 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">&nbsp; Recognize that your needs matter.</span></li><li class="c56 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">&nbsp; Don&#39;t assume people will think badly of you.</span></li><li class="c56 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">&nbsp; Tolerate the discomfort of being criticized.</span></li><li class="c56 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">&nbsp; Seek people who accept you.</span></li><li class="c56 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">&nbsp; Get to know what your preferences are. </span></li><li class="c56 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">&nbsp; Identify what your core values are. </span></li><li class="c56 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">&nbsp; Live authentically in alignment with your beliefs.</span></li><li class="c56 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">&nbsp; &nbsp;Be assertive.</span></li><li class="c56 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">&nbsp; &nbsp;Set boundaries without feeling guilty.</span></li><li class="c56 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Accept that not everyone will like you.</span></li><li class="c56 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Learn to give and take in relationships.</span></li><li class="c56 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Accept that you can&#39;t control what people think. &nbsp;</span></li></ol><p class="c114 c45 c24"><span class="c8">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c17 c120 c284">&nbsp;</span><span class="c71 c17 c120 c288"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://sharonmartincounseling.com/need-to-please-therapy-95008/&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309737294&amp;usg=AOvVaw2NFSZWWMX3J8BYdcnKapb7">Understanding the Need to Please - Sharon Martin, LCSW Counseling San Jose and Campbell, CA</a></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c97 c56 c134 c45 c79 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c109 c45"><span class="c59 c17">&nbsp;Appeasement, acquiescence, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing, indecisive, timid, passive &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26 c13" id="h.rnbpbosbnyyz"><span class="c12">Remember, you are responsible for your own happiness.</span></h1><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c8">Have you been trained not to take charge of your life? Realize that you are responsible for your own happiness. Other people are responsible for their happiness. </span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c36 c17 c40">Consider the following perspective offered by business consultant Isaiah Hankel:</span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c18 c17">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c18 c17">&ldquo;Don&rsquo;t ever feel bad for making a decision about your own life that upsets other people. You are not responsible for their happiness. You&rsquo;re responsible for your own happiness. Anyone who wants you to live in misery for their happiness should not be in your life anyway.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c109 c45"><span class="c59 c17">&nbsp;Appeasement, acquiescence, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing , insecure, sensitive, neurotic &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26 c13" id="h.d4etlzoagf02"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Are you trying to </span><span class="c37 c17 c25">be</span><span class="c12">&nbsp;someone else?</span></h1><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c39 c17">Ponder</span><span class="c39 c17">&nbsp;this:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Are you trying to get people to like you by not being your authentic self? </span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c8">The practice of being inauthentic often starts in childhood when we take on a false identity or &lsquo;mask&rsquo; to please our parents or others. &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c8 c36">Consider this solution offered by psychoanalyst Alice Miller:</span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c18 c17">&nbsp;&ldquo;The answer is that we can never do the right thing as long as we are out to please someone else. We can only be the people we are, and we cannot force our parents to love us. There are parents who can only love the mask their child wears.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c58 c36 c17">Recommended reference: Alice Miller, </span><span class="c58 c36 c17 c43"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.goodreads.com/work/quotes/690803&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309740669&amp;usg=AOvVaw0ueyCZoizgqHJcXK7Z4L_0">The Body Never Lies: The Lingering Effects of Hurtful Parenting</a></span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c64">{M:LATE}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c114 c45"><span class="c33 c59 c17">&nbsp;appeasement,acquiescence, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing &nbsp; </span></p><h1 class="c114 c45 c61" id="h.nshdmt7ou3qv"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Build character, not just popularity?</span></h1><p class="c114 c45"><span class="c8">This video explains the problem with always trying to be nice: </span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c77 c40"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v%3D-TxzW4eklEU&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309741661&amp;usg=AOvVaw3YE8pJGMVwS8UxpghUztwy">Stop Trying to Be Nice All the Time</a></span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c4 c36"></span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c4 c36"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c64">{M:LATE}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17">Appeasement, avoiding, kowtowing, yielding, yesman, timid </span></p><h1 class="c114 c45 c61" id="h.2gniqlgonrsu"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Try these </span><span>S</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">trategies for </span><span>H</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">andling </span><span>D</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">ifficult </span><span>P</span><span class="c12">eople</span></h1><p class="c114 c45"><span class="c8">Do you use appeasement and &lsquo;people pleasing&rsquo; to protect yourself? &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Consider this approach suggested by Bill Eddy, a legal mediator &amp; therapist. &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c33 c17 c32">&ldquo;People who cause conflict and disharmony wherever they go exist everywhere. Sometimes you can avoid them and sometimes it is more difficult to do so. Rather than being brow beaten by them and losing your confidence and peace of mind, learn strategies to stay in your power and handle them and tricky situations with power and grace.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;Recommended Reference: Bill Eddy, </span><span class="c39 c17">5 Types of People Who Can Ruin Your Life</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c64"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c64"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c114 c45"><span class="c59 c17">&nbsp;Fear of rejection, Approval seeking , validation seeking Appeasement, acquiescence, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c54 c45 c61" id="h.9v18wz7v6pwz"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Give up your </span><span>F</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">ear of </span><span>R</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">ejection. </span></h1><p class="c54 c45"><span class="c39 c17">Understand this:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Some people will never give their approval to you. So, it&rsquo;s a waste of your time trying to gain it. In particular, don&rsquo;t worry about being rejected by aggressive and difficult people.</span></p><p class="c54 c45"><span class="c58 c17">&nbsp;Marisa Peer puts it this way: </span><span class="c18 c17">&ldquo;One of the most important lessons I ever learnt was to stop fearing rejection.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c54 c45"><span class="c58 c36 c17">Recommended Resource: </span><span class="c58 c17">Marisa Peer, </span><span class="c58 c17 c43">Ultimate Confidence: The Secrets to Feeling Great About Yourself Every Day</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c64">{M:LATE}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10 c17">Approval seeking, accommodating, kowtowing , yesman, yaklike </span><span class="c37 c17 c25">Consider being less agreeable - let some relationships end. </span></p><p class="c63 c45 c36"><span class="c20 c17">Has your agreeability or &lsquo;need to please&rsquo; lead to problems? Do you have people in your life who suck your time and life energy?</span></p><p class="c63 c45 c36"><span class="c58 c17 c43">Consider this: </span><span class="c58 c17">Is it time to be less agreeable and see if some people naturally leave your life? </span></p><p class="c63 c45 c36"><span class="c17 c20">John Mark Green puts it this way: </span></p><p class="c45 c36 c63"><span class="c17 c32">&lsquo;As you remove toxic people from your life, you free up space and emotional energy for positive, healthy relationships.&rsquo; </span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c118 c40"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c118 c40"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c64">{M:LATE}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17">People pleasing, acquiescence, kowtowing, yielding </span></p><h1 class="c54 c45 c61" id="h.wpb90pz4kowa"><span class="c12">Understand the dangers of being &lsquo;too nice&rsquo;.</span></h1><p class="c63 c45 c36"><span class="c8">The video below presents the dangers of being &lsquo;too nice&rsquo; and features physician and trauma expert Gabor Mate: </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c77 c40"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v%3DRtswQazDSno&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309748415&amp;usg=AOvVaw2gw0cjWjxP9Fyx0fjK9_lV">The Dangers Of Being Too Nice | Dr. Gabor Mate&#769;</a></span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c64">{M:LATE}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c114 c45"><span class="c59 c17">&nbsp;Appeasement, acquiescence, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c45 c61 c147" id="h.56x8klndnnbz"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Understand that </span><span>S</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">atisfaction comes from being </span><span>Authentic</span><span class="c12">.</span></h1><p class="c114 c45"><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;Ponder this quote from </span><span class="c20 c17">Marcel Proust: </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c33 c17 c32">&lsquo;When you work to please others you can&#39;t succeed, but the things you do to satisfy yourself stand a chance of catching someone&#39;s interest.&rsquo; </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c64">{M:LATE}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c114 c45"><span class="c59 c17">&nbsp;Appeasement, acquiescence, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing &nbsp;</span><span class="c12">Understand the Damaging Impacts of &lsquo;People Pleasing&rsquo;.</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c20 c17">Annie Tanasugarn PhD lists the psychological consequences of &lsquo;people pleasing&rsquo; behavior. &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c20 c17">Which of these behaviors apply to you?</span></p><ul class="c41 lst-kix_3vtuzpxtsv4p-0 start"><li class="c48 c45 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c17 c32">A sense of </span><span class="c17 c32"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.psychologytoday.com/au/basics/guilt&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309751423&amp;usg=AOvVaw2f8GmyN-7YIN5A-_U4xz19">guilt</a></span><span class="c17 c32">&nbsp;and </span><span class="c17 c32"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.psychologytoday.com/au/basics/embarrassment&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309751597&amp;usg=AOvVaw3Q_n6vpS4hffOAUHIHSwsI">shame</a></span></li><li class="c45 c24 c48 li-bullet-0"><span class="c17 c32">Low self-worth or </span><span class="c17 c32"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.psychologytoday.com/au/basics/self-esteem&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309751834&amp;usg=AOvVaw2Unq6P9Rdx9Ml9CxWeJfpy">self-esteem</a></span></li><li class="c48 c45 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c33 c17 c32">Wondering who the true you really is </span></li><li class="c48 c45 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c33 c17 c32">Overwhelm due to over-obligation</span></li><li class="c48 c45 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c33 c17 c32">Difficulty in making decisions </span></li><li class="c48 c45 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c33 c17 c32">Difficulty making &amp; maintaining boundaries</span></li></ul><p class="c119 c45"><span class="c17 c40">Adapted from: How People-Pleasing Behavior Affects Self-Worth </span><span class="c17 c40"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.psychologytoday.com/au/contributors/annie-tanasugarn-phd-cctsa&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309752694&amp;usg=AOvVaw2l8YxD3brqGLzefSPdR_fF">Annie Tanasugarn Ph.D.</a></span><span class="c17 c52">, </span><span class="c71 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.psychologytoday.com/au/blog/understanding-ptsd/2&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309752898&amp;usg=AOvVaw1vnSs-SlRYpAm3C31bbw1P">Psychology Today, Understanding PTSD</a></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c114 c45"><span class="c33 c59 c17">Approval seeking, validation seeking, &nbsp;Appeasement, acquiescence, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing &nbsp; </span></p><h1 class="c114 c45 c61" id="h.4kwzf1mz5vax"><span class="c12">Do you need the constant approval of others?</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">Your Challenge: </span><span class="c8">When you interact with others, notice how you feel inside. Notice &nbsp;when you are trying to get their approval.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c17">Self help author Guy Findley puts it this way:</span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&nbsp;&ldquo;What do I really want, the applause of the crowds or to quietly have my own life? &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c17">Recommended Reference; Guy Findley, </span><span class="c51 c17 c43">The Secret of Letting Go</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c4"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c4"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c4"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c4"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c4"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c64">{M:LATE}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c114 c45"><span class="c33 c59 c17">Appeasement, acquiescence, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing</span></p><p class="c114 c45"><span class="c37 c17 c25">More s</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">trategies to free yourself from pleasing people.</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c114 c45"><span class="c17 c40">T</span><span class="c17 c40">his video by confidence coach Dr Aziz is entitled: &nbsp;&lsquo;Use this to free yourself from approval seeking&rsquo; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c19"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c19"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c19"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c19"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c19"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c64">{M:LATE}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c114 c45"><span class="c59 c17">&nbsp;Appeasement, acquiescence, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing, codependency, compassion fatigue &nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c114 c45"><span class="c12">Understand the difference: &lsquo;Pleasing&rsquo; v&rsquo;s &lsquo;Caring&rsquo;.</span></p><p class="c114 c45"><span class="c17 c40">Are you still confusing genuine &lsquo;caring&rsquo; with &lsquo;people pleasing&rsquo;? </span><span class="c37 c17 c25">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c119 c45"><span class="c58 c36 c17">Debbie Ford stresses this difference:</span><span class="c18 c17">&nbsp;&ldquo;Please remember that pleasing another is not the same as caring for another.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c119 c45"><span class="c58 c36 c17">Recommended Resource: Debbie Ford, </span><span class="c58 c36 c17 c43"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.goodreads.com/work/quotes/586095&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309758246&amp;usg=AOvVaw19Z-O8anRAWn2u_gxvkc7X">The Right Questions</a></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp;
