</span></p><h1 class="c26 c13" id="h.5w17qhn8h9a3"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Have you been &lsquo;programmed&rsquo; to put others first? &nbsp;</span></h1><p class="c119 c45"><span class="c8">Watch out for this programming through social conditioning. Raising your awareness of this is the first step. </span></p><p class="c119 c45"><span class="c58 c17">Christopher Dines in his book &nbsp;</span><span class="c51 c17 c43">Drug Addiction Recovery: The Mindful Way, puts it this way: </span></p><p class="c119 c45"><span class="c17 c32">&ldquo;Many of us have been programmed to put others first; to be of service to others before we serve ourselves.&rdquo; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c45 c119"><span class="c39 c17">Your challenge:</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;Start treating yourself the way you treat others?</span><span class="c17 c32">&nbsp;</span><span class="c17 c40">Give yourself equal priority, service </span><span>and</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;love. &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c119 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c64">{M:LATE}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; </span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c17 c27">People pleasing, fawning, &nbsp;accommodating, kowtowing , yak, yoked,</span></p><h1 class="c99 c61" id="h.tefvdcpv0hce"><span class="c12">Are you still having problems with disagreeable people? </span></h1><p class="c102"><span class="c8">Watch this video by Jordan Peterson:</span></p><p class="c102"><span class="c71 c36 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v%3DBGS2mQpVnWw&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309762540&amp;usg=AOvVaw3xCagDb4Hr-JehmbKfdBpp">STOP Being Exploited - How to Deal with Disagreeable People | Jordan Peterson Motivation</a></span></p><p class="c102 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c102 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c17"></span></p><p class="c102 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c59 c17">Validation seeking , approval seeking, lack of self worth &nbsp;appeasement,acquiescence, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26 c13" id="h.uph9994t2ulp"><span class="c12">See yourself as the magnificent creature you are.</span></h1><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c17 c40">Look inside to find your true beauty and magnificence</span><span class="c17">.</span><span class="c20 c17">&nbsp;Sama Akbar puts it this way: </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c36 c17 c32">&ldquo;Stop trying to find yourself in the opinions of others. You can only meet this magnificent creature in the sacredness of solitude and silence. Trying to define yourself with outside validation is like losing something inside the house and looking for it in the yard.&rdquo; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17">Approval seeking, va</span><span>lidation seeking,</span><span class="c17">&nbsp;kowtowing, yesman, stress, anxiety (mild), worried, withdrawn, over</span><span>&nbsp;</span><span class="c17">sensit</span><span>ive</span><span class="c17">, insecure &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.kzh2fjfdzdeo"><span class="c12">Remember the downside of &lsquo;approval seeking&rsquo;. </span></h1><p class="c97 c1 c134 c169"><span class="c20 c17">Ponder this quote by Paulo Coelho: </span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c33 c17 c32">&ldquo;Stress, anxiety, and depression are caused when we are living to please others.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c70 c39 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c39 c17">Your Challenge:</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">Consider how much of your life is spent in pleasing others.</span></p><p class="c97 c1 c134 c7 c169"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c97 c1 c134 c169 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c97 c1 c134 c169 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c109 c45"><span class="c59 c17">&nbsp;Appeasement, acquiescence, </span><span class="c17">sensitive, stress, insecure, </span><span class="c59 c17">fawn, yes-man, kowtowing &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26 c13" id="h.bksgupukzr3r"><span class="c12">Remember: People-pleasing behavior is self generated.</span></h1><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c43">Your Challenge: </span><span class="c8">Face your people pleasing or approval seeking behavior.</span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c17 c40">Consider the following </span><span>approach</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;</span><span>offered by wellness author </span><span class="c58">Kris Carr</span><span class="c20 c17">: </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c3"><span class="c33 c17 c32">&ldquo;You can&#39;t please everyone. When you&#39;re too focused on living up to other people&#39;s standards, you aren&#39;t spending enough time raising your own. Some people may whisper, complain and judge. But for the most part, it&#39;s all in your head. People care less about your actions than you think. Why? They have their own problems!&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c64"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c64"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c64"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c64"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c64">{M:LATE}</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c59 c17">&nbsp;</span><span class="c59">Validation seeking , approval seeking, </span><span class="c59 c17">Appeasement, acquiescence, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing &nbsp;</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c97 c121 c134 c45 c169 c61" id="h.tjrt8f1ae961"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Remember you are whole</span><span>&nbsp;and</span><span class="c12">&nbsp;complete in yourself.</span></h1><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c17 c40">Understanding that you are autonomous </span><span>and</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;sovereign is a big step forward. Acknowledge that you have rights and not just responsibilities. </span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c17 c40">Con</span><span>sider</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;this </span><span>perspective</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;</span><span>offered</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;by</span><span>&nbsp;writer </span><span class="c58 c36">Nic Sheff</span><span class="c20 c17">: &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c97 c1 c134 c169"><span class="c18 c17">&ldquo;As long as you look for someone else to validate who you are by seeking their approval, you are setting yourself up for disaster. You have to be whole and complete in yourself. No one can give you that. You have to know who you are - what others say is irrelevant.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c97 c1 c134 c169 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c97 c1 c134 c169 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c64"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c64"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c64">{M:LATE}</span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c59 c17">&nbsp;Approval seeking , validation seeking, not authentic, not yourself</span><span class="c59">,</span><span class="c59 c17">&nbsp;lack of self worth appeasement,acquiescence, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26 c13" id="h.8gnho9dg2q5z"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Liking &lsquo;</span><span>W</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">ho </span><span>Y</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">ou </span><span>A</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">re&rsquo; will change everything.</span></h1><p class="c1 c13"><span>Ponder this quote from </span><span class="c58 c36"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.azquotes.com/author/9810-Bryant_H_McGill&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309772507&amp;usg=AOvVaw1Ubdp1E9OcYm3pK0851iZM">Bryant H. McGill</a></span><span class="c20 c17">:</span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c36 c32 c43">&ldquo;</span><span class="c36 c32"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.azquotes.com/quote/998124&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309773005&amp;usg=AOvVaw3CIOD33rg5e3JXZofsJRLv">Don&#39;t change just so people will like you! Like yourself and your relationships will change. There are people who will love you for - YOU.</a></span><span class="c18 c17">&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c70 c39 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c43">Remember:</span><span class="c39 c17">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">By liking yourself you will attract different kinds of people - those who like you for who you really are. That will change everything!</span></p><p class="c114 c45 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c64">{M:LATE}, </span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c59 c17">Appeasement,</span><span class="c59">approval seeking, validation seeking,</span><span class="c59 c17">&nbsp;controlled easily, acquiescence, sensitive, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26 c13" id="h.so0ebt1ly0d9"><span class="c37 c17 c25">&lsquo;People pleasing&rsquo; leads to others controlling you.</span></h1><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c43">Remember</span><span class="c39 c17">&nbsp;this:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;The more you give up your personal autonomy, the more vulnerable you are. Others then have more control of you!</span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c8">&nbsp;Contemplate this quote:</span></p><p class="c42"><span class="c36 c17 c32">&ldquo;The more you try to please people, the more they get control of you and you&#39;ll end up hurting yourself.&rdquo; </span><span class="c17 c32">Chanda Kaushik</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c72"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ======== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c72"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c72"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Approval seeking, appeasement, anxiety, perfectionism, angst, acquiescence, kowtowing, neglecting self, overloaded, avoidant, codependency, </span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.q0co6kyaum6r"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Understand the role of </span><span>A</span><span class="c12">nxiety in &lsquo;needing to please&rsquo;.</span></h1><p class="c97 c146 c134 c45 c79"><span class="c17 c40">People-pleasing is one of t</span><span>he </span><span class="c17 c40">many ways we use to manage anxiety. So we </span><span>need</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;to find </span><span>a</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;</span><span>healthy</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;way to </span><span>manage</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;that </span><span>anxiety</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c36 c17 c40">Psychotherapist Sharon Martin explains it this way</span><span class="c8">:</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c36 c17 c32">&ldquo;People-pleasers and perfectionists often struggle with anxiety. We frequently worry. Our worry is excessive and out of control; we can&rsquo;t shut it off. Our bodies also get stressed</span><span class="c18 c17">.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7 c117"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7 c117"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7 c117"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c64">M:LATE}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c45 c109"><span class="c59 c17">&nbsp;Appeasement, acquiescence, not &nbsp;assertive, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c109 c45"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Can you say &lsquo;NO&rsquo; without feeling guilty?</span></p><p class="c109 c45"><span class="c17 c40">Motivational speaker </span><span class="c17 c40"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.azquotes.com/author/2406-Jack_Canfield&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309779146&amp;usg=AOvVaw3ByzsKM2rihj2XqbZDm-FE">Jack Canfield</a></span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;explains that success in business &amp; life requires saying &lsquo;NO&rsquo; when appropriate:</span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36"><span class="c17 c32">&ldquo;Success depends on getting good at saying no without feeling guilty. You cannot get ahead with your own goals if you are always saying yes to someone else&#39;s projects. You can only get ahead with your desired lifestyle if you are focused on the things that will produce that lifestyle.&rdquo; </span><span class="c17 c32"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.azquotes.com/author/2406-Jack_Canfield&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309780026&amp;usg=AOvVaw2TXRtvkAhFKQ0pzW5l1T9W">Jack Canfield</a></span></p><p class="c168 c45 c61 c7 title" id="h.sbm776rqjfkw"><span class="c12"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c64">A:EARLY}</span><span class="c17 c32">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">&nbsp;Traumatized feeling,</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17">Approval seeking, appeasement &nbsp;</span><span>acquiescence</span><span class="c8">, yielding, kowtowing </span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.yp7hstb4eodg"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Are you emotionally wounded?</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Automatically &lsquo;putting others first&rsquo; can be a sign of a past emotional wound. Not facing this behavior has a downside - it depletes our wellbeing. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">British author Christopher Dines puts it this way: </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c32">&ldquo;People pleasing and putting others first literally diminished my mental, emotional, spiritual and physical well-being. Overwhelmingly, most emotionally wounded people demonstrate this trait. Many of us have been programmed to put others first; to be of service to others before we serve ourselves.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c64">A:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c109 c45"><span class="c59 c17">&nbsp;Appeasement, acquiescence, &nbsp;assertiveness, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing, kind &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c109 c45"><span class="c37 c17 c25">What is th</span><span class="c37 c25">e right</span><span class="c12">&nbsp;reason to be kind?</span></p><p class="c109 c45"><span class="c8">Understand that &lsquo;people pleasing&rsquo; or automatically &lsquo;putting others first&rsquo; is not the best expression of kindness. So check your motivation! Is it truly out of generosity, or for some other reason? </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">Contemplate this better </span><span>reason to</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;be kind </span><span>offered</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;b</span><span class="c58 c17">y </span><span class="c58">author </span><span class="c58 c36">J.M. Coetzee</span><span class="c20 c17">:</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c18 c17">&ldquo;If we are going to be kind, let it be out of simple generosity, not because we fear guilt or retribution.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c64"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c64">{M:LATE}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c42"><span class="c59">Lack of self with , not self confidence, </span><span class="c59 c17">&nbsp;Appeasement, acquiescence, &nbsp;assertiveness, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing, kind &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.k87swk9822dk"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Have you adopted the &lsquo;I&rsquo;m not OK&rsquo; position?</span></h1><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c8">According to Transactional Analysis developed by Eric Bern, we are all born &lsquo;OK&rsquo; &mdash; in other words we feel worthy. However we can later develop feelings that we are &lsquo;not OK&rsquo;, particularly if we have been belittled as a child.</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c39 c17">Reflect on this:</span><span class="c17 c25 c40">&nbsp;</span><span class="c17 c40">Have </span><span class="c8">you adopted the position that other people are OK and you are not. &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c17 c40">Additional explanation about the &lsquo;OK - not OK matrix&rsquo; is available in the graphic and links below </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c71 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.crowe-associates.co.uk/psychotherapy/transactional-analysis/&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309785951&amp;usg=AOvVaw0bOXacSnw_JOIa7QRyR4-0">Transactional Analysis | Crowe Associates</a></span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c33 c132 c75"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c71 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v%3DnKNyFSLJy6o&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309786227&amp;usg=AOvVaw1SZeI_g44f1ypcSP7T72Ia">Transactional Analysis 1: ego states &amp; basic transactions</a></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c197 c17 c120 c40"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c17 c120 c40 c197"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c197 c17 c120 c40"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c197 c17 c120 c40"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c64">{M:LATE}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c59">Neglecting self, lacking self care, fawn, </span><span class="c59 c17">&nbsp;Appeasement, acquiescence, assertiveness (lack of), yes-man, kowtowing, kind &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.8a78yfx90kip"><span class="c12">Are you an &lsquo;over giver&rsquo;?</span></h1><h1 class="c26" id="h.b3zx1myq7gum"><span class="c120 c40">Understand that b</span><span class="c17 c120 c40">y &lsquo;over-giving&rsquo; you may be taken advantage of.</span></h1><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58">There is a</span><span class="c58 c17">&nbsp;&lsquo;Reciprocity Continuum&rsquo; </span><span class="c58">which is presented in the link below. </span><span class="c58 c17">&nbsp;Are you primarily &lsquo;a giver&rsquo; or &lsquo;a taker&rsquo; or something in between</span><span class="c58">? </span><span class="c8">&nbsp;A good balance of giving and taking is best.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c45 c61 c251 title" id="h.h0eoysjx9q6o"><span class="c71 c182 c25 c243"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://thepowermoves.com/give-and-take/&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309787906&amp;usg=AOvVaw1-8LxhtpBtsUvFOqNlZ-9n">Give and Take: Summary &amp; Review + PDF | Power Dynamics&trade;</a></span><span class="c25 c40 c159">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c12"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c14"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c14"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c14"></span></p><p class="c168 c45 c61 c7 title" id="h.ds3yrf98x01a"><span class="c33 c10 c17"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c115 c124"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c115 c124"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c115 c124">{M:DEFINE}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c54 c45"><span class="c33 c10 c17">passive-aggressive. </span></p><h1 class="c125 c45 c61" id="h.7zv2l4u1no34"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Understand &lsquo;</span><span>P</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">assive-</span><span>A</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">ggressive&rsquo; behavior.</span></h1><p class="c97 c105 c45"><span class="c8">Passive-aggressive behavior can manifest in several ways, including:</span></p><ul class="c41 lst-kix_umt5h6jv8952-0 start"><li class="c97 c105 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Blaming others for your own unhappiness</span></li><li class="c97 c105 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Giving someone the silent treatment</span></li><li class="c97 c105 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Speaking negatively about others behind their backs</span></li><li class="c97 c105 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Being consistently unreliable, showing up late, or making &quot;mistakes&quot; on purpose</span></li></ul><p class="c97 c45 c105"><span>Do any of these behaviors sound familiar to you? For more insights, check out the link below (from themindsjournal.com).</span></p><p class="c97 c174 c45"><span class="c185 c285">&nbsp;</span><span class="c71 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://themindsjournal.com/dealing-with-a-passive-aggressive-partner/&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309790329&amp;usg=AOvVaw24mPGTxf_zR_g0FyILppNW">12 Characteristics Of Passive Aggression</a></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c97 c45 c7 c174"><span class="c33 c185 c17"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c5"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c115 c124">{A:DEFINE}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c74">passive-aggressive, anger,annoyance, avoidance</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.pbn3vkh7fpxs"><span class="c12">What is passive Aggressive Behavior? </span></h1><p class="c62 c56 c45"><span class="c8">Understand &lsquo;passive-aggressive&rsquo; behavior. Passive-aggressive behavior involves expressing negative feelings, resentment, or hostility in an indirect manner rather than confronting them openly. Instead of addressing issues directly, individuals with passive-aggressive tendencies may engage in subtle actions that convey their dissatisfaction. </span></p><p class="c62 c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c62 c56 c45"><span class="c8">This can include procrastination, stubbornness, sarcasm, giving the silent treatment, or intentionally underperforming on tasks. </span></p><p class="c62 c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c62 c56 c45"><span class="c8">The key characteristic of passive-aggressive behavior is the incongruity between a person&#39;s outward actions and their inner feelings, leading to indirect expressions of frustration or opposition that can create confusion and tension in relationships.</span></p><p class="c62 c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.p9arwkqyxxeh"><span class="c12">Do you deal with Conflict in a &lsquo;Passive Aggressive&rsquo; way?</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Interpersonal conflicts are an inevitable part of life. However, without the skill to effectively express our frustrations, resolving these conflicts becomes challenging. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">When we are unable to achieve a satisfactory outcome or process our emotions constructively, the feelings of annoyance or anger don&rsquo;t simply disappear; instead, they linger, partially repressed. This unresolved tension simmers beneath the surface, creating the potential for a future explosive reaction. This pattern of behavior is often referred to as &quot;passive-aggressiveness.&quot;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c161 c36 c120"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c54 c45"><span class="c10">P</span><span class="c10 c17">assive-aggressive, suppres</span><span class="c10">sing emotions, </span><span class="c33 c10 c17">&nbsp;emotional dysregulation, passive, timid, avoidance, </span></p><h1 class="c45 c61 c125" id="h.svxhrvfxtid3"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Realize that suppressed anger will eventually surface!</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">Strangely, the only way to control emotions is to &lsquo;let them out&rsquo;. This does not mean that we rage at inappropriate moments. Instead, we can recognise and process emotions as they arise. That&#39;s the ideal! We do this &lsquo;emotion processing&rsquo; as soon as practical after the event. Then we don&#39;t become a &lsquo;Mount Vesuvius&rsquo; with occasional huge eruptions. Nor are we a &lsquo;toxic waste dump&rsquo; which quietly leaks toxicity to those nearby. &nbsp;</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c161 c36 c120"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c54 c45"><span class="c8">passive-aggressive, emotional dysregulation, passive, timid, avoidance, shy</span></p><h1 class="c125 c45 c61" id="h.8e27ubg5egzl"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Realize that suppressed anger will cause damage!</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">Vera Peiffer in her book </span><span class="c39 c17">More Positive Thinking; How to create a better future for yourself</span><span class="c8">, explains the differing approaches to handling emotions (such fear and anger) in the following way:</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c33 c17 c32">&ldquo;A person who explodes is a person who allows resentment to build up, and that means that he has not had the courage to deal with small annoying events as and when they cropped up. The inability to tackle upsetting issues head-on as and when they occur allows grievances to accumulate and grow into a bundle of dynamite which is ignited by the smallest spark.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c161 c36 c120"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c54 c45"><span class="c33 c10 c17">passive-aggressive, emotional dysregulation, passive, timid, avoidance, </span></p><h1 class="c125 c45 c61" id="h.2z1e7z8jmggc"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Start dealing with suppressed emotions like anger</span><span>.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Consider</span><span class="c39 c17">&nbsp;this </span><span class="c43">approach</span><span class="c39 c17">:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;take small steps to express yourself. Speak up more confidently with friends. Express your likes and dislikes. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">The next step is talking about matters where there will be disagreements - for example who is &lsquo;the best&rsquo; sports team or actor. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>C</span><span class="c17 c40">onsider researching more</span><span>&nbsp;about this topic </span><span class="c8">for yourself. Consider a course on emotional intelligence. Learn how to optimally release your emotions.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>Recommended</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;</span><span>R</span><span class="c17 c40">esource: </span><span>Free ebook </span><span class="c8">from UltimateQuest.org </span></p><h2 class="c45 c260" id="h.sp1x6ntavvi0"><span class="c39 c268">Emotional Intelligence -</span><span class="c33 c268 c36 c40">THE BOOK</span></h2><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c171 c40"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c72"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c72"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c54 c45"><span class="c10 c17">passive-aggressive, acquiescence, anger, passive, timid, avoidant, not assertive, aggressive </span></p><p class="c54 c45"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Understand that </span><span class="c37 c25">A</span><span class="c12">ssertive behavior is the &lsquo;middle ground&rsquo; </span></p><p class="c54 c45"><span class="c58 c17">Are you generally over-agreeable, but sometimes you become quite annoyed or aggressive? This is a form of passive-aggressive behavior. It either leads to conflict or inner dissatisfaction. So </span><span class="c58">what&#39;s</span><span class="c20 c17">&nbsp;the answer? </span></p><p class="c54 c45"><span class="c58 c43">Consider this approach: </span><span class="c20 c17">Instead of alternating between being passive and aggressive, try a middle path instead. </span></p><p class="c125 c45"><span class="c58 c43">Your Challenge</span><span class="c58 c17 c43">:</span><span class="c58 c17 c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c58 c17">Aim for</span><span class="c58 c17">&nbsp;the</span><span class="c58 c17 c25">&nbsp;&lsquo;</span><span class="c20 c17">middle ground&rsquo; of being &lsquo;assertive&rsquo;.</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c73 c58 c17 c25"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c125 c45"><span class="c8">passive-aggressive, acquiescence, anger, assertiveness, annoyed </span></p><h1 class="c54 c45 c61" id="h.11si5id"><span class="c12">Communicate more assertively using &lsquo;I statements&rsquo;</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c58">Here is a way to communicate more assertively. </span><span class="c20 c17">This technique involves using more &lsquo;first person&rsquo; or &lsquo;I statements&rsquo; in your conversation.</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c20 c17">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c43">Practice this technique:</span><span class="c58">&nbsp;</span><span class="c58 c17">Here</span><span class="c58 c17">&nbsp;is an example</span><span class="c20 c17">&nbsp;of how to use the &ldquo;I message technique&rdquo;:</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c17 c25">Say this:</span><span class="c20 c17">&nbsp;&ldquo;When you &hellip;. &nbsp; I felt &hellip;.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c17 c25">Then add:</span><span class="c20 c17">&nbsp;&ldquo;In the future, I would prefer that you&hellip; &nbsp;&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c17 c43">Here is how it works: </span><span class="c20 c17">This style of wording helps the other person realize how you interpreted their words or actions. They are now more aware of your wishes or desires. It also provides them the opportunity to clarify their own intentions. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c20 c17">Give this &lsquo;I statements&rsquo; technique a good try. </span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c86 c40"></span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c86 c40"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c86 c40"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c86 c40"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c54 c45"><span class="c8">passive-aggressive, not assertive, appeasement, anger, controlled, kowtowing, yes-man</span></p><h1 class="c45 c61 c206" id="h.20xfydz"><span class="c12">Try assertive conversation using this &lsquo;5 Step Plan&rsquo;. </span></h1><p class="c206 c45"><span class="c58">Here are 5 steps to more assertive communication:</span></p><ol class="c41 lst-kix_qqxsykonjxfg-0 start" start="1"><li class="c45 c79 c24 c186 li-bullet-0"><span class="c20 c17">Open the conversation in a positive way. </span></li><li class="c186 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c20 c17">Have a clear goal and stick to the specific issue.</span></li><li class="c186 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c20 c17">Don&#39;t criticize the personality of the other person.</span></li><li class="c186 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c20 c17">Stick to &ldquo;I statements&rdquo; - e.g. &ldquo;I felt X because of Y&rdquo;.</span></li><li class="c206 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c20 c17">Communicate your preferred plan or requested changes.</span></li></ol><p class="c206 c45"><span class="c58 c43">Your Challenge:</span><span class="c58">&nbsp;</span><span class="c58 c17">Start practicing this </span><span class="c58">technique</span><span class="c20 c17">&nbsp;in a non threatening situation e.g. with friends and slowly build your confidence. </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c54 c45"><span class="c8">passive-aggressive, assertive appeasement, not assertive </span></p><h1 class="c45 c61 c292" id="h.302dr9l"><span class="c12">Become more assertive by using these 3 steps.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c17">These are 3 simple steps to being more assertive:</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><ul class="c41 lst-kix_xb3n8yp3aape-0 start"><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c20 c17">Know what you want.</span></li><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c20 c17">Ask for what you want.</span></li><li class="c80 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c20 c17">Negotiate to get what you want.</span></li></ul><p class="c80 c45"><span class="c58 c43">Your Challenge:</span><span class="c58">&nbsp;</span><span class="c58 c17">Remember these 3 key steps to more </span><span class="c58">assertive</span><span class="c58 c17">&nbsp;</span><span class="c58">behavior</span><span class="c58 c17">. </span><span class="c58">Sl</span><span class="c20 c17">owly start using them in practice. Start with low risk situations e.g. with friends. &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c86 c40"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c86 c40"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c74">passive-aggressive, hurt &nbsp;easily, avoidance, not assertive &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c62 c177 c45"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Do you </span><span class="c37 c36 c17 c25">express your frustration or &lsquo;hurt&rsquo; indirectly?</span><span class="c8 c36">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c62 c116 c45"><span class="c20 c36 c17">If you express your frustration indirectly rather than overtly you may be passive-aggressive.</span></p><p class="c62 c116 c45 c7"><span class="c20 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c62 c116 c45"><span class="c58 c36">&nbsp;</span><span class="c58 c36 c17 c25">Consider this carefully: </span><span class="c58 c36 c17">Do you make cutting remarks under your breath or have those silent thoughts? Maybe you aim to subtly get back at the other person? For example, do you consider withholding something the other person wants.</span><span class="c20 c17">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c62 c116 c45"><span class="c20 c17">All these responses indicate a passive-aggressive tendency. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c54 c45"><span class="c17">passive-aggressive, appeasement, assertive, hurt, defensive</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.kvks45fz4m6"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Has your </span><span>L</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">ack of </span><span>B</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">oundaries </span><span>L</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">ed to </span><span>P</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">assive-</span><span>A</span><span class="c12">ggression? </span></h1><p class="c62 c116 c45"><span class="c58 c17">A common cause of passive-aggressive behavior is our failure to set clear boundaries. Research professor </span><span class="c36 c17 c40">Bren&eacute; Brown explains it this way:</span></p><p class="c11"><span class="c18 c17">&ldquo;When we fail to set boundaries and hold people accountable, we feel used and mistreated. This is why we sometimes attack who they are, which is far more hurtful than addressing a behavior or a choice.&rdquo; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c11 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c11"><span class="c58 c36">Recommended Resource:</span><span class="c36 c32">&nbsp;</span><span class="c58 c36 c17">Bren&eacute; Brown, </span><span class="c58 c36 c17 c43">The Gifts of Imperfection </span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c86 c40"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c74">passive-aggressive, avoiding conflict &nbsp;</span><span class="c17 c25 c74">&nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c62 c56 c45 c61" id="h.1f7o1he"><span>Understand w</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">hy you </span><span>become</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">&nbsp;&lsquo;passive-aggressive&rsquo;</span><span>.</span></h1><p class="c1 c62"><span class="c8">Passive aggression results from a fear of conflict. We are scared of expressing our annoyance or anger directly. &nbsp;Usually we haven&rsquo;t been taught the right skills. So, we don&#39;t know how to express our anger in a healthy way. &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c62 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c62"><span class="c8">For example, we might have been brought up to believe that anger is frightening, or just not acceptable. </span></p><p class="c1 c62 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c58">Life coach Oli Anderson offers a simple solution:</span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&nbsp;&ldquo;Unleash in the right time and place before you explode at the wrong time and place.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; HIGH </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c74">passive-aggressive, &nbsp;avoiding conflict </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c12">Acknowledge your suppressed anger!</span></p><p class="c62 c116 c45"><span class="c20 c36 c17">Reflect on your pattern of &lsquo;simmering anger&rsquo; or what&rsquo;s termed &ldquo;passive-aggressive&rdquo; behavior. It&#39;s important to face this behavior and recognize the consequences. </span></p><p class="c62 c116 c45"><span class="c58 c36 c17 c43">Your challenge:</span><span class="c58 c36 c17">&nbsp;T</span><span class="c58 c36">h</span><span class="c58 c36 c17">e challenge is </span><span class="c58 c36">straightforward: Acknowledge the issue and f</span><span class="c20 c36 c17">ind a better way of expressing yourself! &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c62 c177 c45"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; HIGH </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c74">P</span><span class="c17 c74">assive-aggressive, suppressing emotions, hurt easily &nbsp; </span><span class="c17">&nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c62 c177 c45 c61" id="h.thw4kt"><span class="c12">How honest are you about your feelings?</span></h1><p class="c62 c116 c45"><span class="c20 c17">Are you able to express your feelings openly? </span></p><p class="c62 c116 c45"><span class="c58 c17 c43">Try this exercise today:</span><span class="c58 c17">&nbsp;Notice your personal interactions with others. Look a little more closely at your feelings and </span><span class="c58">your</span><span class="c58 c17">&nbsp;</span><span class="c58">expression of</span><span class="c20 c17">&nbsp;them. </span></p><p class="c62 c116 c45"><span class="c58">In particular, assess</span><span class="c20 c17">&nbsp;whether you feel angry, annoyed or hurt? Were you able to express these feelings appropriately? Or instead, did you suppress a considerable part of how you felt? &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c62 c45 c116"><span class="c58 c17 c43">Consider this: </span><span class="c20 c17">The suppression of your true feelings may predispose to passive-aggression. Be honest about any tendency you have in this regard. </span></p><p class="c62 c116 c45"><span class="c58 c17">Admitting the issue exist</span><span class="c58">s is the first step to overcoming it. </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c86 c40"></span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c86 c40"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; HIGH</span></p><p class="c62 c45 c287"><span class="c17 c74">Suppressing emotions, passive-aggressive, </span><span class="c74">repressed</span><span class="c17 c74">&nbsp;</span><span class="c74">emotions, </span><span class="c17 c74">&nbsp;</span><span class="c74">emotional regulation, </span><span class="c17 c74">&nbsp;stress</span></p><p class="c62 c56 c45"><span class="c12">Understand that suppressed emotions will surface.</span></p><p class="c62 c56 c45"><span class="c17 c40">Our feelings &amp; emotions cannot be denied. They will eventually surface. &nbsp;P</span><span class="c8">assive aggressive behavior is one way we release our suppressed frustration. &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c62 c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c62"><span class="c17 c40">Davidji, a stress management expert, explains </span><span>&nbsp;the issue </span><span class="c8">this way:</span></p><p class="c62 c116 c45"><span class="c39 c17">&nbsp;</span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&ldquo;Suppressing emotions is as difficult as holding a balloon under water. Instead of keeping them hidden, you are likely to express them inadvertently by benign snide, sarcastic, snarky, retaliatory, biting, harsh, or downright mean to people who had nothing to do with your initial frustration.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c1"><span>Recommended Resource: </span><span class="c17 c40">Davidji, </span><span class="c70 c39 c17">Destressifying: The Real-World Guide to Personal Empowerment, Lasting Fulfillment, and Peace of Mind</span></p><h1 class="c16 c61 c7" id="h.3dhjn8m"><span class="c12"></span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c16"><span class="c17 c74">passive-aggressive, assertive, avoidance, acquiescence, appeasement, approval </span><span class="c74">seeking</span><span class="c17 c74">, controlled, annoyed</span><span class="c74">, </span><span class="c33 c17 c74">anger, </span></p><h1 class="c16 c61" id="h.1smtxgf"><span class="c12">Practice saying &lsquo;NO&rsquo; more often!</span></h1><p class="c16"><span class="c8">Learn to say &lsquo;NO&rsquo; skillfully &amp; respectfully. This skill is part of &lsquo;assertive communication&rsquo;.</span></p><p class="c16"><span class="c43">Consider t</span><span class="c39 c17">his </span><span class="c43">approach</span><span class="c39 c17">:</span><span class="c39 c17 c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">If you have a hard time turning down requests, practice saying these words: &quot;No, I can&#39;t do that now.&quot; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c16"><span class="c39 c17">Remember:</span><span class="c17 c25 c40">&nbsp;</span><span class="c17 c40">Be direct. Don&#39;t hesitate in </span><span>your</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;reply. If an explanation is appropriate, keep it brief. </span></p><p class="c16 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c62 c177 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c74">Passive-aggressive, not assertive, avoiding conflict, not being yourself, communication &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c16"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Rehearse what you</span><span class="c37 c25">&nbsp;really</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">&nbsp;want to say</span><span class="c37 c25">&nbsp;for a better result.</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c16"><span class="c8">If you practice what you really want to say to another, this can really help your delivery. You may even want to write it out first, as a script. Then practice saying it out-loud. </span></p><p class="c16"><span class="c43">Your challenge: </span><span class="c17 c40">Try role-playing: </span><span class="c8">Ask a friend or colleague to help with this rehearsal. Ask them for helpful feedback too.</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17">Passive aggression</span><span class="c17 c74">, communication, not assertive, avoiding conflict, timid </span><span class="c17 c25 c74">&nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c1 c61 c7" id="h.2rrrqc1"><span class="c12"></span></h1><h1 class="c1 c61" id="h.wwr5rm3ofeei"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Become more direct in</span><span>&nbsp;asking for what you want</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c20 c36 c17">Do you hint at what you want rather than asking for what you want directly? </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c36">Understand that b</span><span class="c20 c36 c17">eing indirect or timid in your communication is inefficient. This may ultimately cause more conflict than benefit.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c43">Your challenge</span><span class="c58 c17 c43">:</span><span class="c20 c36 c17">&nbsp;Practice voicing your wants and needs. Do this more clearly, directly and respectfully. Practice this skill and assess your progress.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c90 c40"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c90 c40"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17">Passive aggressive</span><span class="c17 c74">, controlled, resentful, juvenile view , neurotic,</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Does this description of </span><span class="c37 c25">P</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">assive</span><span class="c37 c25">-A</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">ggression fit you?</span><span class="c12">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">This is how </span><span class="c36 c17 c40">Henry Cloud, a self-help author, describes passive aggressive people</span><span class="c8">:</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c36 c17 c32">&ldquo;These people resist demands by indirect tactics. They will not take responsibility for their own choices; instead, they turn around and blame someone else for making them do it. Or they will agree to do things that they don&rsquo;t really want to do, and then gripe about the person behind her back.&rdquo; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c97 c56 c134 c45 c79 c36"><span>Does this sound like you? </span><span class="c36">Be honest with yourself as nothing changes until we have awareness of what we are doing and are willing to change. Are you willing to make changes?</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c36">Resource: </span><span class="c58 c36 c17">Henry Cloud, </span><span class="c58 c36 c17 c43"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.goodreads.com/work/quotes/801115&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309818610&amp;usg=AOvVaw0czGXxv0_stSJ53LQYG8Gu">Changes That Heal: The Four Shifts That Make Everything Better&hellip;And That Anyone Can Do</a></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c51 c36 c17 c43"></span></p><p class="c97 c56 c134 c45 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c104 c61" id="h.gje85fzcojbx"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Do you regularly use the word </span><span>&ldquo;</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">but</span><span>&rdquo;</span><span class="c12">?</span></h1><p class="c29"><span class="c20 c36 c17">Are you weaponizing your use of the word &ldquo; but&rdquo;?</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c20 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c58 c36 c17">Here are some examples of how the word &lsquo;but&rsquo; can be a putdown.</span></p><ul class="c41 lst-kix_tdi2ayfraj6-0 start"><li class="c29 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c17 c40">That is a nice outfit </span><span class="c39 c17">but</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;it would look better if you lost weight.</span></li><li class="c29 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c58 c36 c17">I love your home, </span><span class="c58 c36 c17 c43">but</span><span class="c20 c36 c17">&nbsp;isn&rsquo;t it a little dark?</span></li><li class="c29 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c58 c36 c17">That&rsquo;s a great idea, </span><span class="c58 c36 c17 c43">but </span><span class="c20 c36 c17">do you think you are really up to it? </span></li></ul><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c20 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c58 c36 c43">Your challenge:</span><span class="c58 c36">&nbsp;Assess the ways </span><span class="c58 c36 c17">you use &nbsp;the word </span><span class="c58 c36">&ldquo;</span><span class="c58 c36 c17">BUT</span><span class="c58 c36">&rdquo;</span><span class="c58 c36 c17">&nbsp;on people? Are you subtly trying to make them feel bad? This can, for example, be an </span><span class="c58 c36">example</span><span class="c58 c36 c17">&nbsp;of </span><span class="c58 c36">p</span><span class="c58 c36 c17">assive </span><span class="c58 c36">aggressive</span><span class="c58 c36 c17">&nbsp;</span><span class="c58 c36">behavior</span><span class="c20 c36 c17">. </span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c20 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c97 c79 c36 c7 c103"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c97 c103 c79 c36"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c97 c103 c79 c36"><span class="c17">passive aggressive</span><span class="c17 c74">, communication, timid, passive, insecure, neurotic &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c97 c103 c79 c36 c61" id="h.ggrglrnxe5lf"><span class="c12">Be willing to clearly communicate what you want.</span></h1><p class="c29"><span class="c20 c36 c17">Without clear communication you won&#39;t get your needs met and you may resort to passive aggressive behavior. </span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c20 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c20 c36 c17">&nbsp;Shannon L. Alder, inspirational author and life coach puts it this way:</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c20 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c18 c17">&ldquo;You cannot become a peacemaker without communication. Silence is a passive-aggressive grenade thrown by insecure people that want war, but they don&rsquo;t want the accountability of starting it.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c97 c103 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c97 c103 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c62 c45 c7 c177"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;HIGH &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c97 c103 c79 c36"><span class="c8 c36">Passive aggressive, not assertive, avoiding conflict, resentful, gossiping, &nbsp;timid, venting </span></p><h1 class="c97 c103 c79 c36 c61" id="h.qehr5j1zuhtl"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Do you attack another rather than address the problem?</span><span class="c12">&nbsp;</span></h1><p class="c29"><span class="c58 c36 c17">Setting poor boundaries can be the underlying cause of your problem. It was your choice to not explain your needs </span><span class="c58 c36">clearly</span><span class="c36 c17 c58">. You failed to set an</span><span class="c58 c36">d</span><span class="c58 c36 c17">&nbsp;</span><span class="c58 c36">assert</span><span class="c58 c36 c17">&nbsp;</span><span class="c58 c36">your</span><span class="c20 c36 c17">&nbsp;boundaries. &nbsp; </span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c20 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c36 c17 c40">Bren&eacute; Brown a researcher and educator </span><span class="c58 c36 c17">explains it this way:</span></p><p class="c97 c56 c134 c127 c79 c36"><span class="c18 c17">&quot;When we fail to set boundaries and hold people accountable, we feel used and mistreated. This is why we sometimes attack who they are, which is far more hurtful than addressing a behavior or a choice.&quot; </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c19"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c19"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c19"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c97 c56 c134 c127 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c97 c103 c79 c36"><span class="c20 c36 c17">Passive aggressive, negative narcissist,</span></p><h1 class="c97 c103 c79 c36 c61" id="h.92kduestizlj"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Are you secretly controlling the behavior of others? </span></h1><p class="c29"><span class="c58 c36 c17">Passive aggressive behavior can trigger anger in others. Are </span><span class="c58 c36">you secretly</span><span class="c58 c36 c17">&nbsp;</span><span class="c58 c36">manipulating </span><span class="c20 c36 c17">that? &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c20 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c58 c36 c17">Author </span><span class="c17 c40">Signe Whitson explains </span><span>passive-aggression</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;this way:</span></p><p class="c65 c45"><span class="c36 c17 c32">&ldquo;&hellip;</span><span class="c17 c18">the passive aggressive individual gets others to act out their hidden anger for them. This ability to control someone else&rsquo;s emotional response makes the passive aggressive person feel powerful. He/she becomes the puppeteer&mdash;the master of someone else&rsquo;s universe and the controller of their behavior.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c45 c7 c65"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c65 c45"><span class="c58">Resource: </span><span class="c58 c17">Signe Whitson</span><span class="c58 c17">, </span><span class="c58 c17 c43"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.goodreads.com/work/quotes/6325027&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309825795&amp;usg=AOvVaw20x3gIi5eIxNcrKSUAS4So">The Angry Smile: The Psychology Of Passive Aggressive Behavior In Families, Schools, And Workplaces</a></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c151 c45 c61 c7 title" id="h.3s49zyc"><span class="c33 c10 c232"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c74">acquiescence, yes-man, kowtowing, not assertive, timid</span></p><h1 class="c16 c61" id="h.279ka65"><span class="c12">Do you say &lsquo;YES&rsquo; when you should really say &lsquo;NO&rsquo;?</span></h1><p class="c16"><span class="c8">&nbsp;Be honest: How often do you give-in and say &lsquo;yes&rsquo;? Do you do this to &lsquo;avoid a fuss&rsquo; or keep things going smoothly? &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c16"><span class="c39 c17">Reflect on this:</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;Have you been saying &lsquo;yes&rsquo; to everyone; except to yourself and your true needs?</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c36 c17">To help you say &lsquo;NO&rsquo;, consider this quote from the billionaire business magnate </span><span class="c20 c17">Warren Buffett: </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c36 c17 c32">&ldquo;The difference between successful people and really successful people is that really successful people say no to almost everything.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c210 c17"></span></p><p class="c97 c103 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c129 c77 c36 c25"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c16 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c33 c10 c17">Acquiescence, agreeable, friendly, kind , humble, not assertive, not assertive, yielding, assured, communicating, negotiating, self confident </span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.giq1ptypx68i"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Understand the pros </span><span>&amp;</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">&nbsp;cons of being &lsquo;</span><span>A</span><span class="c12">greeable&rsquo;</span></h1><p class="c16"><span class="c17 c40">Viktor Sander</span><span class="c17 c32">&nbsp;</span><span class="c17 c40">a relationship expert outlines the benefits of being more agreeable in this way:</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c33 c17 c32">&ldquo;Research shows that agreeable people have more stable, satisfying, and intimate friendships compared than less agreeable people. Their tendency to be polite, kind, and humble makes them likable. Agreeableness is also linked with good mental health</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c17 c40">But </span><span>understand</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;there are considerable downsides to being consistently over agreeable. For example, those who are too agreeable often have poor boundaries which leads to being taken advantage of. This in turn can lead to exhaustion and resentment.</span></p><p class="c1"><span>Resource: Article by Viktor Sander B.Sc., B.A.: </span><span class="c32">&nbsp;</span><span class="c71"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://socialself.com/blog/how-to-be-agreeable/&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309830405&amp;usg=AOvVaw1laOLvpwzbrE9A0GDUkbzm">How To Be More Agreeable For People Who Like To Disagree</a></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c54 c45"><span class="c33 c10 c17">acquiescence, passive aggressive, assertiveness, sensitive appeasement, controlled, kowtowing, self-depreciation, yes-man, insecure, neurotic &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c1 c61" id="h.47hxl2r"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Understand the benefits of being </span><span>A</span><span class="c12">ssertive.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Being assertive involves expressing your thoughts, feelings and needs directly. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>Understand</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;that you can be assertive and still be polite. You respect the rights of others and expect the same from them.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Assertive communication can help you feel understood and decreases misunderstanding and conflict long term. As you become more assertive you will gain courage and feel more confident. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Doreen Virtue a motivational speaker and author puts it this way:</span></p><p class="c97 c1 c36"><span class="c33 c17 c32">&quot;Once you have a major success with assertiveness, you learn that it&#39;s a much healthier path than being a doormat to the insensitive folks. You gain respect for yourself, have more time for your priorities, and develop authentic and healthier relationships.&quot; </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c62 c177 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c74">A</span><span class="c17 c74">cquiescence, </span><span class="c74">appeasement, approval seeking, </span><span class="c17 c74">passive, timid, self depreciation, kowtowing, timid, wavering, yes-man, insecure, </span></p><h1 class="c1 c61" id="h.36ei31r"><span class="c12">Consider the cost of &lsquo;giving in&rsquo; or being overly agreeable.</span></h1><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c8">Reflect on the following:</span></p><ul class="c41 lst-kix_f1s7kyqxhix6-0 start"><li class="c56 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Do you give-in too easily to others? </span></li><li class="c56 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Do you spend excessive time and energy helping others? </span></li></ul><p class="c56 c45 c7 c24"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c45 c223"><span class="c17 c40">Consider the hidden costs of your acquiescence or giving-in to the wishes of others.</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c223 c45"><span class="c8">What goals and dreams do you have personally? Do you lack the time and energy to pursue these because you give-in to the wishes of others? </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c83 c45"><span class="c59 c17">Acquiescence, avoiding conflict, appeasement, juvenile controlled, kowtowing, &nbsp;yes-man, avoidance, yoked</span></p><h1 class="c1 c61" id="h.j8sehv"><span class="c12">Have you said &lsquo;NO&rsquo;, but fear this will displease others?</span></h1><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Do you really need permission or approval from others? While this may have applied as a young child, is it appropriate now?</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Consider this approach:</span><span>&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">As adults we need to take charge of our lives and bear the responsibility for our choices. It&#39;s part of growing up. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>A</span><span class="c8">uthor, Geoffrey F. Albert puts it this way:</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c32">&ldquo;When you take charge of your life, there is no longer a need to ask permission of other people or society at large. When you ask permission, you give someone veto power over your life.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c62 c177 c45 c7"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c74">Acquiescence, appeasing</span><span class="c74">, </span><span class="c33 c17 c74">not assertive, avoiding conflict, &nbsp;kowtowing, timid, wavering, yes-man </span></p><h1 class="c1 c61" id="h.1ljsd9k"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Can you use the word &lsquo;NO&rsquo; just by itself?</span></h1><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c73 c17 c25 c40"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c20 c17">Anne Lamott a writer &amp; activist makes it quite clear:</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c33 c17 c32">&ldquo;&lsquo;No&rsquo; is a complete sentence&rdquo;. </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c20 c17">But that&#39;s something that some people just can&#39;t seem to say. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c73 c17 c25 c40"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Your challenge</span><span class="c39 c17">:</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;How often can you politely say &lsquo;No&rsquo; or &lsquo;No thank you&rsquo; without elaborating? </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c73 c17 c25 c40"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c33 c17 c74">acquiescence, appeasement, aggressive, passive + aggressive, assertive, yesman, controlled, timid, passive </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c74"></span></p><h1 class="c1 c61" id="h.vh7ajmsjl1rg"><span class="c12">Monitor your communication style.</span></h1><p class="c97 c56 c45 c36"><span class="c17 c40">Psychologist Edith Eva Eger explains the various communication styles this way:</span></p><p class="c97 c56 c45 c36"><span class="c33 c17 c32">&quot;To be passive is to let others decide for you. To be aggressive is to decide for others. To be assertive is to decide for yourself. And to trust that there is enough, that you are enough.&quot;</span></p><p class="c97 c56 c45 c36"><span class="c58 c17 c43">&nbsp;</span><span class="c58 c43">Your Challenge</span><span class="c58 c17 c43">:</span><span class="c58 c17 c43">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">Observe your communication style&hellip; </span></p><ul class="c41 lst-kix_vs2md4klr2su-0 start"><li class="c56 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Are you assertive? </span></li><li class="c56 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Are you more passive in response?</span></li><li class="c56 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c17 c40">D</span><span>o</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;you readily feel annoyance or anger arising?</span></li><li class="c56 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c17 c40">D</span><span>o </span><span class="c17 c40">you partially suppress your anger (passive-aggression)? </span></li></ul><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c73 c231 c84 c25"></span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c73 c84 c25 c231"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c83 c45"><span class="c10">A</span><span class="c10 c17">voidan</span><span class="c10">t, </span><span class="c10 c17">acquiescence</span><span class="c10">, </span><span class="c33 c10 c17">appeasement, approval seeking, controlled, self-depreciation, yes-man</span></p><h1 class="c1 c61" id="h.f12umwmujbjw"><span class="c12">Are you downplaying your inner needs? </span></h1><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>Are you avoiding your deep inner needs? </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">American psychiatrist William Glasser </span><span>puts it this way</span><span class="c17 c40">:</span><span class="c17">&nbsp;</span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&ldquo;Too many of us fail to fulfill our needs because we say no rather than yes, and yes when we should say no&rdquo; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Your Challenge</span><span class="c39 c17">:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Work on prioritizing your own needs and dreams.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c62 c177 c45 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c83 c45"><span class="c10 c17">&nbsp;Avoiding conflict, not assertive, acquiescence, appeasement, approval seeking</span><span class="c10">,</span><span class="c33 c10 c17">&nbsp;controlled easily, kowtowing, yes-man, not yourself </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><h1 class="c1 c61" id="h.1d96cc0"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Practice asserting your own rights </span><span>&amp;</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">&nbsp;needs.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">To be happy &amp; healthy you have to assert your rights &amp; needs. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c73 c17 c25 c40"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c17">Motivational speaker Jim Rohn says it </span><span class="c58">this way</span><span class="c58 c17">:</span><span class="c17 c32">&nbsp;</span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&nbsp;&ldquo;The only healthy communication style is assertive communication.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c39 c17">&nbsp;Y</span><span class="c43">o</span><span class="c39 c17">ur Challenge:</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;Practice being more assertive today. Remember, you can do this politely and respectfully!</span><span class="c17">&nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c1 c61 c7" id="h.bis1c0d9hsjy"><span class="c12"></span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c45 c83"><span class="c10">A</span><span class="c10 c17">voiding conflict, kowtowing, yes-man, not assertive, timid, acquiescence, appeasement, </span><span class="c10">approval</span><span class="c33 c10 c17">&nbsp;seeking, not inner &nbsp;peace,</span></p><p class="c83 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><h1 class="c1 c61" id="h.4ha2hnt22ksq"><span class="c12">Inner peace is the ability to cope with conflict.</span></h1><p class="c66 c45 c36"><span class="c36">Mahatma Gandhi, the Indian political and spiritual leader explained Peace this way: </span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36"><span class="c36 c17 c32">&ldquo;Peace is not the absence of conflict, but the ability to cope with it.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c62 c177 c45 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c83 c45"><span class="c10 c17">Avoiding conflict, </span><span class="c10">a</span><span class="c33 c10 c17">cquiescence, appeasement, kowtowing, yes-man, assertive, timid, peace</span></p><h1 class="c1 c61" id="h.7h2qsvlaubeb"><span>Do you tend to &lsquo;give in&rsquo; to avoid </span><span class="c37 c17 c25">conflict?</span></h1><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c3 c36"><span class="c36 c17 c40">Harvard Sociologist </span><span class="c36 c17 c40">Martha Beck explains </span><span class="c36">&lsquo;</span><span class="c36 c17 c40">acquiescence</span><span class="c36">&rsquo;</span><span class="c36 c17 c40">&nbsp;(giving in) and other avoidant behavior this way:</span></p><p class="c3 c36"><span class="c18 c17">&lsquo;When fear makes your choices for you, no security measures on earth will keep the things you dread from finding you.
