But if you can avoid avoidance - if you can choose to embrace experiences out of passion, enthusiasm, and a readiness to feel whatever arises - then nothing, nothing in all this dangerous world, can keep you from being safe.&rsquo; </span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c3 c36"><span class="c20 c36 c17">Quietly ponder these words. </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c20 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c20 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c20 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c74">Acquiescence, appeasement, avoiding conflict, approval seeking &nbsp;yes-man, kowtowing, </span><span class="c74">not boundaries, not assertive, &nbsp;timid</span></p><h1 class="c1 c61" id="h.g4cod772grno"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Practice being </span><span>&lsquo;</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">less agreeable</span><span>&rsquo;</span><span class="c12">.</span></h1><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c73 c17 c25 c40"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Your Challenge</span><span class="c39 c17">:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Practice voicing your opinion. Be willing to disagree with the opinions of others: </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">For example: </span><span class="c8">Practice expressing your preferences eg what restaurant you want to go to, instead of saying &ldquo;I don&rsquo;t mind&rdquo;.</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">Be willing to decline invitations if you need rest or you would rather be doing something else. Tell someone when their comments hurt you, rather than bottling it up. </span><span class="c17">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Maintain your boundaries even if the other person is disappointed. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c74">&nbsp;Powerlessness, disempowered , acquiescence, appeasement , avoiding conflict, yes-man, kowtowing, controlled easily, timid</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.t9az60a382i0"><span class="c12">Are you just giving your power away?</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">Consider th</span><span>e</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;</span><span>wise </span><span class="c17 c40">perspective </span><span>of</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;American novelist </span><span class="c58 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.brainyquote.com/authors/alice-walker-quotes&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309847287&amp;usg=AOvVaw1a_a5BWrUGaCBTM7K2mlSl">Alice Walker</a></span><span class="c58 c17">:</span></p><p class="c3"><span class="c17 c32">&ldquo;The most common way people give up their power is by thinking they don&#39;t have any.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c3 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c3 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c3 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c74">Validation seeking, approval seeking, acquiescence, </span><span class="c74">appeasement</span><span class="c17 c74">, yes-man, kowtowing, self-depreciation, wavering, timid</span></p><h1 class="c96 c45 c61" id="h.wqhk55vei2a7"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Do you care too much about what people think of you? </span></h1><p class="c56 c45 c127 c36"><span class="c58 c36">Ponder the powerful words of Lao Tzu:</span></p><p class="c56 c45 c127 c36"><span class="c36 c32">&nbsp;</span><span class="c18 c17">&ldquo;Care about what other people think and you will always be their prisoner.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c74">acquiescence, appeasement, avoiding conflict, not assertive, yes-man, kowtowing, timid</span></p><h1 class="c45 c36 c61 c122" id="h.gajh88szslmn"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Sometimes b</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">eing less </span><span>A</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">greeable can pay off!</span></h1><p class="c3 c36"><span class="c36 c17 c40">Consider this take on &lsquo;agreeableness&rsquo; from Canadian psychology professor</span><span class="c36 c17 c32">&nbsp;</span><span class="c20 c36 c17">Jordan Peterson: </span></p><p class="c3 c36"><span class="c36 c17 c32">&ldquo;T</span><span class="c17 c32"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.brainyquote.com/quotes/jordan_peterson_926968&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309850103&amp;usg=AOvVaw2lK5m0NWy8K-iPl3cGuhha">here&#39;s a personality trait known as agreeableness. Agreeable people are compassionate and polite. And agreeable people get paid less than disagreeable people for the same job&rdquo;.</a></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c12"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c12"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c74">acquiescence, appeasement, avoiding conflict, not assertive, yes-man, kowtowing, timid, social skills, communication, courage &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c277" id="h.2e2fjqv1p0oo"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Reframe your interactions with </span><span>D</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">isagreeable people.</span></h1><p class="c263"><span class="c8">Spending time with an argumentative and disagreeable person can be frustrating and exhausting. </span></p><p class="c263"><span class="c43">Consider</span><span class="c39 c17">&nbsp;this approach:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Try to to reframe the situation - notice the ways you can develop your skills to stand up for yourself. State your perspective and debate clearly and logically. </span></p><p class="c263"><span class="c8">But only do this if you are physically safe and are not being put in harm&#39;s way by stating your case.</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c45 c61 c7 c151 title" id="h.2s2vf6t2lm8o"><span class="c73 c10 c154 c25"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c73 c154 c25 c40"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c33 c17 c27">Avoiding conflict, &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c12">Do you avoid conflict?</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c17 c40">Does th</span><span>e following</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;behavior sound like you?</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span>&gt; </span><span class="c8">Expressing your opinion feels intimidating or unsettling.</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span>&gt; </span><span class="c8">You find comfort in being known as the &ldquo;nice person&rdquo; at work.</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span>&gt; </span><span class="c17 c40">In relationships you tend to avoid difficult conversations</span><span class="c8">.</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span>&gt; You shift</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;topics, or </span><span>stay</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;in uncomfortable situations instead of addressing concerns directly.</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span>&gt; </span><span class="c8">You deny problems by ignoring or sidestepping them </span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span>&gt; </span><span class="c8">You tend to harbor silent resentment over unresolved issues.</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c8">This behavior is typical of &lsquo;conflict avoidance&rsquo;. </span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c27"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c17 c40">Adapted from: </span><span class="c17 c27">&nbsp;</span><span class="c71 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.healthline.com/health/conflict-avoidance%23characteristics&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309854236&amp;usg=AOvVaw0fEXxtfywidbD7Iqq3n69x">Conflict Avoidance: Why It&#39;s Harmful, How to Overcome It &amp; More</a></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c27"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c27"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c27"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c27"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c27"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c27"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c107 c45"><span class="c10 c36 c17">&nbsp;Avoiding conflict , appeasement, acquiescent , powerlessness, disempowered, passive, &nbsp;yielding, accommodating, approval seeking, kowtowing, timid, </span></p><h1 class="c136 c45 c61" id="h.6fdepl8uvc85"><span>A</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">re you giving away your power by </span><span>A</span><span class="c12">voiding issues?</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">Some people avoid conflict because this might uncover their anger. </span><span>Could</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;this apply to you? </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;Self help author </span><span class="c36 c17 c40">Debbie Ford explains the consequence of </span><span class="c36">avoiding your anger and conflict</span><span class="c36 c17 c40">&nbsp;:</span></p><p class="c107 c45"><span class="c18 c17">&ldquo;If you are fearful about discovering your anger, remember that your power is buried along with it.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c107 c45 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c107 c45"><span class="c58 c36">Resource: </span><span class="c58 c36 c17">Debbie Ford,</span><span class="c58 c36 c17 c43">&nbsp;</span><span class="c58 c36 c17 c43"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.goodreads.com/work/quotes/760609&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309856110&amp;usg=AOvVaw0enpgfcyYtXZOVS-37JDS-">The Dark Side of the Light Chasers: Reclaiming Your Power, Creativity, Brilliance and Dreams</a></span></p><p class="c60 c36 c7"><span class="c5"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c60 c36 c7"><span class="c5"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c74">Avoiding conflict, timid, &nbsp;appeasement, yes man, yielding, kowtowing, comfort seeking </span></p><h1 class="c31 c61" id="h.my717453kmqa"><span class="c12">Do you just want a quiet corner to hide in?</span></h1><p class="c3"><span class="c8">Do you tend to avoid conflict ? Do you understand the hidden consequences? Ponder what this might be for a few moments. </span></p><p class="c3"><span class="c17 c40">World teacher Jiddu Krishnamurti explains the risk of &lsquo;hiding away&rsquo; to avoid conflict:</span></p><p class="c128 c45"><span class="c17 c32">&ldquo;In seeking comfort, we generally find a quiet corner in life where there is a minimum of conflict, and then we are afraid to step out of that seclusion.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c74">&nbsp;Avoiding conflict, </span><span class="c74">Agreable, </span><span class="c33 c17 c74">acquiescence, appeasement, yes man, yielding, kowtowing, Agreeable ,not assertive &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.6pc1hkkbkbf3"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Do you rate yourself as being &lsquo;</span><span>A</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">greeable&rsquo;?</span></h1><p class="c16"><span class="c8">Multiple studies have shown agreeableness to have strong benefits in life.</span></p><p class="c16"><span>Benefits</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;</span><span>of being</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;Agreeable includ</span><span>e</span><span class="c8">: </span></p><p class="c173 c45 c187"><span class="c8">1. Showing care and concern for others. </span></p><p class="c173 c45 c187"><span class="c8">2. Accepting life as it is with an ability to adapt.</span></p><p class="c173 c45 c187"><span class="c8">3. Cultivating positive relationships with others</span></p><p class="c173 c45 c187"><span class="c17 c40">4. Using empathy to coordinate work &amp; </span><span class="c17 c40"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.psychologytoday.com/au/basics/motivation&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309858686&amp;usg=AOvVaw1w58cohU6H-DF2-2w9_CR6">goals</a></span></p><p class="c173 c45 c187"><span class="c8">5. &nbsp;Putting more effort toward quality work.</span></p><p class="c173 c45 c187"><span class="c8">6. Integrating well into social roles and institutions.</span></p><p class="c45 c24 c173"><span class="c8">&nbsp; &nbsp;7. Experiencing more satisfaction in life. </span></p><p class="c173 c45 c24"><span class="c8">Does this agreeable behavior sound like you?</span></p><p class="c173 c45"><span>However, understand</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;t</span><span>hat </span><span class="c17 c40">a major downside of being </span><span>&lsquo;</span><span class="c17 c40">too agreeable</span><span>&rsquo;</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;is a lower assertiveness and a tendency to avoid interpersonal conflict.</span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c173 c45"><span class="c39 c17">Consider this:</span><span class="c17 c25 c40">&nbsp;</span><span>Because</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;you </span><span>do not practice your assertiveness skill, your</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;tendency to avoid conflict can </span><span>make</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;you weaker</span><span>&nbsp;in the long term. &nbsp;</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c74">Avoiding conflict, not yourself, not authentic, &nbsp;not assertive , not &nbsp;self confidence, appeasement, controlled easily, yes man, yielding, kowtowing </span></p><h1 class="c31 c61" id="h.h4e1vixdxqxs"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Are you really saying what you think?</span></h1><p class="c31"><span class="c36">Canadian P</span><span class="c36 c17 c40">sychology professor Jordan Peterson</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;explains the problem of &lsquo;avoidant behavior&rsquo; quite bluntly: </span></p><p class="c31"><span class="c36 c17 c32">&nbsp;&ldquo;If you don&rsquo;t say what you think, then you kill your unborn self.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c31 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c74">Avoiding conflict, assertiveness, appeasement, acquiescence, controlled, yes man, yielding, kowtowing </span></p><h1 class="c31 c61" id="h.5fllkjfueq0l"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Understand how some conflict can be beneficial.</span></h1><p class="c31"><span class="c36">Understand that n</span><span class="c36 c17 c40">ot all conflict should be avoided. </span></p><p class="c31"><span class="c36 c17 c40">Consider this perspective by Benjamin Watson </span></p><p class="c3"><span class="c33 c17 c32">&ldquo;Conflict, when handled correctly, strengthens.&rsquo; Benjamin Watson</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c73 c95 c36 c84 c25"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c73 c95 c36 c84 c25"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c73 c95 c36 c84 c25"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c83 c45"><span class="c74">A</span><span class="c17 c74">void</span><span class="c74">ing conflict</span><span class="c17 c74">, acquiescence, assertive, appeasement, controlled, yes man</span><span class="c74">,</span><span class="c17 c74">&nbsp;yielding, kowtowing</span><span class="c17 c25 c74">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c1 c61 c7" id="h.pkwqa1"><span class="c12"></span></h1><h1 class="c1 c61" id="h.6nvvh0rokcup"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Consider the impact of NOT expressing your feelings</span></h1><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c8">Australian palliative-care nurse Bronnie Ware says the top regrets of the dying include: I wish I&rsquo;d had the courage to express my feelings.</span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c70 c39 c17">Consider this: </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Will you have regrets for not speaking up?</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Will you have some regrets on your death-bed?</span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c110 c45 c36"><span class="c36 c17 c40">Nurse Ware says</span><span class="c36">: </span><span class="c18 c17">&quot;Many people suppressed their feelings in order to keep peace with others. As a result, they settled for a mediocre existence and never became who they were truly capable of becoming. Many developed illnesses relating to the bitterness and resentment they carried as a result.&quot;</span></p><p class="c45 c36 c110"><span class="c39 c36 c17">Your challenge:</span><span class="c36 c17 c40">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8 c36">Find the courage to express your true feelings. Start this on a small scale today. Practice and develop this skill. In this way might avoid long-term regret. </span></p><p class="c31 c7"><span class="c33 c36 c210 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c36 c210 c17"></span></p><p class="c31 c7"><span class="c33 c36 c210 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;(action) </span></p><p class="c83 c45"><span class="c17 c74">A</span><span class="c33 c17 c74">voiding conflict, not assertive &nbsp;acquiescence, appeasement, yes-man, kowtowing, </span></p><h1 class="c31 c61" id="h.1opuj5n"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Being more proactive is </span><span>preferable to avoiding conflict</span><span class="c12">.</span></h1><p class="c31"><span class="c17 c40">Remember, your avoidance of underlying issues </span><span>and</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;</span><span>conflict</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;can be frustrating to others. It can even cause even more conflict</span></p><p class="c135 c45"><span class="c58">Psychologist John Gottman gives this example in marriage:</span><span class="c32">&nbsp;&ldquo;Expressing anger and disagreement - airing a complaint - though rarely pleasant, makes the marriage stronger in the long run than suppressing the complaint.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c135 c45"><span class="c58 c43">Ask yourself: </span><span class="c20 c17">Have you avoided conversations that need to be raised? </span></p><p class="c45 c135"><span class="c58 c43">Consider this approach:</span><span class="c58">&nbsp;</span><span class="c58 c17">Be more proactive instead of </span><span class="c58">conflict</span><span class="c58 c17">&nbsp;avoidance</span><span class="c58">.</span><span class="c58 c17">&nbsp;</span><span class="c58">Consider your</span><span class="c58 c17">&nbsp;long term personal relationships</span><span class="c58">!</span><span class="c20 c17">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c135 c45 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c135 c45 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c135 c45 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c135 c45 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c17 c27">Avoiding conflict , not assertive, timid, not self confidence &nbsp; </span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.1bjcrt9ovt3q"><span>Handled</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">&nbsp;properly, conflict can strengthen us. </span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Understand the benefit of facing our conflicts. It can strengthen us. &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c36 c17 c40">Edmund Burke wrote, </span><span class="c18 c17">&ldquo;He that wrestles with us strengthens our nerves, and sharpens our skill. Our antagonist is our helper.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c36 c17 c40">&nbsp;</span><span class="c36">Resource</span><span class="c36 c17 c40">: </span><span class="c17 c40">Arthur C. Brooks</span><span class="c70 c39 c17">, Love Your Enemies: How Decent People Can Save America from the Culture of Contempt</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c123 c40"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c123 c40"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10 c17">Avoiding conflict, timid, &nbsp;acquiescence, appeasement, not assertive, fawn, jeopardizing relationships, communication &nbsp; </span></p><h1 class="c1 c61" id="h.1302m92"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Tackle a difficult conversation</span><span>: Overcome your Avoidance.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span>Understand that persistently a</span><span class="c8">voiding a difficult conversation can damage your relationship. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Consider this approach:</span><span>&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">Being more direct may not feel natural at first. This is especially so if you dislike conflict. However, it&rsquo;s a valuable skill to learn. So it&#39;s worth practicing and persisting with.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Your Challenge</span><span class="c39 c17">:</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;</span><span>C</span><span class="c17 c40">onfront your </span><span>avoidance</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;</span><span>tendency.</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;Practice being more direct. Explain what you feel and what you want. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c73 c95 c84 c25"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c73 c95 c84 c25"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c73 c84 c25 c95"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c73 c95 c84 c25"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;HIGH &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17">Avoiding conflict, controlled easily, &nbsp;acquiescence, appeasement, not assertive timid, principled </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Learn to articulate what you believe in. &nbsp;</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">It&#39;s important to overcome a tendency to avoid all conflict. Do you now understand why? &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">Consider this </span><span>explanation</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;f</span><span>rom</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;</span><span>C</span><span class="c17 c40">anadian psychology professor</span><span class="c17 c32">&nbsp;</span><span class="c36 c17 c40">Jordan Peterson:</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c18 c17">&ldquo;You have to articulate your own principles, so that you can defend yourself against others&rsquo; taking inappropriate advantage of you, and so that you are secure and safe while you work and play.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c74"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c74">Avoiding conflict</span><span class="c17 c74">, not assertive, &nbsp;yielding, kowtowing, yesman </span></p><h1 class="c1 c61" id="h.gjwwzg5noze"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Visualize being more assertive </span><span>&amp;</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">&nbsp;</span><span>rehearse</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">&nbsp;your </span><span>response</span><span class="c12">. </span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">To help overcome your conflict avoidance, try a visualization technique.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c39 c17 c70"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Consider this approach:</span><span>&nbsp; </span><span class="c17 c40">Visualiz</span><span>e</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;yourself being more assertive in a specific situation or scenario. </span><span>This will help c</span><span class="c8">reate a better version of your response. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>Also consider r</span><span class="c17 c40">ehears</span><span>ing</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;</span><span>your</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;response, as suggested by Stanford professor of psychiatry David Burns: &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c18 c17">&ldquo;Now practice going through this version of the scenario each night until you have mastered it and can fantasize handling the situation effectively and calmly in this manner. This cognitive rehearsal will enable you to program yourself to respond in a more assertive and relaxed way when the actual situation confronts you again.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c36">Resource:</span><span class="c58 c36 c17">&nbsp;</span><span class="c58 c17">David D. Burns, </span><span class="c58 c17 c43"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.goodreads.com/work/quotes/1892311&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309871920&amp;usg=AOvVaw14R-9gR48cbB9s4tpI1XU5">Feeling Good: The New Mood Therapy</a></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c84"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c33 c17 c74">Avoiding conflict, acquiescence, not assertive, procrastination, blocked, lacking effort, lacking self worth, resistance</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c74"></span></p><h1 class="c45 c36 c230" id="h.2fk6b3p"><span>Overcome conflict avoidance: </span><span class="c12">Face a difficult conversation.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c58">A</span><span class="c20 c17">sk yourself these 2 questions:</span></p><ul class="c41 lst-kix_clcx3rm6rzub-0 start"><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c20 c17">&nbsp;Do you avoid sharing your perspective with others? </span></li></ul><p class="c1 c24"><span class="c58 c17">o</span><span class="c58">r</span></p><ul class="c41 lst-kix_clcx3rm6rzub-0"><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c58 c17">&nbsp;Do you steer clear of personal interactions which might involve conflict? </span></li></ul><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c51 c17 c43"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c43">Your</span><span class="c58 c17 c43">&nbsp;challenge: </span><span class="c58 c17">If you have an </span><span class="c58">issue</span><span class="c58 c17">&nbsp;with </span><span class="c58">conflict</span><span class="c58 c17">&nbsp;avoidance</span><span class="c58">,</span><span class="c58 c43">&nbsp;s</span><span class="c58 c17">tart with</span><span class="c58 c17">&nbsp;a small ste</span><span class="c58">p:</span><span class="c20 c17">&nbsp;Set up a conversation which you have put off because you find it challenging.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c74">Avoiding conflict , acquiescence, appeasement, lacking self worth, resentment </span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.jc7szapegmbw"><span class="c12">Are you making false assumptions about people? </span></h1><p class="c1"><span>Here is another downside of conflict avoidance. </span><span class="c17 c40">Professor Bren&eacute; Brown believes that in our rush to avoid conflict &nbsp;we also miss a deeper understanding.</span><span class="c17 c32">&nbsp;</span><span class="c18 c17">&ldquo;People often silence themselves, or &quot;agree to disagree&quot; without fully exploring the actual nature of the disagreement, for the sake of protecting a relationship and maintaining connection.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>Could this situation also apply to you? </span><span class="c36 c17 c40">Brown </span><span class="c36">also explains</span><span class="c36 c17 c40">&nbsp;the </span><span class="c36">downside:</span><span class="c18 c17">&nbsp; &ldquo;&hellip;when we avoid certain conversations, and never fully learn how the other person feels about all of the issues, we sometimes end up making assumptions that not only perpetuate but deepen misunderstandings, and that can generate resentment.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>Resource: </span><span class="c17 c40">Bren&eacute; Brown, </span><span class="c39 c17">Braving the Wilderness: The Quest for True Belonging and the Courage to Stand Alon</span><span class="c39 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.goodreads.com/work/quotes/55699050&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309875420&amp;usg=AOvVaw2SPO4lvRkZtrnwY5q5MjGZ">e</a></span></p><p class="c31 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; HIGH &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c74">Avoiding conflict, appeasement, </span><span class="c59 c17">acquiescence, </span><span class="c17 c74">timid, not </span><span class="c59 c17">assertive, timid, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing, not self confidence &nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c1 c61 c7" id="h.4du1wux"><span class="c12"></span></h1><h1 class="c1 c61" id="h.2szc72q"><span>Understand the cost of Avoiding</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">&nbsp;interpersonal </span><span>challenges.</span><span class="c12">&nbsp;</span></h1><p class="c1"><span>Do you appreciate </span><span class="c17 c40">the hidden long term cost of avoiding conflict</span><span>?</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>Consider this explanation by Psychologist and Psychotherapist </span><span>Albert Ellis: </span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&ldquo;Watch the cost-benefit ratio of dealing with difficult people and situations. Hating them, running away from them, refusing to cope with them may be easier in the short- run, but not in the long - run.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>Resource: Albert Ellis</span><span class="c17 c40">, </span><span class="c70 c39 c17">Feeling Better, Getting Better, Staying Better </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c70 c39 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; HIGH</span></p><p class="c42"><span class="c33 c59 c17">Avoiding conflict, appeasement, acquiescence, not assertive, timid, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing, not self confident </span></p><p class="c42"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Understand the &lsquo;inner cost&rsquo; of </span><span class="c37 c25">A</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">voidant behavior.</span><span class="c17 c229">&nbsp;</span><span class="c59 c17">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">Self-help author </span><span class="c17 c40">Cheryl Richardson</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;explains the personal cost of &lsquo;conflict avoidance&rsquo; very simply: </span></p><p class="c31 c36"><span class="c17 c32">&ldquo;</span><span class="c17 c32"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://quotefancy.com/quote/1707224/Cheryl-Richardson-If-you-avoid-conflict-to-keep-the-peace-you-start-a-war-inside-yourself&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309878461&amp;usg=AOvVaw3HzxyR1sF_LZRHGozojX86">If you avoid conflict to keep the peace, you start a war inside yourself.</a></span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c109 c45"><span class="c33 c59 c17">Avoiding conflict, &nbsp;not assertive, timid, insecure, appeasement, acquiescence, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing, self confidence lack, &nbsp; &nbsp; </span></p><h1 class="c114 c45 c61" id="h.ydb4a6l30u52"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Build your self worth by being more </span><span>A</span><span class="c12">ssertive. </span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">How do we build self worth? &nbsp;Psychotherapist </span><span class="c8">Nathaniel Branden says that learning to be more assertive is a good way:</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c32">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c97 c1 c36"><span class="c33 c17 c32">&quot;It is a mistake to look at someone who is self assertive and say, &#39;It&#39;s easy for her, she has good self-esteem.&#39; One of the ways you build self-esteem is by being self-assertive when it is not easy to do so.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c114 c45"><span class="c59 c17">&nbsp;</span><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c114 c45"><span class="c33 c59 c17">Avoiding conflict, appeasement, acquiescence, fawn, yes-man, kowtowing, timid, passive, not assertive</span></p><h1 class="c42 c61" id="h.lmu31775hbz4"><span class="c12">Realize the damage from not standing up for yourself.</span></h1><p class="c42"><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;Consider the words of inspirational author </span><span class="c36 c17 c40">Shannon L. Alder:</span></p><p class="c97 c1 c36"><span class="c18 c17">&ldquo;Staying silent is like a slow growing cancer to the soul and a trait of a true coward. There is nothing intelligent about not standing up for yourself. You may not win every battle. However, everyone will at least know what you stood for&mdash;YOU.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c97 c1 c36 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c83 c45"><span class="c17 c74">Avoiding conflict, acquiescence, appeasement, blocked, codependence</span></p><h1 class="c31 c61" id="h.zu0gcz"><span class="c37 c17 c25">&nbsp;Be more &lsquo;proactive&rsquo;</span><span>:</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">&nbsp;</span><span>I</span><span class="c12">nitiate the changes you want!</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">Are you still holding yourself back by avoiding conflict? Then consider the advice of William Glasser, a psychiatrist and an advocate for personal responsibility</span><span>:</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c33 c17 c32">&ldquo;Can you identify when you are &lsquo;avoiding conflict&rsquo;? That&#39;s a good start. Then try a more proactive approach instead! Take personal responsibility.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10 c36 c17">Anxiety (mild), fear, acquiescent, avoid</span><span class="c10 c36">ing conflict, </span><span class="c0">timid, not grounded, not calm, </span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.z4w9vyde5hu3"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Try </span><span>P</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">rotective </span><span>I</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">magery w</span><span class="c12">hen facing fear or conflict.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17">&nbsp;</span><span>To overcome the fear of conflict, consider</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;</span><span>using a </span><span class="c17 c40">visualization </span><span>technique. </span><span class="c58">S</span><span>elf-help author Rick Hanson believes the &nbsp;most effective are those with</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;imagery that most activate the right side of the brain</span><span class="c8">. Hanson gives the following examples:</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;</span><span class="c36 c17 c32">&ldquo;</span><span class="c36 c32">...</span><span class="c18 c17">if I&rsquo;m with someone who&rsquo;s getting intense, I might imagine myself as a deeply rooted tree, with the other person&rsquo;s attitudes and emotions blowing through my leaves and shaking them&mdash;but winds always come to an end, and my tree remains standing. Or I&rsquo;ll imagine that there is a picket fence between us&mdash;or, if need be, a glass wall that&rsquo;s a foot thick.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c36">Recommended Resource:</span><span class="c58 c36 c17">&nbsp;Rick Hanson,</span><span class="c58 c36 c17 c43">&nbsp;Buddha&#39;s Brain: The Practical Neuroscience of Happiness, Love, and Wisdom</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><h1 class="c54 c45 c61 c7" id="h.wcif0rcb0ow3"><span class="c73 c17 c32 c25"></span></h1><p class="c151 c45 c61 c7 title" id="h.w6yntio8bkr2"><span class="c33 c10 c47"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c115 c124"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c115 c124">{M:DEFINE}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c17 c27">Angst, </span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.byxymxbgi58l"><span class="c37 c17 c25">What is </span><span>A</span><span class="c12">ngst? </span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">Psychology professor </span><span class="c17 c40"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.psychologytoday.com/au/contributors/jim-taylor-phd&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309885633&amp;usg=AOvVaw2Bu_wtWHfvB90Gp0rjn6gj">Jim Taylor</a></span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;defines &lsquo;angst&rsquo; as:</span><span class="c17 c111">&nbsp;&ldquo;</span><span class="c33 c111 c17">a psychological state that includes worry, doubt, rumination, and hypervigilance&rdquo;. Taylor says that angst can also include &ldquo;a physical state of stress, agitation, and hyper-arousal&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c111 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58">Taylor goes on to explain the factors that predispose to angst:</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c32">&ldquo;What causes this angst? </span><span class="c111 c17">Well, situations that we perceive to be threatening to our physical, psychological, or emotional well-being, including marital discord, financial stress, ill health, loneliness, lack of freedom, and failure just to name a few .&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; </span></p><p class="c1"><span>Resource: Article by Jim Taylor PhD: &nbsp;</span><span class="c71 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.psychologytoday.com/au/blog/the-power-prime/201209/stop-trying-be-happy-hint-just-get-rid-your-angst&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309886782&amp;usg=AOvVaw3Sr2fGb7iu8cZHAVafgQMz">Stop &#39;Trying&#39; to Be Happy (Hint: Just Get Rid of Your Angst) | Psychology Today Australia</a></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c52"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c52"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c52"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10">A</span><span class="c10 c17">ngst, </span><span class="c10">Anxiety, &nbsp;</span><span class="c10 c17">worry, worked up, fear,</span></p><h1 class="c45 c61 c194" id="h.e17viaxo4hl9"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Is your level of </span><span>A</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">nxiety or </span><span>A</span><span class="c12">ngst &lsquo;stuck on high&rsquo;? </span></h1><p class="c80 c45"><span class="c17">&nbsp;</span><span class="c17 c30 c40">Rick Hanson, psychologist and author explains that our level of anxiety</span><span class="c30">&nbsp;</span><span class="c17 c30 c40">may be inappropriate. </span><span class="c30">It might be stuck on high and needs a reset. </span><span class="c17 c30 c40">We might </span><span class="c30">term this ongoing inner turmoil as angst.</span><span class="c8 c30">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c32 c30">&ldquo;Anxiety functions as a signal of danger, but much of the time it is only noise, like a car alarm that&rsquo;s stuck, blaring away, unpleasant but meaningless.&rdquo; Rick Hanson</span><span class="c4 c30">, Resilient: How to Grow an Unshakable Core of Calm, Strength, and Happiness</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c52"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c16 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10 c17">Angst, worried, fear, </span><span class="c10">anxiety (mild),</span><span class="c10 c17">&nbsp;nerv</span><span class="c10">ous</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.vhpebci6cmkt"><span class="c12">Put Your Angst in Perspective: Challenge Your Fears.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Anxiety, worry and angst can often make us believe that the worst is bound to happen. But how frequently do these fears actually become reality? </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>Emily Delzell, a health writer suggests questioning those anxious thoughts: </span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&quot;On a scale of 1 to 100, how likely is it that the thing I&rsquo;m anxious about will happen? Do I have good reasons to think something will go wrong? Is there a chance I&rsquo;m overly worried?&quot;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">By asking yourself these questions, you can step back and gain a clearer perspective, reducing the grip anxiety has on your mind. More often than not, you&#39;ll discover that your worries are less justified than they seem.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Your Challenge:</span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">The next time you feel overwhelmed by anxiety, take a moment to pause and reflect on these questions. Write down your answers to see if your fears are truly grounded, or if they&#39;re being amplified by anxiety. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">This simple practice can help you regain control and respond to challenges with a calmer mindset.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58">Resource</span><span class="c58 c17">: </span><span class="c58">Website</span><span class="c58 c17">&nbsp;article</span><span class="c58">:</span><span class="c17 c32">&nbsp;</span><span class="c71 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.webmd.com/mental-health/features/ways-to-reduce-anxiety&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309890630&amp;usg=AOvVaw3MM9-DcvWAaC_nCz4SXV7P">How to Stop Feeling Anxious Right Now</a></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c111 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c111 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c111 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c111 c17"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c111 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c33 c10 c17">Angst, anxious, worried, &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.ateq6f846rlb"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Try these </span><span>Strategies</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">&nbsp;to help cope with you</span><span>r</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">&nbsp;</span><span>A</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">nxiety or </span><span>Angst</span><span class="c12">.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">To improve your coping skills in situations of anxiety or </span><span>angst</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;</span><span>consider</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;the following 4 strategies: </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><ol class="c41 lst-kix_hzj0yit8fo4e-0 start" start="1"><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Deep breathing or cyclic breathing.</span></li><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Progressive muscle relaxation. </span></li><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Challenge your irrational thoughts.</span></li><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Mindfulness or &lsquo;Imagery&rsquo;.</span></li></ol><p class="c1 c7 c24"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">If you&#39;re not familiar with these techniques, they are summarized in the following resource</span><span class="c8">.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>Resource: </span><span class="c71 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.therapistaid.com/worksheets/coping-skills-anxiety&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309892440&amp;usg=AOvVaw2zAQ_NVzhFZuOCoX79q8Om">Coping Skills: Anxiety (Therapist Aid)</a></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c111 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c111 c17"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10">Angst, worried, </span><span class="c10 c17">Anxiety (mild) &nbsp;worried </span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.su3b48adl59d"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Try </span><span>V</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">isualizing a </span><span>P</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">ositive </span><span>P</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">ast </span><span>E</span><span class="c12">xperience.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">You can overcome your anxiety or angst by using positive imagery or visualization. </span><span>Simply h</span><span class="c8">old a mental image of a previous time when you successfully overcame your anxiety or angst and moved on. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58">Emily Delzell, a health writer explains it this way: </span><span class="c17">&nbsp;</span><span class="c111 c17">&ldquo;Think back to a time when you were anxious but did what you needed to do anyway. Maybe you were filled with anxiety before an event or a meeting. But later, someone said you did a great job.&rdquo; </span><span class="c17 c32">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>Resource: </span><span class="c71 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.webmd.com/mental-health/features/ways-to-reduce-anxiety&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309894031&amp;usg=AOvVaw23VIRgoPjU5SsA_WzBSeYF">How to Stop Feeling Anxious Right Now</a></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c16"><span class="c57 c36 c17">Anxiety (mild)</span><span class="c57 c36">, angst, </span><span class="c57 c36 c17">stress, worried, </span><span class="c57 c36">suffering</span><span class="c57 c36 c17">, timid</span></p><p class="c16"><span class="c12">Learn to be OK with uncertainty.</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Many of us feel discomfort and fear of the unknown. If we can become more comfortable with uncertainty, our anxiety and suffering will ease. In fact, the only real certainty in life is &lsquo;uncertainty&rsquo; itself.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58">Pema Ch&ouml;dr&ouml;n, a Buudhist nun explains suffering this way: </span><span class="c18 c17">&ldquo;The root of suffering is resisting the certainty that no matter what the circumstances, uncertainty is all we truly have.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Remember this: </span><span>Uncertainty is a part of life. Without it, life could even be boring.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c17">&nbsp;</span><span class="c58">Resource</span><span class="c58 c17">: Pema Ch&ouml;dr&ouml;n, </span><span class="c58 c17 c43"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.goodreads.com/work/quotes/104881&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309895791&amp;usg=AOvVaw25QwOgFy3_MvJLrKhrOZRx">Comfortable with Uncertainty: 108 Teachings on Cultivating Fearlessness and Compassion</a></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c4"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10">Angst, </span><span class="c10 c17">anxiety (mild), fear, worry,</span><span class="c10">&nbsp;stress, </span><span class="c10 c17">learned avoidance &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.zadziv7qp496"><span class="c37 c17 c25">A</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">nswer this </span><span>Q</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">uestion to help overcome your </span><span>A</span><span class="c12">nxiety.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">To help overcome your anxiety or </span><span>a</span><span class="c17 c40">ngst a</span><span class="c17 c40">sk </span><span>yourself</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;th</span><span>e following</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;question </span><span>recommended by Alice Boyes Ph.D:</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;and</span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&nbsp;&quot;What is more important to me than avoiding anxiety?&quot; </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58">Then</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;take the time to work out your best answer.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">This question is a strategy </span><span>used in</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;&lsquo;acceptance and commitment </span><span class="c17 c40"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/basics/therapy&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309897332&amp;usg=AOvVaw3Qx7FifxgXFuLaPOSBbVLd">therapy</a></span><span class="c8">&rsquo;.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>Resource: </span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;Alice Boyes Ph.D., </span><span class="c39 c17">The Healthy Mind Toolkit </span><span class="c17 c40">and </span><span class="c70 c39 c17">Stress-Free Productivity</span></p><p class="c1 c36 c7 c24"><span class="c43 c120 c143"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c70 c39 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c70 c39 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c70 c39 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10">A</span><span class="c33 c10 c17">nxiety ( mild), &nbsp;fear, &nbsp;worry, stressed, facing it (lack of)</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.aagctvfemjpy"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Reframe your feelings of </span><span>Anxiety or Angst</span><span class="c12">.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">Another way of tackling anxiety is to &lsquo;reframe&rsquo; the experience. &nbsp;The following explanation, adapted from clinical psychologist Seth J. Gillian explains this strategy</span><span>&nbsp;in the following way:</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c15">Pay attention to how you typically interpret feelings of angst or anxiety. Do you view them as unwelcome intrusions? Understand that in less intense forms, anxiety can be a helpful response, equipping us to take action and driving us to accomplish tasks.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c15"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c15">How might you reframe your anxiety or angst and channel that nervous energy into performing effectively in a new situation? Concentrate on doing your best, regardless of how you&#39;re feeling.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">Adapted from Seth J. &nbsp;Gillian Ph.D. </span><span class="c70 c39 c17">The CBT Deck for Clients and Therapists</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10">Angst, anxious for success, anxious to perform well, a</span><span class="c33 c10 c17">nxiety mild, fear, worry, perfectionism </span></p><h1 class="c199 c45" id="h.70ilovfgh2wb"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Notice perfectionistic thoughts of &lsquo;I should&rsquo; </span><span>&amp;</span><span class="c12">&nbsp;&lsquo;I must&rsquo;.</span></h1><p class="c45 c199"><span>Perfectionist or self critical thoughts can promote Anxiety or Angst. One strategy is to swap</span><span>&nbsp;these thoughts to help lower our anxiety.</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;This can help lower our anxiety. &nbsp; </span></p><p class="c16"><span>Self-help author Alice Boyes Ph.D. gives some e</span><span class="c8">xamples of such problematic thoughts that we could swap:</span></p><ul class="c41 lst-kix_4tzr3zl1fk8j-0 start"><li class="c6 li-bullet-0"><span class="c17 c32">&quot;I must be good at everything the first time I try it, or people will reject me and my life and </span><span class="c17 c32"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/basics/career&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309901081&amp;usg=AOvVaw0w20y96ewkG3vwgoYvmKD-">career</a></span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&nbsp;will be a disaster.&quot;</span></li><li class="c6 li-bullet-0"><span class="c33 c17 c32">&quot;I must always know the perfect thing to say in social situations or I&#39;ll have no friends.&quot;</span></li></ul><p class="c119 c45"><span class="c20 c17">Give this thought swapping technique a try, especially for any self-critical or perfectionist thoughts .</span></p><p class="c1"><span>Resource: </span><span class="c17 c40">Alice Boyes Ph.D, </span><span class="c39 c17">The Healthy Mind Toolkit, The Anxiety Toolkit </span><span class="c17 c40">and </span><span class="c17 c39">Stress- Free Productivity</span><span class="c43">.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c70 c39 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c16 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10">angst, a</span><span class="c10 c17">nxiety (mild), fear, worry, </span><span class="c10">&nbsp;stress,</span><span class="c33 c10 c17">&nbsp;resentful, Perception distortions, </span></p><h1 class="c38" id="h.9rn13j32dgpo"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Challenge your </span><span>D</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">istorted </span><span>T</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">hinking to reduce </span><span>anxiety.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c17">We can also reduce our anxiety or Angst by challenging our distorted thinking. &nbsp;A good way of doing this is by asking ourselves specific questions </span><span class="c58">and</span><span class="c58 c17">&nbsp;challenging our </span><span class="c58">beliefs</span><span class="c58 c17">. </span><span class="c58">Consider reading this resource article by p</span><span class="c58 c17">sychotherapist Sharon Martin for more </span><span class="c58">on</span><span class="c58 c17">&nbsp;</span><span class="c58">this</span><span class="c20 c17">&nbsp;theme:</span></p><p class="c289 c45 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c16"><span class="c58">Resource</span><span class="c58 c17">&nbsp;</span><span class="c58">article</span><span class="c58 c17">: </span><span class="c71 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.livewellwithsharonmartin.com/how-to-challenge-cognitive-distortions/&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309904707&amp;usg=AOvVaw2UFIclWznt13_nE-_6oTJ1">How to Challenge Cognitive Distortions - Live Well with Sharon Martin</a></span><sup><a href="#cmnt1" id="cmnt_ref1">[a]</a></sup><sup><a href="#cmnt2" id="cmnt_ref2">[b]</a></sup></p><p class="c16"><span>Below are some ideas for questions derived from the article:</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c25">Challenge your Cognitive Distortions with these questions:</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c15">What evidence supports or contradicts this belief?</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c15">Does this thought serve me well?</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c15">Can I view this situation or myself from a different perspective?</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c15">Who or what else might have played a role in this situation?</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c15">Am I making assumptions without enough information?</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c15">What advice would I give a friend in a similar situation?</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c15">Can I explore the situation in more nuanced terms?</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c15">Am I holding myself to an unfair or unrealistic standard?</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c15">Are there exceptions to the absolutes I&rsquo;m considering (always, never)?</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c15">Is there a trusted person I can discuss these thoughts with?</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c16 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c16"><span class="c10">Angst, a</span><span class="c10 c17">nxiety( mild), fear, timidity, worry, unease, beset with issues, indecisive,</span></p><h1 class="c38" id="h.h9te67fv9wes"><span class="c12">&#8203;&#8203;Reduce Anxiety by Loving Your Vulnerable Inner Child.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c20 c17">Much of our anxiety and angst stems from the fears of our vulnerable &lsquo;inner child.&rsquo; This part of us, often overwhelmed by life&rsquo;s challenges, needs nurturing and reassurance.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58">Dr. Margaret Paul, a psychologist and expert in self-healing, offers an approach to reducing anxiety by loving your inner child. The following explanation is </span><span>adapted from Dr Margarets Paul&rsquo;s article: </span><span class="c71"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://margaretpaul.com/relationships/loving-yourself-can-heal-fear&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309907899&amp;usg=AOvVaw2kIwOSBivHYDNhdx_iIxz2">Loving Yourself Can Heal Fear | Dr. Margaret Paul</a></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c25 c94">Loving your inner child involves the following:</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43 c94">Consistently showing up as a loving adult:</span><span class="c15">&nbsp;This means being present for your inner child so they don&rsquo;t feel alone when faced with scary things.</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43 c94">Facing fears repeatedly:</span><span class="c15">&nbsp;By courageously doing scary things over and over, you create positive experiences that reshape your neural pathways.</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43 c94">Embracing imperfection:</span><span class="c15">&nbsp;Reassure your inner child that it&rsquo;s okay to make mistakes and fail, and remind them that your worth and lovability are not tied to outcomes.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c73 c58 c17 c25"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c43">Your Challenge: </span><span class="c20 c17">Practice being a compassionate and supportive presence for your inner child. When anxiety arises, gently remind yourself that it&rsquo;s okay to be scared, and reaffirm that you are worthy of love and care, regardless of the outcome. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c20 c17">This nurturing approach can help reduce anxiety, angst or worry and foster inner peace.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c19"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c19"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10 c17">&nbsp;angst , </span><span class="c10">a</span><span class="c10 c17">nxiety ( mild) ,</span><span class="c10">worry, </span><span class="c10 c17">fear, </span></p><h1 class="c38" id="h.nrz7x996n9fu"><span class="c12">Stop inflating your Anxiety or Angst: Do a Reality check.</span></h1><p class="c16"><span>When confronted with a challenging situation, it&#39;s easy to let anxiety take over. But instead of spiraling into worry or angst , try doing a reality check. By assessing the situation objectively, you can remind yourself of the inner and external resources you have at your disposal.</span></p><p class="c16"><span>Psychologist and author Rick Hanson puts it very simply:</span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&nbsp;&ldquo;To feel safer, we need to stop inflating threats and start recognizing all our resources.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c16"><span class="c8">When you focus on your strengths and support systems, you empower yourself to face challenges with greater confidence and calm.</span></p><p class="c16"><span class="c43">Your Challenge</span><span class="c43">: </span><span class="c8">The next time anxiety creeps in, pause and assess the situation realistically. Ask yourself if the threat is as big as it seems. Then recall the tools and support you have to handle it. This shift in perspective can help deflate your anxiety and reinforce your resilience.</span></p><p class="c16"><span class="c58">Resource: Rick Hanson, </span><span class="c58 c43">Resilient: How to Grow an Unshakable Core of Calm, Strength, and Happiness</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c16 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10">Angst, </span><span class="c10 c17">anxi</span><span class="c10">ety ( mild)</span><span class="c33 c10 c17">, worried, rumination</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.xzuhqtmmzecr"><span class="c12">Become More Aware of Your Anxiety: Name what&#39;s going on. </span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Recognizing when you&#39;re experiencing anxiety or worry is the first step toward managing it effectively. By better identifying these moments, you can take proactive steps to address your feelings. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58">Emily Delzell, a health and wellness writer, suggests</span><span class="c32">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">a simple yet effective approach. This is to describe or name what&#39;s happening:</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c33 c17 c32">&ldquo;Tell yourself, &lsquo;My nervous system is kicking into high gear because I&rsquo;m worried about [thing X].&rsquo;&rdquo; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">By acknowledging the specific cause of your anxiety or angst, you can create a sense of control and start to calm your nervous system.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Your Challenge</span><span class="c43">:</span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">The next time you feel anxious, pause and name the worry out loud. This simple acknowledgment can help you distance yourself from the anxiety and take the first step toward managing it.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58">Reference article: Emily Delzell, </span><span class="c71"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.webmd.com/mental-health/features/ways-to-reduce-anxiety&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309913697&amp;usg=AOvVaw2K5VvTJI4Ob9ndTrBmfukt">How to Stop Feeling Anxious Right Now</a></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c84"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c84"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c16"><span class="c57 c36">A</span><span class="c57 c36 c17">nxi</span><span class="c57 c36">ety ( mild)</span><span class="c57 c36 c17">, angst, &nbsp;stressed, fight, flight, freeze, worried , worked up, triggered, hijacked,</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.vbjqbzn3vxcq"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Try this </span><span>Relaxation</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">&nbsp;&amp; Visualization </span><span>E</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">xercise for </span><span>A</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">nxiety</span><span>.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">R</span><span class="c8">elaxation and visualization exercises can help lower anxiety. Find one, adapt one or design one that works well for you. </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">The example below was adapted from Sean Fargo</span><span>&rsquo;s article:</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp; </span><span class="c71 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://mindfulnessexercises.com/self-compassion-visualization-the-blanket-of-love/&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309915807&amp;usg=AOvVaw3A_Nnrxo9YcI53htfXeN3E">Self-Compassion Visualization: The Blanket of Love</a></span><span class="c8">:</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c15">Begin by finding a comfortable seat, settling in, and turning your attention inward to your breath. Take a moment to adjust your posture, ensuring you feel at ease.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c15"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c15">When you&rsquo;re ready, gently close your eyes or soften your gaze.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c15"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c15">Bring your awareness to your jaw. If you notice any tension there, visualize it dissolving, flowing downwards, and merging with the earth beneath you.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c15"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c15">Now, shift your focus to your neck and shoulders. If you sense any tightness, allow it to soften, feeling it slowly melting away and descending through your body, grounding itself into the earth for transformation.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c15"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c15">As you continue, scan your body for any other areas holding onto stress or anxiety. Give yourself permission to let go, releasing any tension you find.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c15"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c15">Now, imagine a blanket crafted from the most exquisite material you can envision. Observe the colors, the textures&mdash;anything that brings you a sense of comfort and peace.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c15"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c15">Picture this blanket gently enveloping you, wrapping around you with the utmost care and love. Feel its warmth and support as it settles around you, providing a soothing embrace.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10">&nbsp;Angst, </span><span class="c10 c17">&nbsp;rumination, worry, a</span><span class="c10">nxiety ( mild), </span><span class="c10 c17">fear, not mindful &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.ik80branxzfv"><span class="c12">Find Peace in the Present Moment.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Much of our angst and worry stems from dwelling on past regrets and resentments. Or it&#39;s anxiously anticipating an uncertain future. These thoughts can keep us trapped in a cycle of worry, dissatisfaction and rumination.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>Marcus Aurelius offers this timeless wisdom for breaking free from this cycle: </span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&ldquo;Confine yourself to the present.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">By focusing on the present moment, you can release the weight of the past and ease the fears of the future. The present is where you have the power to act, change, and find peace.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Your Challenge</span><span class="c43">: </span><span class="c8">When you catch yourself ruminating on the past or worrying about the future, gently bring your attention back to the present. Engage fully in what you&#39;re doing right now, and let go of what you cannot change or predict. This practice can help you cultivate a calmer, more centered mind.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c118 c40"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c118 c40"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c118 c40"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c118 c40"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c118 c40"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10">Angst, </span><span class="c10 c17">Anxiety (mild), worry, worked up, upset, stressed, breathe </span></p><h1 class="c194 c45 c61" id="h.fwh0tekscjrj"><span>Try </span><span class="c12">Centering Yourself by Focusing on the Breath.</span></h1><p class="c80 c45"><span class="c8">When anxiety starts to build, it can be challenging to stay grounded. One simple yet effective way to regain your balance is to focus on your breathing.
