This is often termed focussing on the breath.</span></p><p class="c80 c45"><span class="c8">&nbsp;Becoming centered can be as simple as taking one deep mindful breath, but it often requires mindfully following our breathing for a while. </span></p><p class="c80 c45"><span class="c43">Try this strategy:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Simply focus on the sensation of the breath in the airways as you gently breathe in and out. </span></p><p class="c80 c45"><span>Greg McKeown, in his book </span><span class="c43">Essentialism, </span><span>offers this classic advice: </span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&quot;Take a deep breath. Get present in the moment and ask yourself what is important this very second.&quot;</span></p><p class="c80 c45"><span class="c8">By centering yourself through mindful breathing, you can calm your mind and refocus on what truly matters right now. This practice helps you shift away from overwhelming thoughts and into a state of clarity and calm.</span></p><p class="c80 c45"><span class="c43">Your Challenge</span><span class="c43">:</span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">The next time you feel anxious, pause and take a deep breath, or try a few gentle mindful breaths. Focus on the present moment and ask yourself, &quot;What is most important right now?&quot; Let this mindfulness and the question guide you back to a place of calm and purposeful action.</span></p><p class="c80 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c118 c40"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10">&nbsp;Distressed, </span><span class="c10 c17">Angst, worry, </span><span class="c10">&nbsp;rumination, anxiety (mild),</span><span class="c10 c17">&nbsp;worked up,</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.o1ocvnr4rhp6"><span>T</span><span class="c12">he Stories We Tell Ourselves: Self-Generated Anxiety.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8 c30">Much of the anxiety and angst we experience is self-generated, often fueled by the stories we create in our minds. We tend to magnify our fears, envisioning worst-case scenarios that rarely come to pass. Then we might ruminate on that. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c30"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c30">As Mark Twain humorously observed: </span><span class="c33 c17 c32 c30">&ldquo;I&rsquo;ve had a lot of trouble in my life&mdash;most of which never happened.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c30"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8 c30">Consider how many of the &#39;troubles&#39; in your life are simply products of your imagination and rumination . By recognizing these patterns, you can start to question the validity of your fears and reduce the unnecessary distress they cause.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c30"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c30 c43">Your Challenge</span><span class="c30 c43">: </span><span class="c8 c30">The next time you feel overwhelmed by anxiety, first pause. Then ask yourself if the situation is truly as dire as it seems, or if it&#39;s just a story you&#39;ve created. Challenge these thoughts and remind yourself that many of the troubles you worry about may never actually happen.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c10 c17 c30"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c118 c40"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c118 c40"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c118 c40"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c40 c118"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c17 c32 c30"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c126 c45"><span class="c10 c17">Angst, nervy</span><span class="c10">, </span><span class="c10 c17">neurotic,</span><span class="c10">&nbsp;</span><span class="c10 c17">victim traits, gloomy, grief, </span><span class="c10">&nbsp;sad, </span><span class="c33 c10 c17">broken, learned helplessness , hopelessness &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c45 c61 c136" id="h.7fcsmy6h3ca"><span class="c12">Accept that painful emotions are a part of life.</span></h1><p class="c45 c80"><span class="c30">P</span><span class="c17 c40">ainful emotions are inevitable. T</span><span>h</span><span class="c17 c40">at in </span><span>itself</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;</span><span>is</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;enough</span><span>, </span><span class="c17 c40">we don&#39;t need the added pressure of high expectations </span><span>and</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;self criticism. &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c80 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c80 c45"><span class="c30">Sheryl Paul, a counselor and author, puts it this way:</span></p><p class="c126 c45"><span class="c33 c17 c32 c30">&ldquo;To be human is to struggle. Eventually we realize that when we sit under the umbrella of &ldquo;shoulds&rdquo;&mdash;&ldquo;This shouldn&rsquo;t be so hard. I should be happy.&rdquo;&mdash;the pain rains down harder. </span></p><p class="c80 c45"><span>So what can we do? </span><span class="c17 c40">Paul invites us to accept reality and then try to make it better</span><span>:</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c126 c45"><span class="c32 c30">&ldquo;</span><span class="c33 c17 c32 c30">But when we accept the fact that anxiety, depression, loneliness, powerlessness, grief, joy, and exhilaration are all part of the design, we step out into the rain and perhaps even dance a little.&rdquo; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c126 c45"><span class="c58 c30">Resource: </span><span class="c58 c17 c30">Sheryl Paul, </span><span class="c58 c17 c30 c43"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://thehumancondition.com/books/the-wisdom-of-anxiety-how-worry-and-intrusive-thoughts-are-gifts-to-help-you-heal/&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309927024&amp;usg=AOvVaw0vTljauvXLQhGg5NoZDWyK">The Wisdom of Anxiety</a></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32 c30"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32 c30"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32 c30"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10 c17">Angst, stress, fear, worry, nervy, stressed, an</span><span class="c10">xiety ( mild) </span><span class="c33 c10 c17">&nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.28qdyxi3ai2y"><span class="c12">Reconnect with your &lsquo;Inner Guide&rsquo; to alleviate Anxiety.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c36">Gabrielle Bernstein captures a profound truth about anxiety and Angst: </span><span class="c18 c17">&ldquo;Much of our anxiety and stress comes when we&rsquo;re focused on fear and disconnected from the voice of our inner guide.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8 c36">When we let fear take the wheel, we lose touch with the calm, intuitive guidance within us. This inner voice often becomes drowned out by worry. &nbsp;However it can offer clarity and peace when we tune into it. By reconnecting with our inner guide, we can shift our focus away from fear and towards a more centered, mindful approach to life&#39;s challenges.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c36 c43">Your Challenge</span><span class="c36 c43">:</span><span class="c8 c36">&nbsp;The next time you feel overwhelmed by anxiety, take a moment to quiet your mind and listen to your inner guide. Practice mindfulness or simple meditation to help reconnect with that inner wisdom. Allow it to guide you through stressful situations with greater ease and confidence.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c4 c36"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10">Negative mindset, </span><span class="c10">Not proactive</span><span class="c10 c17">, an</span><span class="c10">gst, anxiety ( mild),</span><span class="c10 c17">&nbsp;</span><span class="c10 c36 c17">learned avoidance, not proactive </span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.tooks3mdcglv"><span class="c12">Shift your Focus: Plan beyond Disaster scenarios .</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c36">Richard Bandler points out a common mindset: </span><span class="c18 c17">&ldquo;Most people plan by disaster. They think of what can go wrong and then they master it.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8 c36">While it&rsquo;s wise to consider potential obstacles, fixating only on what could go wrong can narrow your outlook. Instead of letting fear guide your plans, use it as one piece of the puzzle. Understand that true success comes from also envisioning what can go right and strategizing how to achieve it.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c36 c43">Your challenge</span><span class="c36 c43">: </span><span class="c8 c36">As you plan, recognize the risks but don&rsquo;t let them dominate your thinking. Balance your approach by also focusing on positive outcomes and the actions needed to bring them to life. This shift will help you navigate challenges with confidence and stay motivated toward your goals.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c4 c36"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c4 c36"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c4 c36"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10 c36 c17">Angst, worry, anxious, learned avoidance </span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.8tweo9ee8pg7"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Focus on &lsquo;problem solving&rsquo; rather than the problem.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">If we focus on the narrative or drama surrounding a problem, that just worsens our suffering. By focusing </span><span>instead</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;on the potential solutions to a problem we reduce our angst and distress.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Consider this strategy:</span><span>&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">One way to help refocus is to write down all the ways you can deal with a situation that&rsquo;s worrying you.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10 c36 c17">Angst, worry, anxious to, anxiety, learned avoidance </span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.wh1ucsil8kc9"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Try some of these </span><span>S</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">trategies for </span><span>Anxiety</span><span class="c12">&nbsp;or Angst.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c94">Here are 8 strategies you can use when you feel anxiety, angst or worry: (adapted from calmclinic.com</span><span class="c94">)</span><span class="c15">&nbsp; Give these a try. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c15"></span></p><ol class="c41 lst-kix_570tt4d6smkv-0 start" start="1"><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c15">Focus on your breathing. &nbsp;</span></li><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c15">Replace fearful thoughts with positive ones </span></li><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c15">Stay &lsquo;present&rsquo; or centered in the moment</span></li><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c15">Phone a loved one </span></li><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c15">Engage in calm activities</span></li><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c15">Play some relaxing music</span></li><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c15">Write out your thoughts &amp; options</span></li><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c17 c94">Reduce caffeine </span><span class="c94">and</span><span class="c15">&nbsp;processed food </span></li></ol><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c45 c130"><span class="c59 c36 c17">Adapted from: &nbsp;</span><span class="c71 c36 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.calmclinic.com/anxiety/how-to-calm-anxiety&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309935205&amp;usg=AOvVaw040cF5F3JOfvS9Ix1iX2SS">How To Calm Anxiety &amp; Feel Better Fast</a></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c118 c40"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c10 c36 c17">Angst, worry, anxi</span><span class="c10 c36">ety</span><span class="c10 c36 c17">, learned avoidance, mindfulness </span></p><h1 class="c235 c45 c61 c150" id="h.wj1zgur06092"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Try </span><span>C</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">yclic </span><span>B</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">reathing to reduce </span><span>A</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">nxiety or </span><span>A</span><span class="c12">ngst.</span></h1><p class="c56 c45 c150"><span class="c17 c40">Certain patterns of breathing can help reduce anxiety or angst. You might want to research this further. Here is an example of cyclic breathing from Simone </span><span>Ma</span><span class="c17 c40">rie</span><span>&rsquo;</span><span class="c8">s article in psychcentral.com linked below: </span></p><ul class="c41 lst-kix_7ebaer722bxp-0 start"><li class="c138 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c15 c36">Breathe in for 4 seconds</span></li><li class="c138 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c15 c36">Hold your breath for 7 seconds</span></li><li class="c138 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c15 c36">Exhale slowly for 8 seconds</span></li><li class="c138 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c15 c36">Repeat until you feel calmer</span></li></ul><p class="c203 c45 c150"><span class="c36 c94">Adapted </span><span class="c36 c17 c94">from: </span><span class="c36 c182 c94">&nbsp;</span><span class="c71 c36 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://psychcentral.com/anxiety/how-to-reduce-anxiety-quickly&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309937035&amp;usg=AOvVaw3ySqGNGn9EnypT2HchkMQ2">Reduce Anxiety Now: How to Calm Down Quickly</a></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c56 c45 c150"><span class="c33 c59 c36 c17">Angst, anxiety, anxious to, worry, stress, mindfulness </span></p><p class="c56 c45 c150"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Try the 5-4-3-2-1 </span><span class="c37 c25">M</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">indfulness </span><span class="c37 c25">T</span><span class="c12">echnique.</span></p><p class="c1 c150"><span class="c17 c40">Mindfulness is a good technique to reduce anxiety, angst, worry and stress related feelings. It </span><span>can</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;help to have a system to start the mindfulness process and </span><span>especially</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;one that is easy to remember. </span></p><p class="c1 c150 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c150"><span class="c17 c40">Try this simple 5-4-3-2-1 techni</span><span>qu</span><span class="c17 c40">e from Simone M</span><span>arie in her &nbsp;</span><span class="c17 c40">psychcentral.com </span><span>article</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;linked below. Its based on using 5 of our senses: </span></p><ul class="c41 lst-kix_i6ljljuzp8nk-0 start"><li class="c138 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c15 c36">Look around the room, then name five things you see around you. The key is to count down those five things. </span></li><li class="c138 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c15 c36">Next, name four things you can touch. This can be the ground beneath your feet, the chair you&rsquo;re sitting in, etc.</span></li><li class="c138 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c15 c36">Listen quietly, then acknowledge three things you can hear. These can be external sounds, like a fan in the room.</span></li><li class="c45 c79 c24 c138 li-bullet-0"><span class="c15 c36">Note two things you can smell. Maybe that&rsquo;s the perfume you&rsquo;re wearing or the pencil you&rsquo;re holding.</span></li><li class="c138 c45 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c15 c36">Notice something you can taste inside your mouth. Maybe that&rsquo;s the lipgloss you&rsquo;re wearing.</span></li></ul><p class="c139 c45"><span class="c15 c36">This technique works best if you pair it with deep, slow breathing. </span></p><p class="c139 c45"><span class="c36 c17">Adapted from: &nbsp;</span><span class="c71 c36 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://psychcentral.com/anxiety/how-to-reduce-anxiety-quickly%23how-to-calm-down-now&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309939773&amp;usg=AOvVaw3hKFTz9QhSA2D9yu75IVWt">Reduce Anxiety Now: How to Calm Down Quickly</a></span></p><p class="c139 c45 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c139 c45 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c139 c45"><span class="c0">Anxiety ( mild) , anxious to succeed , worried, rumination, nervous, nervy, stress, </span></p><h1 class="c45 c150 c238" id="h.okp4j4n2mgrt"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Try the &ldquo;</span><span>F</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">ile </span><span>I</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">t&rdquo; mind </span><span>V</span><span class="c12">isualization exercise.</span></h1><p class="c16 c150"><span class="c17 c40">Visualization techniques can be useful for overcoming anxiety, worry. Try this one from Simone </span><span>M</span><span class="c8">arie in her psychcentral.com article linked below</span></p><p class="c22"><span class="c15 c36">This technique is useful if you&rsquo;re lying awake at night thinking of all the things you must do or haven&rsquo;t done, or you are ruminating about a stressful event that happened during the day. </span></p><p class="c22"><span class="c36 c17 c94">Here are the steps </span><span class="c36 c94">involved</span><span class="c15 c36">:</span></p><ul class="c41 lst-kix_1mmlycggdr6l-0 start"><li class="c46 c45 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c15 c36">Close your eyes and imagine a filing cabinet.</span></li><li class="c46 c45 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c15 c36">Imagine yourself picking up a file and writing down the name of a thought that&rsquo;s racing through your mind</span></li><li class="c46 c45 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c15 c36">Then take a moment to acknowledge the thought and how important it is to you and then file it away.</span></li><li class="c45 c24 c46 li-bullet-0"><span class="c15 c36">Repeat this process with every thought that pops into your head until you start to feel calmer (or sleepy).</span></li></ul><p class="c16 c150"><span class="c36 c17 c94">Adapted from: </span><span class="c36 c182 c94">&nbsp;</span><span class="c71 c36 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://psychcentral.com/anxiety/how-to-reduce-anxiety-quickly%23how-to-calm-down-now&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309941796&amp;usg=AOvVaw2jFodnMuWDiOrXjYwYim3Q">Reduce Anxiety Now: How to Calm Down Quickly</a></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c84"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c84"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c4 c36"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c4 c36"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c203 c45 c150"><span class="c10 c36 c17">An</span><span class="c10 c36">xiety ( mild)</span><span class="c10 c36 c17">, adaptive action, proactive, stress, anxiety, &nbsp;worry, </span><span class="c10 c36">a</span><span class="c10 c36 c17">ngst, nervy, learned avoidance, avoidance, timid, &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.pxd6o0evhqeu"><span>Use t</span><span class="c12">he Power of Action in Combating Anxiety &amp; Stress.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c36">Sukant Ratnakar in </span><span class="c36 c43">Quantraz </span><span class="c36">offers a simple yet powerful remedy for life&#39;s pressures: </span><span class="c18 c17">&ldquo;Action is the best medicine for anxiety and a smile is the best tonic for stress.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8 c36">When anxiety strikes, taking proactive steps can help dispel those feelings of worry. Action redirects your focus and empowers you to tackle the source of your anxiety. Meanwhile, a smile&mdash;even in tough times&mdash;can lighten your mood, reducing the impact of stress and promoting a sense of well-being.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c36 c43">Your Challenge</span><span class="c36 c43">:</span><span class="c8 c36">&nbsp;Whenever anxiety or stress begins to creep in, take a small step forward&mdash;whether it&#39;s tackling a task or simply moving your body. And don&rsquo;t forget to smile; it can work wonders in lifting your spirits and keeping you on a healthy, positive path.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c16 c150"><span class="c10 c36 c17">Angst, stress</span><span class="c10 c36">,</span><span class="c10 c36 c17">&nbsp;worry, nervy, anxiety, </span><span class="c10 c36">anxious</span><span class="c10 c36 c17">&nbsp;to, &nbsp;learned avoidance, avoidance, timid, </span><span class="c36 c17">&nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.v1mf89ip3p1y"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Try this simple </span><span>M</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">indfulness </span><span>&amp;</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">&nbsp;</span><span>V</span><span class="c12">isualization technique. </span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Combining mindfulness with visualization provides a powerful technique for overcoming anxiety or worry. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">Try this very simple but powerful strategy:</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c36">Just n</span><span class="c8 c36">ame the physical sensations and feelings in your body and imagine them drifting away.</span></p><p class="c16 c150 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c16 c150 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c16 c150 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c16 c150"><span class="c10 c36">Angst, a</span><span class="c0">nxiety ( mild) , stress &nbsp;worry, nervy, learned avoidance, avoidance, timid, &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c45 c61 c150 c235" id="h.nrhgi825rryn"><span class="c12">Use a Mantra to Ease Anxiety and Worry.</span></h1><p class="c203 c45 c150"><span class="c8 c36">When anxiety or worry takes hold, repeating a calming mantra can help soothe your mind and bring you back to a place of peace. </span></p><p class="c45 c150 c203"><span class="c36">A simple phrase like </span><span class="c36 c32">&quot;this too shall pass&quot;</span><span class="c36">&nbsp;or </span><span class="c36 c32">&quot;all is well&quot; </span><span class="c8 c36">can work well. It serves as a gentle reminder that the storm will eventually settle. You can create your own Mantra. </span></p><p class="c203 c45 c150"><span class="c36 c43">Your Challenge</span><span class="c36 c43">:</span><span class="c8 c36">&nbsp;The next time you feel anxious, close your eyes and repeat your chosen mantra slowly and calmly. Allow the words to anchor you in the present moment, helping to quiet your mind and ease your worries.</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c130 c45 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36 c55"><span class="c33 c10 c17">Angst, overwhelmed, hoarding </span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.f79ncntmbrve"><span class="c12">Reduce Anxiety by Prioritizing, Delegating &amp; Decluttering.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">If you&#39;re feeling anxiety or angst, it may be exacerbated by the sheer volume of tasks and clutter in your life. A practical approach to managing this is to take a short time to tidy up your environment&mdash;perhaps by tossing out some clutter. Clearing physical space can also clear mental space.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">While you&#39;re tidying, assess what truly matters. What tasks or responsibilities are genuine priorities? Which can be delegated to others, and which can be removed from your list entirely?</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Your Challenge</span><span class="c43">:</span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">Start by decluttering a small area around you. As you do, make a list of your top priorities. Identify tasks you can delegate or eliminate altogether. This process can help reduce your sense of overwhelm and bring more clarity and calm to your day.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c118 c40"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c16"><span class="c101">Angst, anxiety ( mild), discouraged &nbsp;worry, stress, negative mindset, pessimistic ,worry, quitting , hard on self </span></p><h1 class="c34 c45 c36 c61 c55" id="h.9mxc9m5swo6v"><span class="c12">Be Your Own Best Encourager.</span></h1><p class="c34 c45 c36 c55"><span class="c8">When a close friend is feeling anxious or discouraged, you likely offer them kind words of support and reassurance. But how often do you do the same for yourself? Encouraging yourself with the same compassion you would show a friend can be incredibly powerful. </span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36 c55 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36 c55"><span class="c43">Consider this approach: </span><span class="c8">Ask yourself: What would I say to a friend in this situation? Then, say those words to yourself. Remind yourself that you&rsquo;re doing your best, that it&rsquo;s okay to feel what you&rsquo;re feeling, and that you have the strength to get through it.</span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36 c55 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36 c55"><span class="c43">Your Challenge</span><span class="c43">:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;The next time you&#39;re feeling down or anxious, pause and imagine what you would say to a friend in your shoes. Speak those words to yourself with the same warmth and kindness. This simple practice can help you cultivate self-compassion and boost your resilience.</span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36 c55 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c16"><span class="c101">Angst, Anxiety ( mild), negative mindset, &nbsp;anxious to perform, worry, anxious to succeed, &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.k3tor1mnu2kz"><span class="c12">Center Yourself in the Present Moment.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Centering yourself in the present moment is a powerful way to combat anxiety and negative emotions. When you focus on the now, you can let go of worries about the past or future and find peace in the present.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>As Th&iacute;ch Nh&#7845;t H&#7841;nh wisely said,</span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&nbsp;&ldquo;The present moment is the only time over which we have dominion.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">By staying present, you can better manage your emotions and reactions, creating a space of calm and clarity within yourself.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Your challenge</span><span class="c43">:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Practice centering yourself throughout the day. You can do this by focusing on your breath, your surroundings, or on simple tasks at hand. Try to remain in the present moment for as long as you can. Notice how this shifts your emotional state to one of greater peace and balance.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c16 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c16 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c16"><span class="c33 c101">Not courage, angst, &nbsp;fear, negative mindset, anxiety ( mild) , worry, not brave </span></p><h1 class="c31 c36 c61" id="h.wy79zzmkh801"><span class="c12">Move Beyond Fear: Find what&rsquo;s more important to you.</span></h1><p class="c31 c36"><span>Franklin D. Roosevelt beautifully redefines courage:</span><span class="c32">&nbsp;&ldquo;Courage is not the absence of fear, but rather the assessment that something else is more important than fear.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c31 c36"><span class="c8">Understand that courage doesn&rsquo;t mean living without fear&mdash;it means recognizing that your goals, values, or loved ones are worth facing that fear. It&rsquo;s about making the conscious decision to move forward despite the fear, driven by something greater.</span></p><p class="c31 c36"><span class="c43">Your Challenge:</span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">The next time fear holds you back, take a moment to reflect on what truly matters to you. Let that sense of purpose guide you through the fear, knowing that your courage comes from placing importance on what lies beyond it.</span></p><p class="c31 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c31 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c10">Angst, </span><span class="c10 c17">Anxiety ( mild), </span><span class="c10">stress,</span><span class="c10 c17">&nbsp;gloomy, glum, &nbsp;exercise, worry, worked up, &nbsp;movemen</span><span class="c10">t</span></p><h1 class="c34 c45 c61" id="h.sgntzhpn3cas"><span class="c12">Move Your Body to Help Release Anxiety &amp; Stress.</span></h1><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c8">Physical movement is a powerful tool for reducing anxiety and lifting your mood. Always choose a form of exercise that is appropriate for your health and fitness level. Whether it&#39;s a brisk walk, a workout, or just some gentle stretching, moving your body can help release built-up tension and stress. </span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span>As John J. Ratey points out in his book </span><span class="c43">Spark: The Revolutionary New Science of Exercise and the Brain,</span><span>&nbsp;</span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&ldquo;exercise is as effective as certain medications for treating anxiety and depression.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c8">Incorporating regular movement into your routine can be a natural and effective way to manage anxiety and improve your overall well-being.</span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c43">Your Challenge</span><span class="c43">: </span><span class="c8">The next time you feel anxious or low, get up and move. Whether it&rsquo;s a short walk, a quick workout, yoga, or simply stretching, notice how physical activity can help you feel calmer and more centered. Make movement a regular part of your day to support your mental and emotional health.</span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c10 c17">Angst, anxiety ( mild), worry, stress, rumination, </span></p><h1 class="c34 c45 c61" id="h.qbfzvmibcbr2"><span class="c12">Try Cognitive Defusion to Ease Anxiety.</span></h1><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c8">Cognitive Defusion is a mindfulness strategy used in Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT). It can help you manage uncomfortable emotions like anxiety, angst, or worry. The key idea is to observe your thoughts and feelings objectively, rather than automatically accepting them as reality.</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c8">This approach teaches us that feelings are just that&mdash;feelings. They don&rsquo;t necessarily predict or dictate what will happen next. By recognizing this, you can begin to detach from negative thoughts and reduce their emotional impact.</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c43">Your Challenge</span><span class="c43">: </span><span class="c8">The next time you feel overwhelmed by anxious thoughts, try practicing Cognitive Defusion. Observe your thoughts as if they were passing clouds, acknowledging them without getting caught up in them. </span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c8">Remind yourself that feelings are not facts, and this simple shift in perspective can help you find relief from anxiety.</span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c10">Angst, </span><span class="c10 c17">Anxiety ( mild) , worry, worked up, rumination,not Letting it go,</span><span class="c8">&nbsp; </span></p><h1 class="c34 c45 c61" id="h.j6hz9fgqn0w6"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Follow John Lennon&rsquo;s advice</span><span>:</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">&nbsp;just &ldquo;Let it Be&rdquo;.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">When you encounter anxiety or worry try to &lsquo;let go&rsquo; of any negative reaction. Or even better just &lsquo;let it be&rsquo;.</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;A study of 500 people conducted by Nick Hobson, a behavioral scientist, showed that while repeating the mantra &lsquo;</span><span>L</span><span class="c17 c40">et it </span><span>G</span><span class="c17 c40">o&rsquo; had a drop in anxiety by 24%. </span><span>In comparison, t</span><span class="c17 c40">hose who repeated the mantra &lsquo;</span><span>L</span><span class="c17 c40">et it </span><span>B</span><span class="c17 c40">e&rsquo; had a 45% drop in anxiety </span><span>after thinking of a stressful situation</span><span class="c8">.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Your Challenge</span><span class="c39 c17">:</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;</span><span>W</span><span class="c8">hen feeling anxious or stressed repeat the words &lsquo;Let it Be&rsquo;. Do this a few times and tune in to the deeper meaning.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">This is the Beatles song </span><span>of</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;that name:</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c71 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v%3DQDYfEBY9NM4&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309961629&amp;usg=AOvVaw0bZ6HLKOXkYsk5oJ68SQdl">Let It Be (Remastered 2009)</a></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10 c17">Anxiety ( mild), angst, &nbsp;worry, worked up, rumination, self conscious, laughter, humor &nbsp; </span></p><h1 class="c45 c61 c165" id="h.yv08b3mjuwx4"><span class="c12">Lighten Up: Use Humor to Ease Your Anxiety.</span></h1><p class="c152 c45"><span class="c8">When anxiety or worry takes hold, one of the best antidotes can be laughter. Viewing a situation through the lens of humor can provide much-needed relief and shift your perspective. Humor helps you see things from a different angle, often revealing that what seems daunting isn&#39;t as serious as it first appeared.</span></p><p class="c152 c45"><span class="c8">By finding the lighter or funny side of a situation, you can reduce the intensity of your worries and bring some much-needed levity to your day.</span></p><p class="c152 c45"><span class="c43">Your challenge</span><span class="c43">:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;The next time you&#39;re feeling anxious, take a moment to step back and try to see the humor in the situation. It might be laughing at the abs</span></p><p class="c45 c7 c152"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c152 c45"><span class="c8">This shift in perspective can help you relax and approach the challenge with a lighter heart.</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c33 c10 c17">Angst, anxiety (mild), worry, rumination, journalling </span></p><h1 class="c34 c45 c61" id="h.6bkikhywnkb1"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Try writing in a Journal to help ease your distress.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">Expressing our feelings in writing can help release the </span><span>emotional</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;discomfort we feel. T</span><span>h</span><span class="c17 c40">is practice is often </span><span>termed</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">journaling:</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">This </span><span>journaling</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;approach can for example help anxiety, angst, worry or stress. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>Consider</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;these prompts to help start your </span><span>Journaling</span><span class="c8">:</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c24"><span class="c8">Describe in full how you are feeling.</span></p><p class="c1 c24"><span class="c8">What worries you about your situation?</span></p><p class="c1 c24"><span class="c8">What are your feelings trying to tell you?</span></p><p class="c1 c24"><span>In w</span><span class="c8">hat ways could you deal with it?</span></p><p class="c1 c24"><span class="c8">What strategies have worked in the past?</span></p><p class="c1 c24"><span class="c8">What do you really need to let go of?</span></p><p class="c1 c24"><span class="c8">What lesson can you learn from this</span></p><p class="c1 c24"><span class="c8">Can you forgive yourself or another?</span></p><p class="c1 c24"><span class="c17 c40">Can you see the lighter side of all this?</span></p><p class="c1 c24"><span class="c8">What deeper wisdom have you gained? &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c7 c24"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7 c24"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7 c24"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7 c24"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c73 c17 c25 c40"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10 c17">&nbsp;</span><span class="c10">S</span><span class="c10 c17">elf doubt</span><span class="c10">, i</span><span class="c10 c17">mposter Syndrome, angst</span><span class="c10">, a</span><span class="c10 c17">nxiety ( mild), worry, stress, self conscious,</span></p><h1 class="c122 c45 c36 c61" id="h.zal9ut2dzx2"><span class="c12">Embrace the Uncertainty: We&#39;re All Figuring It Out.</span></h1><p class="c66 c45 c36"><span>In moments of doubt, it&rsquo;s easy to feel like you&rsquo;re the only one struggling to find your way. But as Ricky Gervais wisely reminds us, </span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&quot;Relax. No one else knows what they&rsquo;re doing either.&quot;</span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36"><span class="c8">We often assume that everyone around us has it all figured out, but the truth is, we&rsquo;re all navigating the unknown together. Thinking we have all the answers is an illusion. Embrace the uncertainty and remember that it&#39;s okay not to have everything under control.</span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36"><span class="c43">Your challenge</span><span class="c43">: </span><span class="c8">The next time you feel overwhelmed by self-doubt, take a deep breath and remind yourself that everyone is on their own journey, learning as they go. Allow yourself the freedom to explore and grow without the burden of perfection.</span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10 c17">anxious to perform, angst, stress, anxiety ( mild), worry, </span></p><h1 class="c122 c45 c36 c61" id="h.tlh9yinlr81u"><span class="c12">Use your conscious breathing to manage your stress.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">By breathing consciously you can </span><span>better manage</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;anxiety. This </span><span>can</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;help </span><span>reduce</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;apprehensive thoughts </span><span>and</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;slow your overactive &lsquo;monkey-mind&rsquo;.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c70 c39 c17">Consider this simple breathing technique:</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">Sit up straight, relax and inhale </span><span>slightly</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;more deeply.</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">When you exhale, allow your lungs to fully empty. </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Be mindful of your breathing and the flow of the air.</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">Repeat this for 1</span><span>&nbsp;up to </span><span class="c17 c40">5 minutes if </span><span>this</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;feels comfortable.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10">&nbsp;not &nbsp;peace, </span><span class="c33 c10 c17">Upset, stress, anxiety ( mild) , angst, worry ,</span></p><h1 class="c122 c45 c36 c61" id="h.yf6xxuv35s7i"><span class="c12">The Secret to Inner Peace: Accept yourself as you are.</span></h1><p class="c66 c45 c36"><span>Realize that &nbsp;t</span><span>he path to lasting peace begins within. As the Dalai Lama XIV wisely reminds us, </span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&ldquo;We can never obtain peace in the outer world until we make peace with ourselves.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36"><span class="c8">True inner peace comes from accepting and embracing who we are, flaws and all. When we stop fighting our inner battles and find harmony within, it naturally extends to the world around us.</span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36"><span class="c43">Your challenge</span><span class="c43">: </span><span class="c8">Take time each day to reflect on your relationship with yourself. Accept yourself as you are with all your flaws and mistakes. Practice self-compassion, forgive yourself, and forgive others for their role. Embrace your whole journey. </span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36"><span class="c8">Remember, by making peace with yourself, you unlock the secret to a more peaceful and harmonious life.</span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10 c17">Anxiety ( mild) , stress,worry, worked up, rumination, self conscious &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.k13gpzg537mj"><span class="c12">Release Your Anxiety with a Simple Visualization.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">When anxiety starts to build, a powerful visualization technique can help you let go of those racing thoughts. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Consider this technique:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Imagine placing your anxious thoughts in a helium balloon. Picture the balloon slowly rising into the sky, taking your worries with it. As the balloon drifts higher and farther away, allow yourself to feel the release of those anxious thoughts, letting them go completely.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Your Challenge</span><span class="c43">:</span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">The next time anxiety creeps in, close your eyes and visualize placing your thoughts into a balloon. Watch it float away, and with it, your worries. This simple exercise can help you feel lighter and more at ease.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c33 c10 c17">Anxiety ( mild) , stress, anxiety, rumination, self conscious &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.unokvoez2epf"><span>Remember: our fears are usually</span><span class="c12">&nbsp;worse than the reality.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span>Fear and anxiety often stem from imagining the worst. We create &lsquo;shadows&rsquo; that loom larger than reality. As Seneca wisely observed, </span><span class="c32">&ldquo;There are more things to alarm us than to harm us, and we suffer more often in apprehension than reality.&rdquo;</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">By focusing on the present moment, we can see through these illusions and realize that much of our suffering comes from anticipating what may never happen. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Consider this approach: </span><span class="c8">Instead of letting fear dictate our thoughts, we can choose to breathe deeply, stay grounded, and trust in our resilience. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Your Challenge:</span><span>&nbsp;Let go of your imagined fears, and embrace the peace that comes with living in the now.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10 c17">Anxiety (mild), stress, worry, upset, not mindful , nature, relaxation </span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.1ojhgv7yjjq8"><span class="c12">Walk Mindfully in Nature to Relax</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">When anxiety, worry, or stress takes over, a mindful walk in nature can be a soothing remedy. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Consider this technique:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;As you walk, immerse yourself in the sights, sounds, and smells around you. Focus on the experience of the moment, not the destination.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>As Thich Nhat Hanh beautifully puts it, </span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&ldquo;Take my hand. We will walk. We will only walk. We will enjoy our walk without thinking of arriving anywhere.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">This mindfulness practice helps you connect with the present, letting go of worries and finding peace in the simple act of walking.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Your Challenge</span><span class="c43">:</span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">The next time you feel overwhelmed, take a walk in nature. Pay attention to the details around you, letting each step bring you back to the present moment. Remember, allow yourself to walk without a goal, just enjoy the journey.</span></p><h1 class="c26 c7" id="h.1ojhgv7yjjq8-1"><span class="c12"></span></h1><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10 c17">Anxiety (mild), </span><span class="c10">Anxious to perform, Anxious to achieve, </span><span class="c10 c17">angst, &nbsp;stress, worry, worked up, yoga, &nbsp;rumination </span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.a658kxkz0f8"><span>Consider</span><span class="c12">&nbsp;Yoga to Reduce Anxiety &amp; Stress.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Yoga is a powerful practice that has been shown to help reduce anxiety and stress. &nbsp;It also offers numerous other benefits for both body and mind. If you&rsquo;re curious about whether yoga is right for you, then it&rsquo;s worth exploring further.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Starting with a supervised in-person class is ideal, as it provides guidance and ensures you&rsquo;re practicing safely. However, if that&rsquo;s not possible, there are many excellent online resources available.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">&nbsp;Consider researching and trying an in person yoga class in your area. See how it affects your anxiety and stress levels. If this is not possible, consider exploring other options including online classes. Always take into consideration your health and fitness to select the style and level that is appropriate for you. &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Another online option is learning basic or beginner Yoga by youtube such as Yoga With Adriene on YouTube. There are a variety of beginner-friendly sessions to help you get started on your yoga journey. Search out what is most appropriate for you. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c71"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.youtube.com/user/yogawithadriene&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586309986216&amp;usg=AOvVaw2zH7ZEMyE13nztC65MQOPb">Yoga With Adriene - YouTube</a></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10">Angst, </span><span class="c10 c17">Anxiety ( mild), stress, worry, not proactive, </span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c122 c45 c36 c61" id="h.ofwyf85mqojo"><span class="c12">Take some Action to Help Reduce Anxiety.</span></h1><p class="c66 c45 c36"><span class="c8 c36">When anxiety feels overwhelming, even taking a small step forward in action or decision making can make a big difference. </span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36"><span class="c36">Action helps to break the cycle of worry and brings a sense of control over your situation. As Walter Anderson wisely said,</span><span class="c18 c17">&nbsp;&ldquo;Nothing diminishes anxiety faster than action.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36"><span class="c8 c36">By focusing on what you can do today, no matter how small, you can begin to reduce your anxiety and move toward a calmer state of mind.</span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36"><span class="c36 c43">Your challenge</span><span class="c36 c43">: </span><span class="c8 c36">Reflect on one small step you can take today to address whatever is causing your anxiety. Then, take that action. </span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36"><span class="c8 c36">Whether it&#39;s making a phone call, organizing a space, or starting a project, moving forward can help ease your mind and reduce your anxiety.</span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10">Not proactive, angst, a</span><span class="c10 c17">nxiety ( mild), stress, worry, worked up, </span><span class="c10">optimistic</span><span class="c33 c10 c17">, rumination</span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><h1 class="c34 c45 c36 c61" id="h.j26aq1k6h38y"><span class="c12">Overcome Anxiety with Positivity &amp; Planning.</span></h1><p class="c34 c45 c36"><span class="c8 c36">Anticipating a positive outcome can help you overcome anxiety. When you focus on a hopeful vision for the future and back it up with a well-thought-out plan, you shift from fear to anticipation.</span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36"><span class="c36">As the motivational speaker and entrepreneur Jim Rohn said, </span><span class="c18 c17">&ldquo;The reason why most people face the future with apprehension instead of anticipation is because they don&#39;t have it well designed!&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36"><span class="c8 c36">Remember, having a positive plan&mdash;especially one you feel excited about&mdash;can replace anxiety with motivation and confidence.</span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36"><span class="c36 c43">Your challenge</span><span class="c36 c43">: </span><span class="c8 c36">Take some time today to design a plan for something you&rsquo;re enthusiastic about. Focus on positive outcomes and steps you can take to make them a reality. </span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36"><span class="c8 c36">This forward-thinking approach can help reduce your anxiety and replace it with eager anticipation for what lies ahead.</span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10">Angst, </span><span class="c10 c17">stress, worry, worked up, rumination, </span><span class="c10">anxiety (mild), anxious to perform, </span><span class="c10 c17">&nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.blm5vb99a3h4"><span class="c12">Talk Over Your Worries with a Trusted Friend.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">When anxiety or stress begins to feel overwhelming, talking to someone you trust can be incredibly helpful. Sharing your concerns with a trusted friend, family member, or mentor can provide relief and clarity. It&#39;s important to choose someone who can be both objective and encouraging, offering a balanced perspective.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Start with this approach</span><span class="c8">: Assess who in your circle you can turn to for support. Who do you trust to listen and help you explore your options?</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Your challenge</span><span class="c43">:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Reach out to someone you trust and ask if they have time to talk. Use the conversation to brainstorm solutions and gain another perspective. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Sometimes, just hearing your thoughts out loud in the form of a conversation can help you see things more clearly and reduce your anxiety.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10 c17">Stress, </span><span class="c10">worry, anxiety, </span><span class="c33 c10 c17">angst, overwhelm,</span></p><h1 class="c31 c36 c61" id="h.7t56ysxg2hw7"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Try this </span><span>V</span><span class="c12">isualization technique for worry or stress. </span></h1><p class="c31 c36"><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;A visualization technique with a meditative component can help with anxiety, </span><span>stress</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;or </span><span>worry</span><span class="c17 c40">. Have you tried this before? There are many variations of this that you might want </span><span>to explore. </span></p><p class="c31 c36"><span class="c43">Consider this technique</span><span class="c39 c17">: </span><span class="c70 c17 c43 c149">&nbsp; </span></p><ul class="c41 lst-kix_ocpmjw9dekrx-0 start"><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Find a suitable quiet place to sit or lie down. Close your eyes and take a few deep breaths.</span></li></ul><p class="c1 c7 c24"><span class="c8"></span></p><ul class="c41 lst-kix_ocpmjw9dekrx-0"><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Once you&#39;re feeling relaxed, allow your thoughts to drift towards whatever is causing you stress.</span></li><li class="c31 c79 c36 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">&nbsp;As you focus on the source of your stress, imagine a white light surrounding it.The light represents peace and calm.</span></li><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Allow this light to fill your entire body, and visualize it dissipating stress and anxiety</span></li></ul><p class="c1 c7 c24"><span class="c8"></span></p><ul class="c41 lst-kix_ocpmjw9dekrx-0"><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c8">Open your eyes and take a few more deep breaths. Notice &nbsp;feeling more relaxed and in control.</span></li></ul><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c12"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10 c17">Angst, stress, anxiety (mild) , worry, worked up, rumination </span></p><h1 class="c34 c45 c61" id="h.oh365lj90dqs"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Having a little anxiety can increase performance.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Anxiety often gets a bad reputation, but did you know that a certain level of it can actually be beneficial? This concept is known as &ldquo;eustress&rdquo;. This refers to positive stress that can enhance your performance.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Imagine a graph where performance is measured on the vertical axis and anxiety on the horizontal axis. As anxiety increases, performance initially improves, reaching a peak at a &#39;sweet spot.&#39; This sweet spot represents the optimal level of anxiety that motivates and energizes you to perform at your best. Beyond this point, however, too much anxiety can overwhelm you and cause performance to decline.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">So, anxiety isn&rsquo;t always our enemy! When managed well, it can drive us to excel, pushing us to take on challenges with focus and determination. The key is to find that balance&mdash;enough anxiety to keep you sharp, but not so much that it becomes debilitating. Recognizing and harnessing this sweet spot can turn anxiety into a powerful tool for success.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c276"></span></p><p class="c97 c250 c134 c45 c79 c36"><span style="overflow: hidden; display: inline-block; margin: 0.00px 0.00px; border: 0.00px solid #000000; transform: rotate(0.00rad) translateZ(0px); -webkit-transform: rotate(0.00rad) translateZ(0px); width: 601.70px; height: 366.67px;"><img alt="The relationship between anxiety and performance" src="images/image3.png" style="width: 601.70px; height: 366.67px; margin-left: 0.00px; margin-top: 0.00px; transform: rotate(0.00rad) translateZ(0px); -webkit-transform: rotate(0.00rad) translateZ(0px);" title=""></span></p><p class="c97 c134 c45 c79 c36 c250"><span class="c71 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.psychologytools.com/self-help/anxiety/&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586310000505&amp;usg=AOvVaw35ftftcQWQZdZsLD19ZAMD">Anxiety | Psychology Tools</a></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7 c24"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c97 c1"><span class="c10">anxiety ( mild), anxious to achieve, a</span><span class="c10 c17">ngst, stress, &nbsp;worry, </span><span class="c10">fear,</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.vxif70i1crix"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Accept that some anxiety </span><span>&amp;</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">&nbsp;bodily </span><span>reactions</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">&nbsp;can be normal. </span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">It is not realistic to feel peaceful and happy all the time. Unexpected and unwanted things do happen. Our body will then feel mildly uncomfortable at times as a consequence. Perhaps you will feel that in your chest or your stomach. Or perhaps there will be tension in your throat or neck? </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">If we become over-concerned about natural bodily sensations or think some catastrophe is imminent, we trigger more adrenaline release. We can then become even more anxious.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>However, i</span><span class="c8">t&#39;s also important to recognize what is unusual for us or out of character and seek appropriate expert help. &nbsp; </span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c97 c1"><span class="c10 c17">A</span><span class="c10">nxiety ( mild)</span><span class="c10 c17">, stress, worry, </span><span class="c10">angst, </span><span class="c10 c17">worked up, not relaxation </span></p><h1 class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36 c61" id="h.x5jjkx4nxha0"><span class="c12">Self-Soothe by Focusing on Your Five Senses.</span></h1><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36"><span class="c20 c17">One effective way to relax and ease anxiety is by shifting your attention to your five senses: sight, smell, touch, taste, and hearing. By fully engaging with your sensory experiences, you can release the mental narrative that fuels anxiety and instead immerse yourself in the present moment. Give this a try. </span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36"><span class="c58 c43">Consider this technique:</span><span class="c20 c17">&nbsp;Focus on the colors and shapes around you, notice the scents in the air, feel the textures of objects, savor any tastes, and listen to the sounds in your environment. Allow yourself to experience these sensations without judgment, just pure awareness.</span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36"><span class="c58 c43">Your challenge:</span><span class="c20 c17">&nbsp;The next time you feel anxious, pause and take a few moments to focus on each of your five senses. Notice what you see, smell, touch, taste, and hear, letting go of any thoughts.</span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36"><span class="c20 c17">&nbsp;As you immerse yourself in the sensory experience, you&rsquo;ll find that your anxiety naturally begins to ease.</span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c97 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c56"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c97 c56 c45"><span class="c10 c17">A</span><span class="c10">nxiety (mild) </span><span class="c10 c17">, stress, </span><span class="c10">worry, </span><span class="c10 c17">anxious to perform</span><span class="c10">, anxious to succeed, </span><span class="c10 c17">&nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c104 c45 c36 c61" id="h.q5vo1bj66w8x"><span class="c12">Reframe Your Anxiety as a Positive Experience.</span></h1><p class="c29 c45 c36"><span class="c8">When faced with anxiety regarding a situation, try to reframe it as a positive experience. By consciously searching for a silver lining, you can shift your mindset from one of fear to one of optimism. </span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36"><span>This simple change in perspective to a more positive one can help your anxiety or angst dissipate. It allows you to approach challenges with anticipation rather than apprehension. As Jim Rohn wisely said, </span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&ldquo;There are two ways to face the future. One way is with apprehension; the other is with anticipation.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36"><span class="c43">Your Challenge</span><span class="c43">: </span><span class="c8">The next time you feel anxious, take a moment to reframe the situation. Ask yourself, &quot;What positive aspect can I find in this?&quot; Focus on how this experience might lead to growth, learning, or new opportunities. </span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36"><span class="c8">This shift in thinking can help transform anxiety into a more manageable and even motivating force.</span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><h1 class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36 c61 c7" id="h.320h2xpkq4g9"><span class="c12"></span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c56"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c97 c56 c45"><span class="c10 c17">Angst, stress, anxiety, anxious to </span><span class="c10">succeed</span><span class="c10 c17">, lacking direction, muddled, worry, anxious to </span><span class="c10">perform</span><span class="c10 c17">, worked up</span></p><h1 class="c97 c56 c45 c61" id="h.za6rmnyhhniv"><span class="c12">Work Out What You Want and Develop a Plan.</span></h1><p class="c97 c56 c45"><span class="c8">When you&#39;re feeling anxious or apprehensive, it can help to focus on what you truly want&mdash;especially if it&#39;s within your control. Spend some time clarifying your goals, then create a plan with small, actionable steps to move toward them.</span></p><p class="c97 c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c97 c56 c45"><span>By taking these steps, you can start to anticipate positive changes rather than fear the unknown. As Jim Rohn said, </span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&ldquo;The reason why most people face the future with apprehension instead of anticipation is because they don&#39;t have it well designed!&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c97 c56 c45 c7"><span class="c33 c10 c17"></span></p><p class="c97 c56 c45"><span class="c43">Your Challenge: </span><span class="c8">Identify one goal you want to achieve that&rsquo;s within your control. Break it down into small, manageable steps, and start taking action today. </span></p><p class="c97 c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c97 c56 c45"><span class="c8">As you move forward towards your goal, you&rsquo;ll likely find that your apprehension eases, replaced by a sense of anticipation and purpose.</span></p><p class="c97 c56 c45 c7"><span class="c33 c10 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c4"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c3 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; HIGH</span></p><p class="c97 c1"><span class="c10 c17">Angst, stress, anxious, worry, worked up, rumination, letting go , detachment </span></p><h1 class="c97 c1 c61" id="h.e04ikyamtblr"><span class="c12">Accept Anxiety as Part of the Human Experience.</span></h1><p class="c97 c1"><span class="c8">Anxiety is an inevitable part of being human. Rather than trying to eliminate it entirely, it&#39;s important to learn how to live with it and manage it effectively.</span></p><p class="c97 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c97 c1"><span>As Paulo Coelho wisely noted, </span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&ldquo;Anxiety was born in the very same moment as mankind. And since we will never be able to master it, we will have to learn to live with it&mdash;just as we have learned to live with storms.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c97 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c97 c1"><span class="c8">Understanding that anxiety is a natural part of life can help you approach it with more acceptance and less resistance.</span></p><p class="c97 c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c97 c1"><span class="c43">Your challenge</span><span class="c43">: </span><span class="c8">The next time you feel anxious, remind yourself that it&rsquo;s a normal part of life.
