This book offers mindfulness practices that can support your journey towards assertiveness.</span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c64">{M:LATE}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c29 c45"><span class="c10">Not Assertiveness, appeasing,</span><span>&nbsp;</span><span class="c10">acquiescence, kowtowing, </span><span>&nbsp;</span><span class="c27">no boundaries,</span><span class="c10">&nbsp;codependency, </span><span class="c27">passive, timid, </span><span class="c33 c10 c17">no relationship IQ</span></p><h1 class="c104 c45 c61" id="h.knnjn7tavg0l"><span>Overcome Unhealthy</span><span class="c12">&nbsp;Submissiveness.</span></h1><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c8">Do you often find yourself struggling to assert your needs, feeling guilty when you say no. Or do you constantly try to please others at the expense of your own well-being? If so, you are not alone. Many people experience unhealthy submissiveness, which can lead to low self-esteem, stress, and dissatisfaction in relationships. </span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c8">Fortunately, there are resources available to help you overcome these challenges and develop a healthier, more assertive approach to life. Here are some highly recommended books that can guide you on this journey:</span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c43">The Assertiveness Workbook </span><span class="c8">by Randy J. Paterson</span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c8">This workbook provides practical exercises and techniques to help you express your ideas and stand up for yourself, both at work and in personal relationships.</span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c70 c39 c17"></span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c43">When I Say No, I Feel Guilty </span><span class="c8">by Manuel J. Smith</span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c8">A classic guide that teaches assertiveness skills and helps you stand up for yourself without feeling guilty.</span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c70 c39 c17"></span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c43">The Disease to Please </span><span class="c8">by Harriet B. Braiker</span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c8">This book delves into the causes of people-pleasing behaviors and offers strategies for overcoming the need to please, helping you develop a healthier sense of self.</span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c43">Boundaries</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;by Dr. Henry Cloud and Dr. John Townsend</span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c8">Learn how to establish and maintain personal boundaries to protect your emotional well-being and assert your needs.</span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c43">Radical Acceptance </span><span class="c8">by Tara Brach</span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c8">This book combines mindfulness and self-compassion practices to help you accept yourself, develop self-esteem, and overcome unhealthy submissiveness.</span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c43">Your Perfect Right </span><span class="c8">by Robert Alberti and Michael L. Emmons</span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c8">A comprehensive guide to assertiveness, covering various aspects of communication, self-esteem, and personal rights.</span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c43">The Art of Everyday Assertiveness</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;by Patrick King</span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c8">Offers practical advice on developing assertiveness in everyday situations, with examples and techniques for standing up for yourself and setting healthy boundaries.</span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c8">By exploring these books and applying the exercises and concepts they present, you can develop the skills necessary to overcome unhealthy submissiveness. </span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c188 c45 c7"><span class="c33 c36 c182 c214"></span></p><p class="c188 c45"><span class="c36 c182 c214">&nbsp;</span><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c97 c98 c45 c79"><span class="c10">Not </span><span class="c10 c17">Assertiveness, appeasing, kowtowing, yielding, not boundary setting &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.1lzcqphpg6du"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Try these strategies to deal with high conflict people. </span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">Dealing with high-conflict people can be challenging and often requires a nuanced approach. The aim </span><span>is not to react but instead to</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;</span><span>respond in a calm but assertive way:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c39 c17 c25">&nbsp;Here are </span><span class="c43 c25">6</span><span class="c39 c17 c25">&nbsp;strategies</span><span class="c43 c25">&nbsp;for</span><span class="c39 c17 c25">&nbsp;interacti</span><span class="c43 c25">ng</span><span class="c39 c17 c25">&nbsp;with </span><span class="c43 c25">difficult people</span><span class="c156 c39 c17 c25">:</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><ol class="c41 lst-kix_fi2fi7zijstc-0 start" start="1"><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c39 c17">Stay Calm:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;High-conflict people often thrive on emotional reactions. Keeping a calm and controlled demeanor can prevent the situation from escalating.</span></li></ol><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c70 c39 c17"></span></p><ol class="c41 lst-kix_fi2fi7zijstc-0" start="2"><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c39 c17">Set Boundaries:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Clearly define what is acceptable behavior and what isn&rsquo;t. Stick to these boundaries and enforce them consistently.</span></li></ol><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c70 c39 c17"></span></p><ol class="c41 lst-kix_fi2fi7zijstc-0" start="3"><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c39 c17">Don&rsquo;t Take it Personally:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;High-conflict individuals often project their issues onto others. Recognize that their behavior is about them, not you.</span></li></ol><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c70 c39 c17"></span></p><ol class="c41 lst-kix_fi2fi7zijstc-0" start="4"><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c39 c17">Use Reflective Listening:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Show that you are listening and trying to understand their perspective without necessarily agreeing or disagreeing. This can be done by summarizing what they&rsquo;ve said and reflecting it back to them.</span></li></ol><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c70 c39 c17"></span></p><ol class="c41 lst-kix_fi2fi7zijstc-0" start="5"><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c39 c17">Focus on Problem-Solving:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Shift the conversation from blame to finding a solution. Ask questions like, &ldquo;How can we resolve this?&rdquo; rather than getting stuck on who is right or wrong.</span></li></ol><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c70 c39 c17"></span></p><ol class="c41 lst-kix_fi2fi7zijstc-0" start="6"><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c39 c17">Choose Your Battles: </span><span class="c8">Decide if the issue is important enough to stand your ground. Sometimes it may be better to disengage if the conflict isn&rsquo;t worth your time or will only lead to further issues.</span></li></ol><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Remember that you cannot control how others behave, only how you respond to them.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c97 c98 c45 c79"><span class="c10">Not </span><span class="c10 c17">Assertiveness, no boundary setting</span><span class="c10">, </span><span class="c10 c17">appeasing, kowtowing, yielding </span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.wqfl51zch66d"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Additional strategies in dealing with difficult people. </span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">Dealing with difficult or high-conflict people can be challenging. The aim is not to </span><span>r</span><span class="c8">eact, but to to remain calm and assertive. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c39 c17 c25">Here are more strategies </span><span class="c43 c25">to deal with difficult people</span><span class="c156 c39 c17 c25">:</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c39 c17">Use &ldquo;I&rdquo; Statements:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;When discussing issues, use statements that focus on your feelings rather than accusatory &ldquo;you&rdquo; statements. For example, &ldquo;I feel frustrated when&hellip;&rdquo; instead of &ldquo;You always&hellip;&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c70 c39 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c39 c17">Seek to De-escalate:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Reduce the intensity of the interaction by speaking softly, acknowledging the other person&rsquo;s feelings, and demonstrating your willingness to find common ground.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c70 c39 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c39 c17">Be Assertive, Not Aggressive:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Assert your views respectfully and firmly without being aggressive. High-conflict people respect strength and are more likely to back down if they see you are not easily bullied or manipulated.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c70 c39 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c39 c17">Document Interactions:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;If necessary, especially in a work environment, keep records of your interactions in case you need to report behavior or address issues formally.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c70 c39 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c39 c17">Limit Interaction:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Minimize your exposure to the high-conflict person when possible. If you do not need to engage with them, it may be best to avoid unnecessary contact.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c70 c39 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c39 c17">Seek Support:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Talk to friends, family, or professionals who can offer support and advice. They can provide an outside perspective that can help you see the situation more clearly.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c70 c39 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c39 c17">Consider Professional Help:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;If the high-conflict individual is a colleague or someone you must interact with regularly and the situation is affecting your well-being, it might be useful to consult a mediator, a human resources professional, or a counselor.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c70 c39 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c39 c17">Practice Self-care:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Dealing with high-conflict individuals can be exhausting. Ensure you are taking care of your physical and emotional health.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c70 c39 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c39 c17">Educate Yourself: </span><span class="c8">There are many resources and books available on dealing with high-conflict people. Learning more about their behavior can give you the tools and understanding you need to interact with them more effectively.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Dealing with high-conflict people can be difficult, but by using these strategies, you can often minimize stress and conflict. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c97 c45 c79 c7 c98"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c14 c30"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c14 c30"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c27">No boundaries &nbsp;Not Assertiveness, Not yourself,</span><span class="c17 c27">&nbsp;Codependency, </span><span class="c27">Not autonomous, </span><span class="c17 c27">&nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.cxq19vei8pcx"><span class="c12">Take Control of Your Life: Start by setting Boundaries.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">If you&rsquo;re looking to take control of your life, understanding and setting boundaries is key. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Boundaries are the limits we set to protect ourselves&mdash;physically, emotionally, and mentally. They help define who we are and create a healthy balance in relationships. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">By establishing clear boundaries, you can take responsibility for your own choices and actions, allowing you to focus on managing your life rather than trying to control others.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Your challenge</span><span class="c43">: </span><span class="c8">Reflect on areas in your life where boundaries are lacking and start making changes to protect your well-being.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>Recommended </span><span>Reading: </span><span class="c43">Boundaries: When to Say Yes, How to Say No to Take Control of Your Life</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;by Dr. Henry Cloud and Dr. John Townsend,</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c33 c10 c17">Overloaded, overwhelmed, not boundary setting, not assertive, not wellbeing, neglecting yourself , not self care, &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.5b1qis7lrm4o"><span class="c12">Learn to Say No: Protect Your Well-Being.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span>Recognize the</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;importance of saying &lsquo;no&rsquo; when required. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Saying &lsquo;no&rsquo; is essential for maintaining healthy boundaries. This prevents you from taking on too much responsibility, and allows you to focus on your own needs. This small word can make a huge difference in your ability to manage your time and energy effectively.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Your challenge</span><span class="c43">:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Next time you&rsquo;re asked to take on an extra task, consider whether it aligns with your priorities. Practice saying no, knowing it&rsquo;s a step toward healthier boundaries.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>&nbsp;Resource: </span><span class="c43">Boundaries: When to Say Yes, How to Say No to Take Control of Your Life </span><span class="c8">by Dr. Henry Cloud and Dr. John Townsend </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c33 c10 c17">Relationship IQ, Jeopardizing relationships, no boundary setting, not assertive, &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.30frwiyeynx0"><span class="c12">Respect Boundaries: Build Stronger Relationships.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span>It&#39;s</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;important to respect others&rsquo; boundaries as well as to guard your own. Recognize that healthy relationships thrive on mutual respect, and this includes recognizing and honoring the personal limits of those around you. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">By respecting boundaries, you foster trust and understanding, which are essential for strong, balanced relationships.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Your Challenge:</span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">Reflect on how you interact with others&mdash;are you respecting their boundaries? Make a conscious effort to honor their limits, and see how it positively impacts your relationships. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>Resource:</span><span class="c43">&nbsp;Boundaries: When to Say Yes, How to Say No to Take Control of Your Life, </span><span class="c8">Dr. Henry Cloud and Dr. John Townsend</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c33 c10 c17">burned out, compassion fatigue, No wellbeing, guilty feeling, not boundary setting, not assertive </span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.qxcaa2wxxswg"><span class="c12">Empower Yourself: Learn to Say No Without Guilt.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span>Remember that s</span><span class="c8">aying &lsquo;no&rsquo; is one of the most effective ways to protect your time, energy, and well-being. It&rsquo;s not about being selfish; it&rsquo;s about recognizing your limits and honoring them. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">When you learn to say &lsquo;no&rsquo;, you prevent burnout and create space for the things that truly matter in your life.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Your Challenge</span><span class="c43">:</span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">Next time someone asks you to take on an extra task, pause and consider whether it aligns with your priorities. If it doesn&rsquo;t, practice saying &lsquo;no&rsquo; politely but firmly.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c33 c10 c17">Not respect, not relationship IQ, not social skills, not boundary setting </span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.q603xghkmw9h"><span class="c12">Build Stronger Relationships: Respect Boundaries.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Healthy relationships thrive on mutual respect, and that includes respecting each other&#39;s boundaries. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">By honoring the limits set by others, you create a foundation of trust and understanding. This not only prevents conflicts but also strengthens the bond you share with others.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Your challenge: </span><span class="c8">Take a moment to think about the boundaries of those around you&mdash;whether it&rsquo;s a friend, family member, or colleague. Make a conscious effort to respect their limits, and observe how it positively impacts your relationship.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c27">Not </span><span class="c17 c27">Assertiveness, not &nbsp;boundaries, controlled</span><span class="c27">&nbsp;easily, </span><span class="c17 c27">&nbsp;kowtowing, appeasing, not resp</span><span class="c27">ect </span><span class="c17 c27">&nbsp; </span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.n2kj6v6viojq"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Stand up for yourself. </span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">In a world that often feels dominated by overbearing individuals and overpowering structures, it can sometimes feel like we are being walked all over. </span><span>However </span><span class="c17 c40">Brian </span><span>Weir reminds us that:</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;</span><span class="c142 c17">&ldquo;In order to be walked on, you have to be lying down</span><span class="c142">.</span><span class="c33 c142 c17">&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>So, it&#39;s important</span><span>&nbsp;to</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;</span><span>stand</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;up for ourselves and </span><span>maintain</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;our self-respect.</span><span>&nbsp;We need to</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;both express our opinions, and set </span><span>boundaries, but this</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;doesn&rsquo;t mean being aggressive or confrontational</span><span>. We can</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;</span><span>assert</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;our needs and rights in a respectful manner.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>Recognize that a</span><span class="c8">llowing others to walk all over us erodes our self-respect. It sends the message, both to ourselves and others, that our needs, opinions, and rights are not important. Conversely, standing up for ourselves and asserting our needs helps to build our self-respect and sends the message that we value ourselves.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c21 c167">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c27">not boundaries, Not </span><span class="c17 c27">Assertiveness, controlled </span><span class="c27">easily</span><span class="c17 c27">&nbsp;, kowtowing, appeasing &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.7l016mckt7cw"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Learn about the </span><span>importance</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">&nbsp;of Boundaries.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Boundaries are the invisible walls we erect around ourselves, the unspoken guidelines we establish in our relationships and interactions. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Think of boundaries as the protective barriers between our individual worlds and the rest of the universe. Contrary to the notion that boundaries create a divide, they can actually be a bridge to healthier connections and mutual respect. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>Understand that b</span><span class="c17 c40">y setting boundaries, we&rsquo;re not merely pulling away from discomfort but purposefully shaping the environment we exist in</span><span>. This helps ensure</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;our mental well-being and emotional safety.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c72">{M:EARLY}</span><span class="c21 c167">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c27">not boundaries, Not </span><span class="c17 c27">Assertiveness, controlled, kowtowing, appeasing &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.ohev0fh3wkhn"><span class="c12">Understand why Boundaries matter.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">We&#39;ve all been in a situation where someone&rsquo;s words or actions have left us feeling uncomfortable or undervalued. This discomfort can be a result of boundaries being crossed. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">When we set clear boundaries, it&#39;s a proclamation of how we wish to be treated. This not only empowers us but also educates those around us about our values, limits, and expectations. </span><span>Think of boundary setting as </span><span class="c8">a proactive approach against miscommunication, resentment, and codependency. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Remember, boundaries aren&rsquo;t just about self-defense, they&#39;re about self-respect too.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp; &nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c27">not &nbsp;boundaries, Not </span><span class="c17 c27">Assertiveness, controlled, kowtowing, appeasing &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.d8zet9gjjzr6"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Practice setting Boundaries which are &lsquo;just right&rsquo;.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span>Remember</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;to ensure th</span><span>at the boundaries we choose </span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;are neither too rigid nor too </span><span>weak</span><span class="c8">.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">&nbsp;Boundaries that are too loose can often be trampled upon, leading to feelings of resentment. On the flip side, overly strict boundaries can alienate us from others. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">The perfect boundary is a well-balanced one: clear, decisive, and based on genuine needs. It allows us to stay authentic and connects us deeply with those we care about, without the fear of being undervalued.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c27">not boundaries, Not </span><span class="c17 c27">Assertiveness, controlled easily, kowtowing, appeasing &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.gw8skrs07ml0"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Navigate the tricky waters of </span><span>&lsquo;B</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">oundary </span><span>S</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">etting</span><span>&rsquo;</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span>Setting &lsquo;b</span><span class="c17 c40">oundaries</span><span>&rsquo;</span><span class="c17 c40">&nbsp;can be tricky. They can be misunderstood, seen as rigid, or considered as barriers. </span><span>I</span><span class="c8">t&rsquo;s important to understand that their core purpose is not to separate us from the world, but to facilitate healthier interactions within it.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">&nbsp;Whether it&#39;s asking a colleague not to disturb you during a certain hour or telling a friend that certain topics are off-limits, these boundaries can lead to mutual understanding and respect. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">The key is to communicate our boundaries effectively and be willing to adjust when necessary. Always keep in mind the ultimate goal: protecting our well-being and fostering meaningful connections.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c27">Conflict resolution, </span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.jko5vjg0ul03"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Learn how to navigate aggressio</span><span>n</span><span class="c12">.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">Dealing with aggressive or passive-aggressive individuals can often feel like treading on thin ice. However, by arming ourselves with tactful responses, we can maneuver through such situations with grace and confidence. Here are </span><span>three examples:</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">When faced with veiled insults or blatant aggression, asking &quot;Could you clarify what you mean by that?&quot; can help defuse the situation, making the aggressor either explain themselves or back down.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Responding with &ldquo;I understand your perspective, but I see it differently&rdquo; can establish a boundary, showing that you respect their viewpoint but have your own opinions too.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Offering a compassionate response like, &ldquo;It seems like you&rsquo;re going through a lot,&rdquo; can sometimes disarm the aggression, leading to a more productive conversation.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span><span class="c5">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c27">Conflict resolution,</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.wvt1n2wnx1zz"><span class="c37 c17 c25">Be the Calm: Respond to aggression with poise.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c40">In the face of aggression or passive-aggressiveness, maintaining a cool demeanor is a skill that can transform confrontations into constructive dialogues. Here are </span><span>3</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;useful techniques:</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><ol class="c41 lst-kix_hm4pff3em3kg-0 start" start="1"><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c17 c25 c40">Be Assertive yet Respectful:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Saying &ldquo;I value your opinion, but I have my own views on this matter&rdquo; displays assertiveness without being confrontational, promoting a respectful exchange.</span></li></ol><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><ol class="c41 lst-kix_hm4pff3em3kg-0" start="2"><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c17 c25 c40">Use Gratitude Over Grudges:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Acknowledging with &ldquo;Thank you for sharing your thoughts,&rdquo; can be a gentle way to ease the tension while not necessarily agreeing with the aggressive remarks.</span></li></ol><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><ol class="c41 lst-kix_hm4pff3em3kg-0" start="3"><li class="c1 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c17 c25 c40">Maintain the Focus: </span><span class="c8">Steering the conversation back to the main topic with, &ldquo;Let&rsquo;s stay focused on the issue,&rdquo; can help bypass the drama and keep the discussion productive.</span></li></ol><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c54 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c64">{A:LATE}</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c10">Not </span><span class="c10 c17">Assertive, not </span><span class="c10">brave, not courage, </span><span class="c10 c17">&nbsp;justice, &nbsp;acquiescence , kowtowing yaklike , yoked , </span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.d3nthchjq36t"><span class="c12">Speak Up to Challenge Injustice.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Building assertiveness can involve standing up for what&rsquo;s right, even when the odds seem stacked against you.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>&nbsp;As Jessica Mitford said,</span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&nbsp;&ldquo;You may not be able to change the world, but at least you can embarrass the guilty.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Speaking up against wrongdoing, whether big or small, asserts your values and strengthens your confidence. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">When you confront injustice, you not only assert your own dignity but also inspire others to do the same. Whether it&rsquo;s speaking up in a meeting or correcting misinformation, take a stand and notice how it empowers you.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c10">Not boundary setting, Not </span><span class="c10 c17">Assertive, acquiescence , yielding, not wellbeing </span></p><h1 class="c22 c61" id="h.7f3ooojpcomf"><span class="c12">Set Firm Boundaries to Protect Your Well-Being.</span></h1><p class="c22"><span class="c8">It&#39;s important to remember that setting firm boundaries is an act of self-care, not selfishness. </span></p><p class="c22"><span class="c8">For example, you might consider yourself kind-hearted, but without clear boundaries, you risk others overstepping or taking advantage of your generosity. This can lead to exhaustion and burnout from constantly giving without replenishing your own energy.</span></p><p class="c22"><span>&nbsp;As Rachel Wolchin wisely noted, </span><span class="c32">&ldquo;Givers need to set limits because takers rarely do.&rdquo; </span><span class="c8">By establishing boundaries, you protect your well-being and ensure that your kindness remains sustainable.</span></p><p class="c22"><span class="c43">Your challenge:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Reflect on where your boundaries might be too loose. Choose one area where you can set a clear limit, and observe how it positively impacts your energy and peace of mind.</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c22 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c10 c36">Triggered, reactive, </span><span class="c10">defensive, </span><span class="c10 c17">anger,</span><span class="c0">&nbsp;conflict resolution, </span></p><h1 class="c34 c45 c61" id="h.fbxkilb708j"><span class="c12">Stay Calm: Don&rsquo;t Let Others&rsquo; Anger Trigger You.</span></h1><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c36">When faced with someone else&rsquo;s anger, it&rsquo;s easy to react impulsively or defensively with your own. But before you respond, consider this wisdom from Bohdi Sanders: </span><span class="c18 c17">&quot;Never respond to an angry person with a fiery comeback, even if he deserves it... Don&#39;t allow his anger to become your anger,&quot;.</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c8 c36">&nbsp;By keeping your cool, you maintain control over your emotions and prevent their anger from dictating your response. This not only preserves your peace but also de-escalates the situation.</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c36 c43">Your challenge</span><span class="c36 c43">: </span><span class="c8 c36">The next time you encounter someone&rsquo;s anger, take a deep breath and pause before responding. Choose a calm, measured response that reflects your composure, not their rage.</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c22 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c10">Not boundary setting, not a</span><span class="c10 c17">ssertive, appeasing, &nbsp;acquiescence , kowtowing, yaklike, yoked, yielding, codependency, enmeshed, </span></p><h1 class="c22 c61" id="h.2wcd3hdtl96m"><span class="c12">Embrace Your Right to Say &#39;No&#39;.</span></h1><p class="c22"><span>Realize </span><span>that you have the right to simply say &#39;No.&#39; It&#39;s a powerful assertion of your boundaries and needs. As Annie Lamott succinctly puts it, </span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&quot;&#39;No&#39; is a complete sentence.&quot; </span></p><p class="c22"><span class="c8">Understand that you don&rsquo;t owe anyone an explanation or justification for protecting your time, energy, or well-being. Saying &#39;No&#39; confidently allows you to stay true to yourself and prioritize what truly matters to you.</span></p><p class="c22"><span class="c43">Your Challenge</span><span class="c43">:</span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">Practice saying &#39;No&#39; without guilt or apology. Remind yourself that it&#39;s a valid response and a necessary part of self-care.</span></p><p class="c22 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c22 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c10">Not boundary setting, Not </span><span class="c10 c17">Assertive, appeasing, &nbsp;acquiescence , kowtowing, yaklike, yoked, yielding, codependency, enmeshed, </span></p><h1 class="c22 c61" id="h.kk6etr2y5ts2"><span class="c12">Stand Firm with your &ldquo;No&rdquo;: An Explanation is NOT Needed.</span></h1><p class="c22"><span class="c8">When you say &#39;No,&#39; there&rsquo;s no need to explain or justify your decision. Over-explaining can open the door for more forceful personalities to challenge your reasoning and pressure you to change your mind. A simple, confident &#39;No&#39; is often all that&rsquo;s required to assert your boundaries and maintain control over your choices.</span></p><p class="c22"><span class="c43">Your challenge</span><span class="c43">:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Practice delivering a clear, straightforward &#39;No&#39; without feeling the need to elaborate. Trust that your decision is enough on its own, and observe how it strengthens your resolve.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c10">Not boundary setting, Not </span><span class="c10 c17">Assertive, not emotional intelligence, appeasing, &nbsp;acquiescence , </span><span class="c10">kowtowing,</span><span class="c10 c17">&nbsp;yaklike, yoked , yielding, codependency, enmeshed, </span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.918id5ojbldf"><span class="c12">Practice setting Healthy Boundaries and Asserting Yourself.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8 c36">People with high Emotional Intelligence (EQ) excel at asserting themselves and establishing clear boundaries. The skill of firm boundary setting not only protects your well-being but also fosters respect in your relationships. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8 c36">Learning to assert your needs and limits is also a powerful habit that contributes to your overall emotional health and personal growth. By doing so, you create a balanced environment where your needs are met without compromising your values or energy.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c36 c43">Your challenge</span><span class="c36 c43">:</span><span class="c36 c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8 c36">Start by identifying a situation where you need to assert yourself. Also practice setting a boundary in a respectful yet firm manner. Notice how this positively impacts your interactions and emotional well-being.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c36 c182"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c188 c45 c7"><span class="c14 c36"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c59 c36">&nbsp;Reactive, triggered, Not </span><span class="c59 c36 c17">Assertive, </span><span class="c59 c36">emotional, </span><span class="c59 c36 c17">angry, vindictive, vendetta, &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c97 c134 c45 c79 c36 c61 c55 c216" id="h.l8dmtb5k5o7m"><span class="c12">Are You Responding Like a True Adult?</span></h1><p class="c97 c56 c134 c45 c79 c36 c55"><span class="c8 c36">Being a responsible adult means going beyond emotional reactions. It involves pausing to assess the situation with intuition, experience, and inner wisdom. Emotional maturity is reflected in how we respond, not react, especially during conflicts.</span></p><p class="c97 c56 c134 c45 c79 c36 c55 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c97 c56 c134 c45 c79 c36 c55"><span class="c36">&nbsp;As David Richo insightfully notes,</span><span class="c18 c17">&nbsp;&ldquo;To be adult in a relationship is not to be conflict-free, it&rsquo;s to resolve conflicts mindfully.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c97 c56 c134 c45 c79 c36 c55"><span class="c8 c36">True adulthood is about handling disagreements with thoughtfulness and care, ensuring your actions align with your best self.</span></p><p class="c97 c56 c134 c45 c79 c36 c55 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c97 c56 c134 c45 c79 c36 c55"><span class="c36 c43">Your challenge</span><span class="c36 c43">: </span><span class="c8 c36">When faced with a conflict, take a step back and reflect before responding. Let your inner wisdom guide you to approach the situation with calmness and intention, aiming for a mindful resolution.</span></p><p class="c97 c216 c134 c45 c79 c36 c55 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c188 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c59 c36">Not </span><span class="c59 c36 c17">Assertive, </span><span class="c59 c36">&nbsp;not setting boundaries, </span><span class="c59 c36 c17">appeasing, passive, avoidant, acquiescence, timid, kowtowing, yesman,</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.30cbs076l0qm"><span class="c12">Standing Strong May Offend&mdash;And That&#39;s Okay.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8 c36">Do you often fear upsetting or offending others? This fear can hold you back from being more assertive and standing up for what you believe in. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c36">Remember the words of Winston Churchill: </span><span class="c18 c17">&ldquo;You have enemies? Good. That means you&#39;ve stood up for something, sometime in your life.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8 c36">Being assertive sometimes means others won&rsquo;t agree with you, and that&rsquo;s a natural part of standing strong. It&rsquo;s a sign that you&rsquo;re living with integrity and courage, even if it ruffles some feathers.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c36 c43">Your challenge</span><span class="c36 c43">:</span><span class="c36 c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8 c36">Reflect on a situation where fear of offending someone held you back. Consider how you might approach it differently, embracing the courage to assert yourself, even if it means some may disagree.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c188 c45 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c33 c59 c36 c17">Assertive, confidence,angry, aggressive, appeasing, passive, avoidant, acquiescence, timid, kowtowing, yesman,</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c36 c17"></span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.8ubzezeh1n62"><span>To avoid hostility u</span><span class="c12">se the word &lsquo;I&rsquo; rather than &lsquo;You&rsquo;.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c36 c17 c40">To be assertive without coming across as hostile, use more &quot;I&quot; statements. Make it a habit to say things like: &quot;I think ... &quot; or &quot;I feel .... &quot;. </span><span class="c36">&nbsp;These &quot;I&quot; statements allow you to be more confident and assertive without alienating others.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c36">Similarly r</span><span class="c8 c36">efrain from aggressive language or phrases like &quot;You never... &quot; or &quot;You always.... &quot; These statements trigger other people, and they become defensive. They might attack back or shut down the conversation.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c36 c17 c40">&nbsp;Give </span><span class="c36">this approach </span><span class="c36 c17 c40">a tr</span><span class="c36">y. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c2"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span></p><p class="c126 c45"><span class="c10">Not </span><span class="c10 c17">Assertive, timid, passive, avoiding </span><span class="c10">conflict, </span><span class="c10 c17">acquiescence, appeasement,</span><span class="c17">&nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26 c36" id="h.enzp39z6tj73"><span class="c12">Step Up and Be More Assertive!</span></h1><p class="c1 c36"><span class="c8">It&#39;s time to step forward, raise your voice, and become more vocal about what matters to you. That&#39;s called being assertive.</span></p><p class="c1 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c36"><span>Being assertive is about taking charge of your life and expressing your thoughts and needs confidently. As Louise Hay encourages us, </span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&quot;Step forward, use your voice, get out in the world, and live!&quot; </span></p><p class="c1 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c36"><span class="c8">Don&rsquo;t just wait for the perfect moment&mdash;embrace the opportunity to be heard and make your presence known. You can still do this politely and respectfully and get your point of view across. &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c36"><span class="c43">Your &nbsp;challenge</span><span class="c43">:</span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">Identify one area in your life where you&rsquo;ve been holding back. Take a bold step today to express yourself, using your voice to assert your needs and live more fully.</span></p><p class="c1 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c129 c77 c25"></span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c129 c77 c25"></span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c129 c77 c25"></span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c77 c25 c129"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c45 c7 c188"><span class="c14 c36"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c115">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span><span class="c33 c10 c123">HIGH</span></p><p class="c126 c45"><span class="c10">Lack of boundaries, Not </span><span class="c10 c17">Assertiveness</span><span class="c10">, not agency, not autonomous,</span><span class="c10 c17">&nbsp;acquiescence, appeasement, approval seeking, timid, passive, learned avoidance, </span></p><h1 class="c104 c45 c36 c61" id="h.5zo38hu12w7b"><span class="c12">Protect Yourself by Strengthening Your Boundaries.</span></h1><p class="c29 c45 c36"><span class="c8">Are you at risk of attracting the wrong people? </span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36"><span class="c8">Poor boundaries and a lack of self-respect can lead to this unfortunate consequence. When you don&rsquo;t value and assert your own needs, you invite others to do the same. </span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36"><span>As Vironika Tugaleva wisely notes,</span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&nbsp;&ldquo;If you do not respect your own wishes, no one else will. You will simply attract people who disrespect you as much as you do.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36"><span class="c8">Enhancing your self respect and your assertiveness skills is key to setting the standard for how others should treat you. You do this in part by maintaining more appropriate boundaries </span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36"><span class="c43">Your challenge</span><span class="c43">:</span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">Reflect on where your boundaries may be too loose. Start by setting one firm boundary today, and notice how it shifts the dynamics in your relationships. </span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36"><span class="c8">Remember this approach will invite respect from others and promote healthier connections.</span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c59 c36">Not </span><span class="c59 c36 c17">Assertive, not boundary setting, &nbsp;avoid</span><span class="c59 c36">ing conflict </span><span class="c59 c36 c17">&nbsp;acquiescence, </span><span class="c59 c36">&nbsp;passive, </span><span class="c59 c36 c17">timid, kowtowing, yesman, guilty feeling</span></p><h1 class="c22 c61" id="h.13l4lr6xtf7t"><span class="c12">Don&rsquo;t Let Guilt Stop You from Being Assertive.</span></h1><p class="c22"><span class="c36">Do you feel</span><span class="c8 c36">&nbsp;guilty when you assert yourself? </span></p><p class="c22"><span class="c8 c36">Remember, saying &quot;no&quot; to a request doesn&rsquo;t mean you&rsquo;re rejecting the person&mdash;it simply means you&rsquo;re declining something that isn&rsquo;t right for you at that time.</span></p><p class="c22"><span class="c8 c36">Being assertive is about respecting your own needs and boundaries, it&rsquo;s not about hurting others. You can assert your needs respectfully. </span></p><p class="c22"><span class="c8 c36">So, let go of the guilt and recognize that prioritizing your well-being is not only valid but necessary.</span></p><p class="c22"><span class="c36 c43">You challenge</span><span class="c36 c43">:</span><span class="c8 c36">&nbsp;The next time you feel guilty for asserting yourself, remind yourself that you&rsquo;re not rejecting the person, just the request. Practice saying &quot;no&quot; kindly but firmly, and observe how it strengthens your self-respect and relationships.</span></p><p class="c22 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c4"></span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c129 c77 c25"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c129 c77 c25"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c59 c36">Not Assertive, not boundary setting, &nbsp;avoiding conflict &nbsp;acquiescence, &nbsp;passive, timid, kowtowing, yesman, guilty feeling</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.xuyyiwjpckz"><span>Find Strength in Balance: Compassion Vs Personal Power.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">In Hindu tradition, the body&rsquo;s seven major energy centers, known as chakras, play a crucial role in our physical and psychological well-being. Among these, the heart chakra, is associated with love and compassion, and the solar plexus chakra, is connected to personal power and self-esteem. These two are particularly important to balance.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">An overactive heart chakra combined with an underactive solar plexus chakra can leave you vulnerable to being taken advantage of. Conversely, if the solar plexus chakra is overly dominant while the heart chakra is weak, it can lead to excessive self-centeredness or even ruthlessness. Achieving a healthy psychological state requires harmony between these two energy centers.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">&#8203;&#8203;Your Challenge:</span><span>&nbsp;Reflect on your own tendencies&mdash;are you too giving or too focused on your own needs? Consider how you can address this. Practices such as meditation or yoga can also help balance both compassion and personal power.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c36">Resource:</span><span class="c59 c36">&nbsp;</span><span>Master yogi Choa Kok Sui, </span><span class="c43"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.goodreads.com/work/quotes/27518703&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586310550167&amp;usg=AOvVaw3cmxXxXZW7gHLIlqkmstxT">The Chakras and their Functions</a></span><span>&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c115">&nbsp; </span><span class="c10 c123">HIGH</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c59 c36">Bullied, not </span><span class="c59 c36 c17">Assertive, passive, avoid</span><span class="c59 c36">ing conflict, </span><span class="c59 c36 c17">acquiescence, appeasement, timid, kowtowing, yesman, learned avoidance,</span></p><h1 class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36 c61" id="h.1awdi4geytz5"><span class="c12">Don&rsquo;t Let Anyone Push You Around: Reclaim Your Power.</span></h1><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36"><span>Stand up for yourself&mdash;be assertive and take back your power. When you allow a bully to intimidate you, you&rsquo;re giving them permission to do it again. As Charles Djou wisely said, </span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&ldquo;If you let a bully intimidate you, he&#39;s going to do it again. You&#39;ve got to stand up to these strong-arm tactics.&rdquo; </span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36"><span class="c8">Assertiveness is however not just about defending yourself in the moment; it&rsquo;s also about setting boundaries that protect your dignity and self-respect.</span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36"><span class="c43">Your challenge: </span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">Practice standing firm in your interactions. Remember that your voice and your boundaries are powerful tools in reclaiming your personal strength.</span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c59 c36">Not </span><span class="c33 c59 c36 c17">Assertive, passive, avoidant, acquiescence, appeasement, timid, kowtowing, yesman, learned avoidance,</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c37 c25">Try A</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">ffirmations to become more </span><span class="c37 c25">A</span><span class="c37 c17 c25">ssertive</span><span class="c37 c25">.</span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36"><span class="c8">Try the affirmation below from motivational author Louise Hay: </span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36 c55"><span class="c32">&lsquo;</span><span class="c32"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.azquotes.com/quote/880141&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586310553008&amp;usg=AOvVaw0_RyZkQyO-MqSa-8jpFga1">I speak up for myself. I claim my power now.</a></span><span class="c32">&rsquo; </span><span class="c32"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.azquotes.com/author/19603-Louise_Hay&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586310553119&amp;usg=AOvVaw3qcW95104E2w8BYaYBeRyv">Louise Hay</a></span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36 c55 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36"><span class="c8">Say this affirmation to yourself a few times. Try this aloud and quietly to yourself. Do this with feeling and conviction. </span></p><p class="c34 c45 c36 c55 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c59 c36">Not Assertive, passive, avoidant, acquiescence, appeasement, timid, kowtowing, yesman, learned avoidance,</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.24hc4pm231lh"><span class="c12">Use Affirmations to Boost Your Assertiveness.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Affirmations are a powerful tool to help you build assertiveness and confidence. By repeating positive statements, you reinforce your belief in your ability to stand up for yourself. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>Motivational author Louise Hay offers various simple yet effective affirmations. For example: </span><span class="c32">&ldquo;I speak up for myself. I claim my power now.&rdquo;</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Say this to yourself a few times, with genuine feeling and conviction, to internalize the message and strengthen your resolve.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Your Challenge</span><span class="c25">:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Make an affirmation part of your daily routine. For example, you could repeat it in front of a mirror each morning. Embrace the words with confidence and belief. Notice how it gradually enhances your assertiveness in everyday situations.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c14 c36"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c14 c36"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c59 c36">Not </span><span class="c59 c36 c17">Assertive, passive, avoidant, acquiescence, timid, kowtowing, yesman,</span></p><h1 class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36 c61" id="h.6otrgj7tzd3q"><span class="c12">Ask Yourself: Why Do I Give Up My Power?</span></h1><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36"><span class="c8">Have you ever wondered why you give up your power so easily? Take a moment to contemplate this. Often, the root cause lies in a belief that you have no power to begin with. </span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36"><span>Novelist Alice Walker offers a profound insight: </span><span class="c32">&ldquo;The most common way people give up their power is by thinking they don&#39;t have any.&rdquo; </span><span class="c8">Recognizing and challenging this false belief can be the first step toward reclaiming your personal strength and asserting yourself with confidence.</span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36"><span class="c43">Your Challenge</span><span class="c43">:</span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">Reflect on situations where you&rsquo;ve given up your power. Ask yourself if it was due to an underlying belief in your own limitations, and consider ways to shift this mindset toward recognizing and embracing your true potential.</span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c59 c36">Not </span><span class="c59 c36 c17">Assertive, passive, avoidant, acquiescence, timid, kowtowing, yesman,</span></p><h1 class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36 c61" id="h.42qdns8ra03h"><span class="c12">Stand Up for Truth: Boost your Assertiveness</span></h1><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36"><span class="c8">Standing up for truth and compassion not only empowers you but also naturally builds your assertiveness. When you become an advocate for what is right, you strengthen your voice and your confidence. This isn&rsquo;t just about personal growth; it&rsquo;s about contributing to a better world.</span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36"><span>&nbsp;As William Faulkner wisely said, </span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&ldquo;Never be afraid to raise your voice for honesty and truth and compassion against injustice and lying and greed. If people all over the world...would do this, it would change the earth.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36"><span class="c43">Your challenge: </span><span class="c8">Start by speaking up for what you believe in, even in small ways. </span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36"><span class="c8">Remember, each time you stand up for truth, you not only empower yourself but also inspire others. This creates a ripple effect that can lead to meaningful change.</span></p><p class="c97 c103 c45 c79 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c59 c36 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c59 c36">Not </span><span class="c59 c36 c17">Assertive, passive, avoid</span><span class="c59 c36">ing conflict </span><span class="c59 c36 c17">, acquiescence, timid, kowtowing, yesman,</span></p><h1 class="c45 c61 c261" id="h.t7pftinb5tg2"><span class="c12">Do You Hold Back From Asking for What You Need?</span></h1><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c20 c17">Many of us have been socially conditioned not to ask for what we need, fearing we might appear greedy or needy. This reluctance can leave us unfulfilled and overlooked. Does this resonate with you?</span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c58">&nbsp;It&rsquo;s important to remember that asking for what you need isn&rsquo;t overreacting&mdash;it&rsquo;s self-care. As Amy Poehler wisely says,</span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&nbsp;&ldquo;It&rsquo;s never overreacting to ask for what you want and need.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c58 c43">Your challenge</span><span class="c58 c43">:</span><span class="c20 c17">&nbsp;Reflect on areas in your life where you&rsquo;ve hesitated to express your needs. Practice asking for what you truly need. Recognize that it&rsquo;s a vital part of honoring yourself and your well-being.</span></p><p class="c45 c7 c76"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c76 c45 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c76 c45 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c115">&nbsp; </span><span class="c10 c123">HIGH</span></p><p class="c76 c45"><span class="c33 c10 c17">Not assertive, not boundaries, forgiveness, not self respect, bullied &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c96 c45 c61" id="h.rk26pdvaq9fa"><span>Understand h</span><span class="c12">ow to &lsquo;Turn the Other Cheek&rsquo;.</span></h1><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c8">Forgiving someone doesn&rsquo;t mean allowing their bad behavior to continue unchecked. True forgiveness can coexist with assertiveness. Do you understand how to do this? </span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c8">You can both forgive the person and stand up for yourself. You clearly communicate that certain behaviors are unacceptable or harmful. </span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span>Yogic Grand Master Choa Kok Sui explains it this way: </span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&ldquo;Although the disciple has internally forgiven the offending person(s), it is still necessary, in some instances, to take actions that may be, to a certain extent severe, in order for the person to learn his lesson and not commit the same serious mistake again. It is also necessary to protect possible future victims.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c43">Your challenge</span><span class="c43">:</span><span>&nbsp;Practice forgiveness internally, but don&rsquo;t shy away from enforcing firm boundaries. Let the other person know that their behavior must change, and take the necessary steps to protect yourself and others from further harm.</span></p><p class="c126 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c45 c7 c126"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10 c17">Assertiveness, not assertive, sensitive, nervy, appeasement, approval seeking, acquiescence, passive, avoidant, </span></p><h1 class="c99 c45 c61" id="h.tprzoz8n5r48"><span class="c12">Let Bad Behavior by Others Fuel Your Assertiveness.</span></h1><p class="c3"><span class="c8 c36">Instead of tolerating bad behavior, use it as a catalyst to strengthen your assertiveness. When you encounter disrespect or bullying, see it as an opportunity to respond with confidence and self-respect. </span></p><p class="c3"><span class="c36">As Nick Vujicic puts it,</span><span class="c18 c17">&nbsp;&ldquo;Bullies want to abuse you. Instead of allowing that, you can use them as your personal motivators. Power up and let the bully eat your dust.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c3"><span class="c36 c43">Your challenge</span><span class="c36 c43">:</span><span class="c36 c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8 c36">The next time someone behaves poorly toward you, take it as a cue to stand up for yourself. Practice assertiveness by responding firmly and positively. There is no need to be aggressive or abusive. Just be assertive. Turn their negativity into your empowerment.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c14 c36"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c14 c36"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c14 c36"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c14 c36"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c10">Not boundaries, Not </span><span class="c33 c10 c17">Assertiveness, codependence, approval seeking, acquiescence, bullied </span></p><p class="c1 c7 c117"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><h1 class="c26 c117" id="h.btua63bqoi1j"><span class="c12">Don&rsquo;t Tolerate Bad Behavior from Friends Either!</span></h1><p class="c1 c117"><span class="c8 c36">Do you find yourself accepting bad behavior from a friend that you wouldn&rsquo;t tolerate from others? It&rsquo;s important to recognize this pattern and practice assertiveness in your friendships too. </span></p><p class="c1 c7 c117"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1 c117"><span class="c36">As J.K. Rowling wisely said, </span><span class="c36 c32">&ldquo;It takes a great deal of bravery to stand up to our enemies, but just as much to stand up to our friends.&rdquo; </span><span class="c8 c36">Holding friends accountable is crucial for maintaining healthy, respectful relationships.</span></p><p class="c1 c7 c117"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1 c117"><span class="c36 c43">Your challenge</span><span class="c36 c43">: </span><span class="c8 c36">Reflect on any friendships where you&rsquo;ve overlooked bad behavior. Practice assertiveness by addressing these issues directly and kindly, ensuring that your relationships are based on mutual respect.</span></p><p class="c1 c7 c117"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1 c7 c117"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7 c117"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7 c117"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7 c117"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7 c117"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c59 c36">Not boundaries, Not </span><span class="c59 c36 c17">Assertive, defensi</span><span class="c59 c36">ve,</span><span class="c59 c36 c17">&nbsp;sensitive, nervy, &nbsp;timid, kowtowing, yesman, appeasing, passive, avoid</span><span class="c59 c36">ing conflict, bullied </span></p><h1 class="c136 c45 c61" id="h.xoxfzytyyym0"><span class="c12">Reclaim Your Power with the JADE Technique.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8 c36">The JADE technique is a powerful tool to help you establish and maintain healthy boundaries, especially when dealing with difficult or toxic individuals.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8 c36">&nbsp;JADE is an acronym that stands for a strategy. It&rsquo;s one that encourages you to refrain from engaging in certain unproductive behaviors. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c36">Trauma coach Dana Arcuri in </span><span class="c36 c43"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.goodreads.com/work/quotes/93934166&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586310570355&amp;usg=AOvVaw2JJ9OvEdZscd9Uwk628y79">Soul Rescue: How to Break Free From Narcissistic Abuse &amp; Heal Trauma</a></span><span class="c8 c36">&nbsp;breaks down the JADE acronym in this way:</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8 c36">J = Justify: Avoid the need to justify your actions to toxic people.</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8 c36">A = Argue: Don&rsquo;t waste your energy arguing with those who thrive on conflict.</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8 c36">D = Defend: Refrain from defending yourself to individuals who have no interest in understanding you.</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c36">E = Explain: Resist the urge to explain yourself to those who are intent on discrediting you.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c15 c36"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c36">Give this JADE approach a try. </span><span class="c8 c36">By following this approach, you can conserve your energy and maintain your sense of self-worth when faced with challenging situations.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c19"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c126 c45 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c126 c45 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c118 c40"></span></p><p class="c29 c7 c81"><span class="c33 c118 c40"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c118 c40"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span></p><p class="c126 c45"><span class="c100 c36">Not boundaries, Not </span><span class="c100 c36 c17">Assertiv</span><span class="c100 c36">e</span><span class="c100 c36 c17">, not self respect, </span><span class="c36 c100">manipulated easily, controlled</span><span class="c100 c36 c17">&nbsp;
