Sometimes, we even pick up on the emotions of people around us without realizing it.</span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c43">Your Challenge:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;The next time you feel angry, pause and ask yourself if the cause is really what it seems. Understanding this can help you manage your anger better and find peace.</span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c8">Remember, your anger is real, but the cause might not be what you think it is!</span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span>Resource: &nbsp;Gary van Warmerdam, </span><span class="c43">MindWorks: A Practical Guide for Changing Thoughts, Beliefs, and Emotional Reactions,</span></p><p class="c107 c45 c7"><span class="c73 c93 c36 c25"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c73 c93 c36 c25"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c73 c93 c36 c25"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c107 c45"><span class="c36 c236 c17">Anger, annoyed, intolerant</span></p><h1 class="c34 c61" id="h.hn6hgpwynjsq"><span>Try this strategy: </span><span class="c12">Calm your Anger by Counting Down.</span></h1><p class="c34"><span class="c8 c36">When you feel anger rising, it&rsquo;s important to catch it early before it gets out of control. Here is an old and simple trick to help. Simply stop what you&#39;re doing and silently count to 10&mdash;or even to 100 if you need more time.</span></p><p class="c34 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c34"><span class="c36">Thomas Jefferson put it this way:</span><span class="c36 c32">&nbsp;&quot;When angry, count to ten before you speak. If very angry, count to one hundred.&quot;</span></p><p class="c34 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c34"><span class="c8 c36">Counting gives you a moment to pause and cool down before reacting. It&rsquo;s like pressing the pause button on your emotions, giving you time to think clearly.</span></p><p class="c34 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c34 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c34 c7"><span class="c73 c36 c17 c25 c40"></span></p><p class="c34"><span class="c36 c43">Your Challenge:</span><span class="c8 c36">&nbsp;The next time you start to feel angry, take a deep breath and start counting. By the time you&rsquo;re done, you might find that the anger has softened, and you can respond more calmly.</span></p><p class="c34 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c34"><span class="c8 c36">Remember, a little pause can make a big difference when it comes to Anger!</span></p><p class="c34 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c34 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c34 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c34 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c107 c45"><span class="c36 c236 c17">Anger, annoyed , intolerant, hijacked </span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.ih4ujiaq8hvu"><span>Don&#39;t hold on to Anger: </span><span class="c12">Grow through Forgiveness. </span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8 c36">When we hold on to anger, it can make us feel small and stuck. But when we choose to forgive, we open the door to growth. We become better, stronger versions of ourselves.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c36">As Ch&eacute;rie Carter-Scott beautifully said:</span><span class="c18 c17">&nbsp;&quot;Anger makes you smaller, while forgiveness forces you to grow beyond what you were.&quot;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c36 c43">Understand this: </span><span class="c8 c36">Forgiving doesn&rsquo;t mean forgetting or accepting what happened. It&rsquo;s about letting go of the anger that holds you back, so you can move forward and grow.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8 c36">Remember, choose forgiveness, and give yourself the gift of growth.</span></p><p class="c22 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c66 c45 c36 c7"><span class="c33 c84 c269"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c10 c36 c17">Anger, </span><span class="c10 c36">&nbsp;reactive</span></p><h1 class="c104 c61" id="h.9f5jew4lvl5r"><span>Uncover</span><span class="c12">&nbsp;the Deeper Emotion Behind Your Anger.</span></h1><p class="c29"><span class="c8">Anger often signals a deeper issue or emotion. It might not be easy to identify, but it&#39;s worth exploring.</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c43">Consider this approach:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;The next time you feel angry, take a moment to pause and reflect. Ask yourself what might be hiding beneath that anger: For example&hellip;</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c8">&gt; Do you feel embarrassed or ashamed?</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c8">&gt; Do you feel sad?</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c8">&gt; Do you feel disappointed?</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c8">Understanding the true source of your anger can help you address the real issue and find peace. Give this a try. </span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c17 c40 c215">&nbsp;</span><span class="c64">{M: LATE}</span><span class="c5 c215">&nbsp; </span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c27">anger,</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; </span></p><h1 class="c34 c45 c61" id="h.ktuoe14tzaxp"><span class="c12">Discover More Ways to Manage Your Anger.</span></h1><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c8">If you need some extra help with managing your anger, it might be time to explore new strategies. Adding different techniques to your toolbox can make a big difference.</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c43">Check this out: </span><span class="c8">This video from MindTools.com explains 8 effective ways to overcome anger. It could give you the help you need!</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c71 c36"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.mindtools.com/pages/videos/anger-video-transcript.htm&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586310944029&amp;usg=AOvVaw3txAHR0wUoYK_OGRDHrwp2">8 Ways to Overcome Anger Video</a></span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c10 c36 c17">Anger, </span><span class="c10 c36">&nbsp;reactive, triggered,</span><span class="c10 c36 c17">&nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.9pacsvddcr39"><span class="c12">Realize that Anger is a Choice.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Do you truly understand that feeling angry is something you choose? It might seem surprising at first because anger often feels like it has a mind of its own. But is this really so? </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Try this contemplation:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Take a few moments to quietly reflect on the following question: How is my anger really my choice?</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>Lynn G. Robbins offers a helpful perspective on the topic:</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c33 c17 c32">&quot;Others don&#39;t make us angry. There is no force involved. Becoming angry is a conscious choice, a decision, therefore, we can make the choice not to become angry. We choose!&quot;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Remember this:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;You have the power to choose how you respond. So, next time, choose calm over anger.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; </span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c10 c36">Anger, &nbsp;reactive, triggered, </span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.bk5ljhg5jsen"><span class="c12">Try Art Therapy to help Manage your Anger.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Art can be a powerful way to calm yourself and release anger. Whether it&rsquo;s molding clay, drawing, or painting, artistic activities can help you express and soothe your emotions.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Consider this approach: </span><span class="c8">Use art as a tool to work through your anger. It can be as simple as sketching out how you feel or shaping clay to release tension.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Resource: This YouTube video from ThirstyForArt.com explains how you can use art therapy to manage anger.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c77 c40"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v%3DoiztNfsZnfU&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586310947283&amp;usg=AOvVaw3e5zBsUMyASO5tDh5yUtiW">Art Therapy Activity for Anger</a></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c0">Angry, annoyed, triggered, passive aggressive, resentful, grudge, grievance, shamed , guilt, &nbsp;grief, sensitivity to criticism, feeling victimized, resentment</span></p><p class="c45 c139"><span class="c37 c36 c17 c25">Process emotions through </span><span class="c37 c36 c25">J</span><span class="c37 c36 c17 c25">ournaling or </span><span class="c37 c36 c25">L</span><span class="c37 c36 c17 c25">etter </span><span class="c37 c36 c25">W</span><span class="c12 c36">riting.</span></p><p class="c139 c45"><span class="c37 c36 c17 c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8 c36">Getting our emotions out onto paper or into text can help process them. It can clarify why we feel the way we do, and how to deal with it.</span></p><p class="c22"><span class="c36 c43">Your Challenge</span><span class="c39 c36 c17">:</span><span class="c8 c36">&nbsp;Give journaling a try. Or write &lsquo;a letter&rsquo; which you don&rsquo;t send. This form of reflection provides more perspective and clarity. &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c22"><span class="c36">Consider these Journaling prompts</span><span class="c36 c17 c40">:</span><span class="c8 c36">&nbsp;Why were you triggered? &nbsp;What do you want and need? How can you convey what&rsquo;s going on within you to others?</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c22 c7"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c64">{M:LATE}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c17 c27">Angry, annoyed, &nbsp;arguing , aggressive, fighting, hijacked,</span></p><h1 class="c104 c61" id="h.q8wv35osm2d7"><span>Keep Persevering: Don&#39;t be too hard on yourself</span><span class="c12">.</span></h1><p class="c29"><span class="c8">It&rsquo;s not always easy to change how you respond to situations. Sometimes, you might still react quickly without thinking. Don&rsquo;t be too hard on yourself. What&rsquo;s important is that you keep trying.</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c43">Think about this:</span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">Am I getting better over time? Even small improvements matter.</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c8">Remember, the more you practice, the better you&rsquo;ll become at pausing and choosing a calm response.</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c27">Angry, reactive, annoyed, &nbsp;arguing , aggressive, fighting, hijacked,</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c104 c61" id="h.ahhc2gjbj0np"><span class="c12">Protect your mind&rsquo;s Clarity by managing your Anger.</span></h1><p class="c29"><span class="c8">Anger has a way of clouding our judgment and making it hard to think clearly. You have probably noticed this. </span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span>As Robert G. Ingersoll wisely said,</span><span class="c32">&nbsp;&ldquo;Anger blows out the lamp of the mind.&rdquo; </span><span class="c8">When we let anger take over, it&rsquo;s like turning off the light in a dark room&mdash;we lose our ability to see things clearly.</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c43">Consider this:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;How many times have you reacted in anger, only to regret it later? When anger takes control, it can lead us to make choices that aren&rsquo;t in our best interest.</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c70 c39 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c43">Your challenge:</span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">When you next feel anger rising, take a deep breath and pause. Remind yourself that by calming down, you&rsquo;re keeping the light of your mind on, allowing you to make better decisions.</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c8">Remember, managing your anger doesn&rsquo;t just protect your peace&mdash;it protects your ability to think clearly and respond wisely.</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c27">Angry, reactive, &nbsp;annoyed, &nbsp;arguing , aggressive, fighting, hijacked,</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c104 c61" id="h.cm90dxrbrw7s"><span class="c12">Avoid Mistakes: Pause when you are Angry.</span></h1><p class="c29"><span class="c8">Anger can be a powerful emotion, but acting on it can often lead to mistakes. This has probably happened to you too. </span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span>As Baltasar Gracian said, </span><span class="c32">&ldquo;Never do anything when you are in a temper, for you will do everything wrong.&rdquo; </span><span class="c8">When we&rsquo;re in a temper, our judgment is clouded, and we&rsquo;re more likely to act impulsively.</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c43">Consider this:</span><span class="c43 c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">How often have you done something in anger, only to wish you had handled it differently? That anger can easily push us to make hasty decisions that we later regret.</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c43">Challenge yourself</span><span class="c43">:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;The next time you feel your temper flaring, pause and take a moment to cool down. Give yourself time to think before you act. By doing so, you&rsquo;ll avoid making mistakes that could cause more harm than good.</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c8">Remember, taking a moment to pause when angry can save you from big regrets later.</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;HIGH</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c27">Angry, reactive, &nbsp;annoyed, &nbsp;arguing , aggressive, fighting, hijacked,</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c104 c61" id="h.844k5aofzsda"><span class="c12">Respond to Anger with Silence: Pause &amp; Reflect.</span></h1><p class="c29"><span class="c8">Anger is a powerful emotion, and it can often push us to say things we don&rsquo;t mean. But sometimes, the best way to handle anger is to say nothing at all.</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span>Marcus Aurelius, the famous Stoic philosopher from ancient Rome, offered this same wise advice: </span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&ldquo;The best answer to anger is silence.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c43">Consider this:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;When we choose silence instead of reacting in anger, we give ourselves time to cool down and think clearly. Silence can be a powerful tool&mdash;it helps us avoid saying things we might later regret and allows us to respond more thoughtfully.</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c43">Challenge yourself</span><span class="c43">: </span><span>When you are triggered or feel anger rising,</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;pause and stay silent. Give yourself some space and use that to process your emotions before speaking. You might find that the silence helps you see the situation in a new light and respond more calmly.</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c8">Remember, silence isn&rsquo;t weakness&mdash;it&rsquo;s a sign of strength and self-control.</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c27">Angry, reactive, &nbsp;annoyed, &nbsp;arguing , aggressive, fighting, hijacked,</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c104 c61" id="h.wv0ch8eujjr0"><span class="c12">The Calm Fighter Wins.</span></h1><p class="c29"><span>In moments of conflict, it&rsquo;s easy to think that anger gives us strength. But ancient wisdom tells us otherwise. Lao Tzu, a wise philosopher from ancient China, observed:</span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&nbsp;&ldquo;The best fighter is never angry.&rdquo;</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c43">Consider this:</span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">Anger can cloud our judgment and lead us to make hasty, harmful decisions. A calm mind, on the other hand, allows us to think clearly and act wisely. The best fighters, whether in battle or in life, are those who can keep their cool, even in difficult situations.</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c43">Your </span><span class="c43">challenge:</span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span>Realize</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;that staying calm and collected is your greatest strength. When you approach conflicts without anger, you&rsquo;re more likely to make decisions that lead to positive outcomes.</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c8">Remember, true strength lies in controlling your emotions, not letting them control you.</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c14"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c14"></span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c5">&nbsp; HIGH</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c17 c27">Angry, </span><span class="c27">grudge, grievance vendetta, </span><span class="c17 c27">&nbsp;arguing , aggressive, fighting, hijacked,</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26 c117" id="h.2so507uzhnbj"><span class="c12">Are you still Ingesting the Poison of Anger?</span></h1><p class="c1 c117"><span class="c8 c36">Anger is more than just an emotion&mdash;it&rsquo;s a toxin that can corrode your well-being from the inside out. Do you understand how this works? </span></p><p class="c1 c7 c117"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1 c117"><span class="c36">When we hold onto anger, it doesn&rsquo;t just hurt those around us; it harms us, too. Mitch Albom, the inspirational author, explains this further in this in his book </span><span class="c36 c43">The Five People You Meet in Heaven</span><span class="c8 c36">:</span></p><p class="c1 c117"><span class="c18 c17">&quot;Holding anger is a poison. It eats you from inside. We think that hating is a weapon that attacks the person who harmed us. But hatred is a curved blade. And the harm we do, we do to ourselves.&quot;</span></p><p class="c1 c7 c117"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c117"><span class="c36 c43">Consider this:</span><span class="c8 c36">&nbsp;When you hold onto anger, it&rsquo;s like swallowing poison and expecting someone else to suffer. The more we cling to it, the more it consumes us, damaging our mental and physical health.</span></p><p class="c1 c7 c117"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1 c117"><span class="c36 c43">Your Challenge: </span><span class="c8 c36">Are you still holding onto anger, letting it eat away at you? It&rsquo;s time to let go. Forgiveness and releasing anger are not about excusing others&mdash;they&rsquo;re about freeing yourself from the corrosive effects of anger.</span></p><p class="c1 c7 c117"><span class="c8 c36"></span></p><p class="c1 c117"><span class="c36">Remember, letting go of anger is a gift you give to yourself. It&rsquo;s time to stop ingesting the poison and start healing from within.</span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c18 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; HIGH</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c10">Not facing fears, reactive, triggered, impulsive, </span><span class="c10 c17">Anger,</span><span class="c10">&nbsp;</span><span class="c10 c17">hijacked, fight, </span><span class="c10">flight</span><span class="c10 c17">, aggressive, withdrawn, appeasing, avoid</span><span class="c10">ing conflict</span><span class="c10 c17">, timid, passive,</span></p><h1 class="c34 c45 c61" id="h.6kac6ygdnh6m"><span>Which Reactive Category Do You Fit Into?</span></h1><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c8">When life pushes our buttons, our Fear-based reactions typically fall into one of several reactive categories: Fight, Flight, Freeze, Fawn, Fantasy, or Flop. Understanding which category you tend to fit into can help you manage your responses better.</span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c43">Assess yourself:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;How do you typically react when triggered? Ponder this for a moment. Then consider which of the following Fear-based categories your reaction best fits in. &nbsp; </span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c156 c39 c17 c25">Here&rsquo;s a breakdown of these Fear-based categories:</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c43 c25">Fight:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;You might react with anger and impulsiveness, quickly lashing out when things don&rsquo;t go your way.</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c43 c25">Flight:</span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">You could feel anxious and try to escape the situation, often compensating defensively by avoiding confrontation.</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c43 c25">Freeze:</span><span class="c43">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">You may find yourself stuck, avoiding issues altogether, and struggling to make decisions or take action.</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c43 c25">Fawn:</span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">You might lean towards people-pleasing, often sacrificing your own boundaries and needs to keep the peace.</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c43 c25">Fantasy: </span><span>You escape into make-believe or magical thinking as a way to mentally flee from reality. </span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c43 c25">Flop:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;In some cases, you might feel so overwhelmed that you give up entirely, feeling defeated and powerless to act.</span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c43">Your challenge:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Identify your typical responses to stress or fear. This can be the first step in managing it more effectively. By recognizing your patterns, you can begin to choose healthier and more balanced ways to react when you&rsquo;re triggered.</span></p><p class="c34 c45"><span class="c8">Remember, awareness is the key to change. Understanding your reactive category helps you take control and respond more mindfully in challenging situations.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; </span></p><p class="c56 c45 c13"><span class="c10">unrealistic expectations, </span><span class="c10">anger, reactive, fight, annoyance, hijacked, resentment, grievance, passive-aggressive,self righteous, intolerance, kamikaze, dogmatic, zealot, </span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.i0eysg6ndy4y"><span>Do you have a too Rigid</span><span class="c12">&nbsp;Perception of Fairness?</span></h1><p class="c1"><span>We often react</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;when we perceive something as unfair. We hold specific expectations of what should happen and what we believe is &lsquo;right&rsquo; or &lsquo;fair.&rsquo; However, it&rsquo;s important to remember that our view of fairness may not align with others&rsquo; perspectives.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Because our anger is often based on personal perception rather than true moral principles, we can hopefully change this too. Psychiatrist David Burns explains this further:</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c33 c17 c32">&quot;The perception of unfairness or injustice is the ultimate cause of most, if not all, anger... In fact, fairness is simply a perceptual interpretation... Your assumption that they are &lsquo;being unfair&rsquo; implies that your way of looking at things is universally accepted.&quot; </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c4">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Consider this</span><span class="c43">: </span><span class="c8">Could your anger be fueled by a belief that everyone should see things your way? By realizing that fairness is subjective, you can begin to let go of the anger that stems from unmet expectations.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Challenge</span><span class="c43">&nbsp;yourself: </span><span class="c8">The next time you feel anger over perceived injustice, pause and reflect on whether your view is the only way of interpreting the situation. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">This shift in perception could help you overcome your anger and approach the situation with greater understanding.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>Resource:</span><span class="c43">&nbsp;David D. Burns, Feeling Good: The New Mood Therapy</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c34 c45 c7"><span class="c33 c10 c17"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp; </span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c17 c74">anger, fight, annoyance, hijacked, resentment, grievance, passive-aggressive,self righteous, intolerance, kamikaze</span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><h1 class="c26 c13" id="h.lxnsl4kf5ims"><span class="c12">Is your Anger Really Helping or Hurting You?</span></h1><p class="c1 c13"><span>When you feel angry, it&rsquo;s important to pause and ask yourself a crucial question suggested by Psychiatrist David Burns:</span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c33 c17 c32">&quot;Is my anger useful? Does it help me achieve a desired goal or does it simply defeat me?&quot;</span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c43">Consider this</span><span class="c25">:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Is your anger actually helping you get what you want, or is it just making things worse? Sometimes, anger can motivate us to take action, but more often, it can cloud our judgment and lead to outcomes we don&rsquo;t really want.</span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c43">Challenge</span><span class="c43">&nbsp;yourself:</span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">The next time you feel anger rising, pause and reflect on whether it&rsquo;s moving you closer to your goals or pushing you further away. Understanding this can help you make better choices and avoid letting anger undermine you.</span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c8">Remember, not all anger is beneficial&mdash;choose wisely in how you respond.</span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span>Resource:</span><span class="c32">&nbsp;</span><span>David D. Burns, </span><span class="c70 c39 c17">Feeling Good: The New Mood Therapy</span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c14"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c14"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; HIGH &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c121 c45 c13"><span class="c10">anger, fight, annoyance, hijacked, resentment, grievance, passive-aggressive,self righteous, intolerance, kamikaze</span></p><h1 class="c45 c61 c190" id="h.24bkgrbyyybf"><span class="c12">View Anger as a Messenger, Not a Way of Life.</span></h1><p class="c11"><span class="c8">Have you ever wondered if anger can be healthy? Can it be harnessed for good rather than letting it cause harm? The answer is yes&mdash;anger can be beneficial, but only if we treat it as a messenger and use it wisely.</span></p><p class="c11"><span class="c43">Here&rsquo;s how it works:</span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">Anger isn&rsquo;t meant to be unleashed as raw aggression or suppressed as passive-aggression. Instead of reacting impulsively, we can choose to respond with thoughtfulness and compassion. When we do this, anger becomes a tool for positive change. </span></p><p class="c11"><span class="c8">Anger can alert us to injustices, motivate us to take action, and give us the energy to push forward. But using anger constructively requires practice and self-awareness.</span></p><p class="c11"><span class="c43">Your challenge</span><span class="c43">:</span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">Let anger be your signal, not your master. With wisdom and practice, you can transform anger into a powerful force for positive outcomes, rather than allowing it to control your life.</span></p><p class="c11 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c11 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c11 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp; </span></p><p class="c121 c45 c13"><span class="c10">anger, fight, annoyance, hijacked, resentment, grievance, passive-aggressive,self righteous, intolerance, kamikaze</span></p><h1 class="c190 c45 c61" id="h.6zrbvd1lqkdu"><span class="c12">Your Anger Can Reveal Where You Stand.</span></h1><p class="c11"><span class="c8">Anger, when handled wisely, can be more than just a disruptive emotion&mdash;it can be a valuable guide. Consider how this process might work. </span></p><p class="c11"><span class="c8">This powerful feeling often points out what truly matters to us. It can highlight injustices we perceive, the changes we desire, and the boundaries we need to set. But it&#39;s up to us to use this alert system and its energy wisely </span></p><p class="c11 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c11"><span>Self-help author Brianna Wiest explains anger&#39;s true purpose this way:</span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&nbsp;&quot;Ultimately, anger is trying to mobilize us, to initiate action.&quot;</span></p><p class="c11"><span class="c8">Anger&rsquo;s purpose is to motivate us, urging us to take action where it&rsquo;s needed. However, the real challenge lies in how we choose to express it. Problems however arise when we either lash out at others in aggression or turn that anger inward, harming ourselves.</span></p><p class="c11"><span class="c43">Your Challenge</span><span class="c43">:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;The next time you feel anger bubbling up, try to see it as a signal, not a problem. Ask yourself what this emotion is revealing about your values, your boundaries, and what changes you need to make.</span></p><p class="c11"><span>Realize that a</span><span class="c8">nger can be a powerful tool for self-awareness and positive action&mdash;if you manage it carefully. Rather than letting it lead to destructive behavior, use it to gain insight into where you stand and what steps you need to take.</span></p><p class="c11 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c11 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c11 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp; </span></p><p class="c11"><span class="c17 c74">anger, fight, hijacked, annoyance, passive-aggression, vengeance, vendetta, grievance, grudge</span></p><h1 class="c190 c45 c61" id="h.snkhm5vnkcle"><span class="c12">Harness Anger as a Catalyst for Positive Change.</span></h1><p class="c11"><span class="c8">Anger is a powerful emotion, but its true value lies in how we choose to use it. Can you guess what this approach might be? </span></p><p class="c11"><span class="c8">Author Brianna Wiest offers this guidance on how to use anger:</span></p><p class="c11"><span class="c33 c17 c32">&quot;...anger is not intended to be projected onto someone else; rather, it&#39;s an influx of motivation that helps us to change what we need to change within our lives.&quot;</span></p><p class="c11"><span class="c8">When we recognize anger as a signal for self-improvement rather than a weapon to wield against others, we can address the real issues at their core. If we fail to see anger in this light, it often spirals into aggression, harming our relationships and leaving the root cause unresolved.</span></p><p class="c11"><span class="c43">Your Challenge</span><span class="c43">:</span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">The next time anger flares up, pause and consider how you can channel that energy into constructive change. Instead of letting it fuel conflict, use it as a driving force to improve your situation or transform yourself.</span></p><p class="c11"><span class="c43">The take-home message: </span><span class="c8">Anger, when harnessed with intention, can be a powerful catalyst for growth and transformation. Don&rsquo;t let it consume you&mdash;use it to propel yourself forward.</span></p><p class="c11 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><h1 class="c11 c61" id="h.26in1rg"><span class="c19 c120 c40">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span><span class="c73 c17 c25 c40">&nbsp;</span></h1><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; HIGH &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c11"><span class="c17 c74">anger, fight, passive aggressive, annoyance, resentment, vengeance, vendetta grievance, grudge, hijacked, worked up, learned helplessness</span><span class="c17 c25 c74">,</span><span class="c17 c74">&nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c190 c45 c61" id="h.arksm6k2rla4"><span class="c12">Understand the Hidden Factors That Fuel Your Anger.</span></h1><p class="c11"><span class="c8">Have you ever considered what might be driving your anger beyond the obvious? There could be hidden motivators that influence your reactions without you even realizing it.</span></p><p class="c11"><span class="c8">Anger management expert Aaron Karmin suggests exploring the underlying factors that might be fueling your anger:</span></p><p class="c11"><span class="c156 c39 c17 c25">Consider 5 Factors that might be Fueling your Anger: </span></p><ol class="c41 lst-kix_2d4c8q8lcg42-0 start" start="1"><li class="c11 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c43 c25">Seeking Revenge:</span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">When we feel hurt, anger can drive us to seek revenge as a way to make things feel fair.</span></li><li class="c11 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c43 c25">Preventing Helplessness:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Anger can be a way to take control when we feel powerless or vulnerable.</span></li><li class="c11 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c43 c25">Pushing Others Away:</span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">Sometimes, we use anger to distance ourselves from others, avoiding judgment or rejection.</span></li><li class="c11 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c43 c25">Getting Attention: </span><span class="c8">If we feel disrespected or ignored, anger might be our way of demanding the attention we crave.</span></li><li class="c11 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c43 c25">Reducing Discomfort:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;When feeling overwhelmed, anger can act as a release, helping to reduce internal discomfort.</span></li></ol><p class="c11"><span class="c43">Your Challenge:</span><span>&nbsp;Consider w</span><span class="c8">hich of these hidden factors might be influencing your anger? By identifying the underlying motivators, you can gain greater control over your emotions and respond in a healthier way.</span></p><p class="c11"><span class="c8">Understanding what drives your anger is a big step toward mastering it. Take the time to reflect and see if any of these hidden factors resonate with you.</span></p><p class="c11"><span>Recommended </span><span>Resource:</span><span class="c43">&nbsp; </span><span>Aaron Karmin, </span><span class="c43">Anger Management Workbook for Men:</span><span class="c43">Take Control of Your Anger and Master Your Emotions</span></p><p class="c11 c7"><span class="c33 c178 c17"></span></p><p class="c11 c7"><span class="c33 c178 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c11 c7"><span class="c33 c178 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; HIGH &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c17 c74">anger, fight, hijacked, harsh, annoyance, intolerance, passive aggressive</span></p><h1 class="c190 c45 c61" id="h.k78lc48eop5u"><span class="c12">Understand the &lsquo;Four Keys&rsquo; to Anger Management.</span></h1><p class="c11"><span class="c8">Anger management isn&rsquo;t just about suppressing your feelings&mdash;it&rsquo;s about adopting strategies that help you handle anger in a healthy way,</span></p><p class="c11"><span class="c8">Aaron Karmin, an expert in anger management, outlines four essential keys to managing anger: &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c11"><span class="c156 c39 c17 c25">These 4 Keys to effectively managing anger are:</span></p><ol class="c41 lst-kix_llevrcu3yzs-0 start" start="1"><li class="c11 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c43 c25">Expressing Yourself:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Learn to communicate your feelings openly and honestly, rather than bottling them up or letting them explode.</span></li><li class="c11 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c43 c25">Taking Care of Yourself:</span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">Prioritize self-care, ensuring that your physical, emotional, and mental well-being are in check. This helps prevent anger from taking over.</span></li><li class="c11 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c43 c25">Building Tolerance for Frustration:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Develop patience and resilience, which will allow you to stay calm even in challenging situations.</span></li><li class="c11 c79 c24 li-bullet-0"><span class="c43 c25">Maintaining a Positive Outlook:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Focus on the positive aspects of life, which can help shift your mindset away from anger and toward more constructive emotions.</span></li></ol><p class="c11"><span class="c43">Challenge yourself:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;How can you incorporate these four principles into your daily life? Use better communication, self-care routines, practicing patience, or cultivating positivity, to better manage your anger.</span></p><p class="c11"><span class="c8">By integrating these strategies into your routine, you can take control of your emotions and create a more balanced, peaceful life.</span></p><p class="c11 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c11"><span>Recommended resource: &nbsp;Aaron Karmin, </span><span class="c43">Anger Management Workbook for Men: Take Control of Your Anger and Master Your Emotions</span><span class="c8">:</span></p><p class="c11 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c121 c45 c13 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; HIGH &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c74">A</span><span class="c17 c74">ggression, reactive, anger, aggravation, hijacked,</span></p><h1 class="c26 c13" id="h.v1ncp17n3szv"><span>Understand w</span><span class="c12">hy Explosive Anger Is Counterproductive.</span></h1><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c8">It&rsquo;s easy to feel the urge to &ldquo;explode&rdquo; when you&rsquo;re angry, and to use that moment to let off steam. However, while it might provide temporary relief, explosive anger often backfires, making situations worse and leading to lasting regrets.</span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span>As the journalist and writer Ambrose Bierce insightfully remarked: </span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&quot;Speak when you are angry and you will make the best speech you will ever regret.&quot;</span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c73 c17 c25 c40"></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c43">Consider this:</span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">When you lash out in anger, you may say or do things that harm your relationships and escalate conflicts. The momentary satisfaction of venting is rarely worth the damage it can cause.</span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c43">Your Challenge:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Next time anger flares up, take a deep breath and pause before reacting. </span></p><p class="c1 c13"><span class="c8">By choosing to manage your anger wisely, you can avoid unnecessary regrets and foster more positive, constructive outcomes in your interactions with others.</span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c13 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;HIGH &nbsp; </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c17 c74">Anger, hijacked, annoyance, intolerance, oppositional-view</span><span class="c17">,</span><span class="c17 c74">&nbsp;harsh </span><span class="c17 c25">&nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c34 c61" id="h.t6vr0luzec5d"><span class="c12">Hit the &lsquo;PAUSE&rsquo; button to Diffuse your Anger.</span></h1><p class="c34"><span class="c8">When anger flares up, it can feel overwhelming, but the good news is that you have the power to control it. If you can just pause your anger response for just 90 seconds, it will usually begin to subside. This will happen naturally when you give yourself a few moments to break the cycle of reactive thinking.</span></p><p class="c34"><span>Neuroanatomist Dr. Jill Bolte Taylor explains why this simple strategy works: </span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&quot;We experience anger when the &lsquo;anger circuit&rsquo; in our brain is stimulated. Anger is just a group of cells in our brain that have been triggered, and we have the power to choose to act out or not. It only takes 90 seconds for that circuit to settle down.&quot;</span></p><p class="c34"><span class="c43">Here&rsquo;s the key:</span><span class="c43">&nbsp;</span><span>Understand that</span><span class="c43">&nbsp;</span><span>a</span><span class="c8">fter your brain is triggered, it&rsquo;s hijacked by anger for about 90 seconds. So, during this time your best strategy is to stop, pause, and delay any immediate reaction. If you can hold off for those crucial 90 seconds, you&rsquo;ll find that your anger begins to fade, allowing you to respond more calmly and wisely.</span></p><p class="c34"><span class="c43">Challenge yourself: </span><span class="c8">The next time you feel anger rising, hit the pause button. Give yourself those essential 90 seconds to let the storm pass. You&rsquo;ll likely notice an immediate benefit in how you handle the situation.</span></p><p class="c34 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c34 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c34 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c34 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;HIGH </span></p><p class="c107 c45 c36 c61 subtitle" id="h.udueqqgdticb"><span class="c17 c74">anger, hijacked, fight, annoyance, hyper-critical, oppositional-view, judgemental</span><span class="c17 c25 c74">&nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c34 c61" id="h.iptnm5e71m49"><span class="c12">Use a &lsquo;Countdown Technique&rsquo; to Diffuse Your Anger.</span></h1><p class="c34"><span class="c8">When anger strikes, it&rsquo;s easy to react impulsively and get fired up. But before you do, try a simple countdown technique. </span></p><p class="c34"><span class="c43">Here is how to do it: </span><span class="c8">&nbsp;First PAUSE and then count down slowly from 10 to zero. If you&rsquo;re still feeling the heat, repeat the countdown until your anger starts to fade.</span></p><p class="c34"><span>If you&rsquo;re really fired up, count down from 100 instead. Keep going until you notice your emotions cooling down. Once you&rsquo;ve given yourself this time, you&rsquo;ll find that you&rsquo;re able to respond more calmly and wisely.</span></p><p class="c34"><span class="c43">Challenge yourself</span><span class="c43">: </span><span class="c8">The next time anger threatens to take over, give yourself a moment to pause and start counting down. This simple act can make all the difference, helping you stay in control and respond with clarity.</span></p><p class="c34 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp; </span></p><p class="c107 c45 c36 c61 subtitle" id="h.4i7ojhp"><span class="c17 c74">anger, reactive, hijacked, fight, annoyance, oppositional-view, </span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.z2wa1y7lf1qb"><span>Use t</span><span class="c12">he Power of Delay: A Simple Remedy for Anger.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">We&rsquo;ve all experienced those moments when anger flares up, threatening to take control. Whether it&rsquo;s a frustrating situation at work, a disagreement with a loved one, or just one of those days, anger can sneak up on us when we least expect it. But what if there was a simple way to keep it in check?</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>Seneca, the ancient philosopher, offered a timeless piece of wisdom:</span><span class="c32">&nbsp;&quot;The greatest remedy for anger is delay.&quot; </span><span>His</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;advice is incredibly relatable and still practical today. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">When we&rsquo;re angry, our first instinct might be to react immediately&mdash;whether that&rsquo;s snapping at someone, sending a hasty text, or making a decision we&rsquo;ll later regret. But by simply delaying our response, we give ourselves a chance to cool down and think more clearly.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Your challenge: </span><span class="c8">When you next feel anger rising, pause. Take a deep breath, count to ten, or even walk away for a moment. This brief delay can make all the difference, allowing you to respond with a clear mind instead of reacting in the heat of the moment.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Remember, delaying your response isn&rsquo;t about ignoring your feelings&mdash;it&rsquo;s about giving yourself the time to process them. In the end, you&rsquo;ll find that this small act of patience can lead to much wiser decisions and fewer regrets.</span></p><p class="c248 c45 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c45 c7 c248"><span class="c33 c17 c74"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp;HIGH &nbsp; </span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c17 c74">Anger, emotional dysregulation, hijacked, fight, reactive, grievance, vengeance, </span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.erm7t43qjhgn"><span class="c12">What, If Anything, Is Truly Worth Your Anger?</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Have you ever paused to consider if your anger was really worth it? Do you really understand the cost? </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>Seneca, the ancient Roman philosopher, believed that anger is rarely, if ever, worth the cost. He said, </span><span class="c32">&quot;Your anger is a kind of madness, because you set a high price on worthless things.&quot;</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Seneca saw anger as an emotion that often clouds our judgment and leads us to place value on things that don&rsquo;t really matter. Could he be right? </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Consider this</span><span class="c43">:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;How often do we let small annoyances or trivial matters stir up our anger? In those moments, we&rsquo;re essentially allowing things of little importance to steal our peace of mind and happiness.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Challenge yourself:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Next time you feel anger bubbling up, ask yourself: Is this really worth my energy? More often than not, you&rsquo;ll find that the answer is no. By letting go of unnecessary anger, you free yourself to focus on what truly matters in life.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Remember, most things that provoke anger aren&rsquo;t worth the price we pay emotionally. Choose wisely where you direct your energy, and you&rsquo;ll find greater peace and clarity.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; HIGH &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c17 c74">Anger, emotional dysregulation, reactive, hijacked, fight, grievance, vengeance, </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.gt0rho465l3v"><span class="c12">Release Trapped Anger with this Simple Technique.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Have you ever noticed where anger tends to settle in your body? If you can pinpoint where that tension or &lsquo;heat&rsquo; is building up, this technique might be just what you need to release it:</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Here&rsquo;s how it works:</span><span>&nbsp;Place your hands gently on the area where you feel the anger most intensely&mdash;whether it&rsquo;s in your chest, stomach, or even your jaw. Take slow, deep breaths, directing your breath into that spot. Allow any emotions that surface to arise without resistance. Just let them flow. After a few moments, slowly relax your hands and notice how the tension begins to ease.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Here&rsquo;s why it works: </span><span class="c8">This technique helps you connect with your body, giving you a chance to acknowledge and release the anger stored within. It&#39;s a form of emotional processing. By focusing your breath and attention on the area where the anger is trapped, you both invite it to go and visualize it dissolving. This emotion processing and clearing process can leave you feeling calmer and more centered.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Next time you feel anger building up, give this a try. It&rsquo;s a gentle yet powerful way to release that trapped energy and restore a sense of balance.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>Resource: Inna Segal, </span><span class="c43">The Secret Language of Your Body: The Essential Guide to Healing:</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; HIGH &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c17 c74">Anger, rage, &nbsp;fight, hijacked, reactive, emotional dysregulation, resentment, grudge, grievance, vengeance, vendetta,</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.qx3zht9vkvj4"><span>A Review: </span><span class="c12">Reflect on the Last Time You Felt Anger.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Think back to the last time you felt enraged by something or someone. Was it really worth it? </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c70 c39 c17">Take a moment to consider the following:</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">&gt; What were the consequences or fallout from your anger?</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">&gt; How did it make you feel inside, both during and after?</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">&gt; Was your response proportionate to the situation?</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">&gt; How long did it take you to calm down and recover?</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Maybe it was another driver cutting you off, or perhaps someone spoke to you disrespectfully. Consider how you reacted in that moment? Did your anger help resolve the situation, or did it only add fuel to the fire?</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span>As the Buddha wisely said: </span><span class="c33 c17 c32">&quot;You will not be punished for your anger, you will be punished by your anger.&quot;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Challenge yourself</span><span class="c43">:</span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">The next time anger flares up, consider the true cost. Often, it&rsquo;s not the external situation that harms us most, but the internal turmoil we allow anger to create. By choosing to respond more calmly, you can avoid the self-inflicted wounds that anger often leaves behind.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Remember, it&rsquo;s not just about what happens in the moment&mdash;it&rsquo;s about how you carry those feelings forward. Choose wisely, and protect your peace.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c32"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp; </span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c74">A</span><span class="c17 c74">nger, rage, &nbsp;fight, hijacked, reactive, triggered, emotional dysregulation,</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.z47b1wgi8xu"><span class="c12">Track what Triggers your Anger: Learn from this.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c20 c17">Understanding what triggers your anger is a key step in managing it effectively. One simple yet powerful way to do this is by keeping an &ldquo;Anger Diary.&rdquo; You simply write down or journal your triggers and responses. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c43">How to do it: </span><span class="c20 c17">Each time you feel anger rising, make a note of the situation, what triggered it and your back story. </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c20 c17">For example:</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c20 c17">&gt; What was the setting &amp; what contributed to your reaction? </span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c20 c17">&gt; When triggered, were you tired, dehydrated, or hungry?</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c20 c17">&gt; Did you take steps to address these issues afterward?</span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c20 c17">But don&rsquo;t stop there&mdash;also record how successful you were in calming yourself down.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c20 c17">By identifying these patterns, you can start to see connections between your physical and emotional states and your anger. This awareness can help you take proactive steps to manage those triggers before they escalate.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c43">Challenge yourself:</span><span class="c58">&nbsp;</span><span class="c58">Remember, t</span><span class="c20 c17">he goal isn&rsquo;t just to track your anger, but to learn from it. Celebrate your successes in calming yourself, and use your insights to better navigate future situations.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c237 c84"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c84 c237"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c14"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; HIGH &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c74">Repressing emotions, not assertive,, repressed emotion suppressed emotions, passive aggressive, not boundary setting, not empowered , powerlessness, disempowered </span></p><p class="c82 c45"><span class="c12">Do you Suppress your Anger rather than process it?</span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c8">When something triggers your anger, do you often find yourself holding it in. Do you opt to stay quiet and give in to someone else&rsquo;s bad behavior? </span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c8">While suppressing anger might seem like the easiest way to avoid conflict, it can lead to unresolved tension and internal stress over time.</span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c43">Challenge yourself:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;The next time you feel anger rising, consider how you could respond differently. Instead of bottling up your emotions, what would be a healthier, non-reactive way to handle the situation?</span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c8">Perhaps you could set a clear boundary, express your feelings calmly and constructively. &nbsp;Or simply take a moment to pause and breathe before reacting. The goal is to find a balance where you acknowledge your anger without letting it dictate your actions.</span></p><p class="c56 c45 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c43">The take-home message:</span><span>&nbsp;Aim to</span><span class="c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c8">move from suppressing your anger to managing it in a way that&rsquo;s both healthy and empowering? By exploring these approaches, you can start to transform your reactions, leading to more positive and balanced outcomes in your relationships and daily life.</span></p><p class="c82 c45 c7"><span class="c73 c59 c17 c25"></span></p><p class="c45 c7 c82"><span class="c73 c59 c17 c25"></span></p><p class="c82 c45 c7"><span class="c73 c59 c17 c25"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c14"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c74"></span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c74"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp; </span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c17 c74">A</span><span class="c17 c74">nger, reactive, fight, hijacked, emotional dysregulation,</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.jhzn2kp3o98o"><span>Consider w</span><span class="c12">hat Lurks Beneath your Mask of Anger?</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c20 c17">Have you ever wondered if your anger is just a mask for something deeper? Sometimes, we use anger as a cover to hide more vulnerable feelings like hurt, disappointment, or fear. These emotions can make us feel exposed, weak, or helpless&mdash;so instead, we express anger as a way to protect ourselves.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c43">Consider this: </span><span class="c20 c17">By acknowledging the true source of your anger, you can start to address the root of the issue, rather than just reacting to the symptoms. This awareness can help you respond more authentically and constructively, leading to greater emotional well-being.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c43">Ask yourself:</span><span class="c20 c17">&nbsp;What was really driving your most recent anger? Understanding this can be the first step in moving beyond anger to a place of healing and growth.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c43">Challenge yourself</span><span class="c58 c43">:</span><span class="c20 c17">&nbsp;The next time you experience an outburst of anger, pause and consider what might be lurking beneath the surface. Was your anger really about the situation at hand, or was it masking deeper emotions like sadness, fear, or hurt?</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; HIGH &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c17 c74">Anger, rage</span><span class="c74">,</span><span class="c17 c74">&nbsp;fight, arguing, reactive</span><span class="c74">,</span><span class="c17 c74">&nbsp;hijacked, emotional dysregulation, </span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.yuym1sb6ed96"><span class="c12">Uncover the Hidden Emotions Beneath Your Anger.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Anger is often just the tip of the iceberg, with many other emotions, feelings, or behaviors lurking beneath the surface. These other underlying emotions can be difficult to recognize because they&rsquo;re often hidden beneath the reactive anger we display on the surface.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">Challenge yourself:</span><span class="c8">&nbsp;Uncover what might these additional emotions be for you? When you experience anger, what other feelings might be contributing to it? Are there deeper emotions such as hurt, fear, or sadness that you haven&rsquo;t acknowledged?</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">To help you explore these hidden emotions, take a look at the infographic below from the Gottman Institute (link below). It&rsquo;s a valuable tool for identifying the complex feelings that can be masked by anger. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c43">The big question: </span><span>Using the graphic below,</span><span class="c43">&nbsp;</span><span>w</span><span class="c8">hich of those hidden emotions below the waterline might apply to you? &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">By recognizing these deeper emotions, you can gain a better understanding of your anger and begin to address the root causes, rather than just reacting to the symptoms. This awareness can lead to more constructive responses and emotional healing.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c8">Understanding these hidden emotions is another big step towards managing your anger more effectively and finding peace beneath the storm.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c8"></span></p><h1 class="c1 c61 c7" id="h.qdtha2p65csk"><span class="c73 c58 c17 c25"></span></h1><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span style="overflow: hidden; display: inline-block; margin: 0.00px 0.00px; border: 0.00px solid #000000; transform: rotate(0.00rad) translateZ(0px); -webkit-transform: rotate(0.00rad) translateZ(0px); width: 624.00px; height: 814.67px;"><img alt="anger-iceberg-1" src="images/image7.png" style="width: 624.00px; height: 814.67px; margin-left: 0.00px; margin-top: 0.00px; transform: rotate(0.00rad) translateZ(0px); -webkit-transform: rotate(0.00rad) translateZ(0px);" title=""></span><sup><a href="#cmnt4" id="cmnt_ref4">[d]</a></sup></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58">SOURCE: </span><span class="c71 c17"><a class="c89" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://community.thriveglobal.com/the-anger-iceberg/&amp;sa=D&amp;source=editors&amp;ust=1745586311013045&amp;usg=AOvVaw057VG88d-3GtqT5OjyURwF">Thrive Global The Anger Iceberg</a></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c211"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c29 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c211"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c33 c17 c211"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp; </span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c17 c74">Anger, upset, rage, triggered, hijacked, emotional dysregulation, </span><span class="c74">upset</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.cpy1mjlxcnxq"><span class="c12">Distance Yourself: Unattach from the Drama.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c58">R</span><span class="c20 c17">ecognize that often, it&rsquo;s not the event itself that triggers your anger or upset&mdash;it&rsquo;s your thoughts about the event. These thoughts can amplify emotions and create unnecessary drama. But here&rsquo;s the empowering part: you can step in and stop this reaction before it spirals out of control. It&#39;s called &lsquo;self distancing&rsquo;. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c43">Consider</span><span class="c58 c43">&nbsp;this approach:</span><span class="c58 c25">&nbsp;&lsquo;</span><span class="c58">Self-distancing</span><span class="c20 c17">&rsquo; involves consciously un-attaching yourself from the narrative that&rsquo;s fueling your anger. Just resist getting entangled in the drama or the storyline your mind is creating. Do you get the general idea? </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c43">How to do</span><span class="c58 c43 c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c58 c43">it:</span><span class="c58 c25">&nbsp;</span><span class="c20 c17">When you feel negative thoughts starting to take over, deliberately shift your attention away from them. Focus on something positive and uplifting instead&mdash;whether it&rsquo;s a calming activity, an inspiring piece of music, or a pleasant memory. Redirecting your thoughts in this way can have a profound effect.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c43">Challenge yourself:</span><span class="c58">&nbsp;</span><span class="c20 c17">You have the power to choose where your mind goes. By distancing yourself from negative thoughts and the accompanying drama, you can maintain a calm, clear, and centered state of mind. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c20 c17">With practice, this distancing technique can help you manage your emotions more effectively and keep you in control.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c17">&nbsp; </span><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c17 c74">Anger, rage, reactive, emotional dysregulation, passive aggressive, grudge, grievance, vengeance, worked-up, obstinate, oppositional-view, annoyance,</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.19ux6bwswkx1"><span class="c12">Try this Strategy for Anger: Unattach from Negative thoughts.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c20 c17">When you feel anger bubbling up, consider using this simple technique: un-attach from the negative thoughts in your mind. The key is to do this early, before your emotions get too intense.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c43">Consider this</span><span class="c58 c43">:</span><span class="c20 c17">&nbsp;You might catch yourself thinking that what someone did is unforgivable and that they deserve punishment. But here&rsquo;s the hard truth&mdash;it&rsquo;s not the event itself causing your pain, it&rsquo;s your thoughts about it. So, the more you focus on those negative thoughts, the angrier you feel.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c43">Here&rsquo;s what to do</span><span class="c58 c25">:</span><span class="c20 c17">&nbsp;Stop giving those thoughts your attention. Just un-attach from them&mdash;don&rsquo;t let them take up your energy. When you stop feeding those thoughts, the anger and pain will start to fade on their own.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c43">Your challenge</span><span class="c58 c43">:</span><span class="c20 c17">&nbsp;As soon as negative thoughts pop up, practice distancing yourself from them. This simple shift can help you keep your cool and stay in control.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c19">==== ------ ++++++ &nbsp; this is the delimiter at the end of the blog post ++++++ ------ ====</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c29"><span class="c2">{M:MID}</span><span class="c21">&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p class="c56 c45"><span class="c10">&nbsp;Reactive, triggered, negative mindset, </span><span class="c10 c17">Anger, reactive, hijacked, emotional dysregulation, passive aggressive, vengeance, vendetta, grudge, grievance, &nbsp;</span></p><h1 class="c26" id="h.1sl6arsnm0w0"><span>Practice Distancing: </span><span class="c12">Don&rsquo;t get Caught Up in the Drama.</span></h1><p class="c1"><span class="c20 c17">Do you sometimes find yourself making situations worse by overthinking or getting too wrapped up in the story? Here&rsquo;s a tip: Calm your inner dialogue. </span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c20 c17">Work on quieting your mind and avoid engaging with those negative thoughts that can spiral out of control.</span></p><p class="c1 c7"><span class="c20 c17"></span></p><p class="c1"><span class="c58 c43">Consider this Strategy:</span><span class="c20 c17">&nbsp;When you notice yourself getting drawn into the drama, take a mental step back.
